CHAPTER 3. - TELEVISION 

Sec. 3-3001. - Television antenna service; agreement authorized. 
    The mayor of the City of Westlake, Louisiana, be and he is hereby authorized to enter into an agreement with the partnership of R. H. Tyler, a resident of Olney, Texas, and Wilbur A. Green, a resident of DeRidder, Louisiana, or its successors or assigns, authorizing the partnership of R. H. Tyler, a resident of Olney, Texas, and Wilbur A. Green, a resident of DeRidder, Louisiana, or its successors or assigns, to construct, operate and maintain a television antenna service and electronic distribution system along, over and under the streets, avenues, parkways and public places in the City of Westlake, Louisiana, and otherwise evidencing the franchise rights and privileges, herein granted to the partnership of R. H. Tyler, a resident of Olney, Texas, and Wilbur A. Green, a resident of DeRidder, Louisiana, or its successors or assigns. 
(Ord. No. 298, § 1, 2-9-78) 
Sec. 3-3002. - Agreement incorporated. 
    The agreement shall be substantially on the same terms and items as the following proposed agreement attached to Ordinance No. 298 and made a part thereof. 
(Ord. No. 298, § 2, 2-9-78) 
Community Television Franchise Agreement 
Section I. 
    The word "city" as hereinafter used shall mean and designate the City of Westlake, and the words "company" or "franchisee" as hereinafter used shall mean and designate Cable Communications System. "Cable communications system," "cable system," or "CATV" or "system" shall mean a system of coaxial cables or other electrical conductors and equipment used or to be used to originate or receive television or radio signals directly or indirectly off the air and to transmit them via cable to subscribers for a fixed or variable fee, including the originations, receipt, transmission, and distribution of voices, sound signals, pictures, visual images, digital signals, telemetry, or any other type of closed circuit transmission by means of electrical impulses, whether or not directed to originating signals or receiving signals off the air. The word "property" as hereinafter used shall mean and designate all rights and contracts of whatever kind, and all poles, wires, cables, apparatus and other appliances, appurtenances, and fixtures owned by the franchisee and located within the corporate limits of said city. 
Section II. 
    There is hereby granted to the franchisee the right, privilege and authority to construct, lay, maintain and operate, and remove a system of poles, wires, conduits, and other fixtures in, upon and across, along, under and over the streets, alleys, parkways, public grounds and other places in said city for the purpose of construction, maintaining and operating a cable television service and electronic distribution system in the City of Westlake. 
Section III. 
    This franchise hereby granted shall be effective from and after the date hereof and shall remain in full force and effect for a period of 15 years upon payment of the annual fee and tax as hereinafter provided and the said company shall have a right and option to extend the terms of this lease for an additional 15 years after the expiration of the primary term under the same terms and provisions except that the sum paid by the company for yearly franchise shall be subject to re-negotiation at the expiration of the primary term between the parties. 
Section IV. 
    The company shall defend the city against all lawful claims for injury to any person or property caused by the installation and operation of the company in the construction or operation of its property; and the company does hereby agree to indemnify and hold harmless the city from any injury to any person or property as a result of the installation and operation on the part of the company, its successors and assigns hereunder, in whole or in part, arising out of construction, repair, extension, maintenance or operation of its equipment of any kind or character used in connection with its business. 
Section V. 
    The company shall at all times make and keep full and complete plats, maps and records showing the exact location of all cable television service and electronic distribution system equipment. 
Section VI. 
    All such installations of equipment shall be of a permanent nature, durable and of a location not to interfere in the manner with the rights of the public or individual property owners, and shall not interfere with the travel and use of places by the public. The city reserves the right of reasonable regulation of the erection and construction of any work by the company, and to reasonably designate where such works and construction shall be placed. The company agrees when requested by the city, to make changes in its distribution system, in wires, poles, or apparatus to conform to the reasonable necessary requirements of small localized areas, such changes to be effected when so requested within a reasonable time, and further agrees to comply with such ordinances as the city may now have or may hereafter pass regulating the installation and maintenance of such equipment. 
Section VII. 
    The company shall have the right to operate a cable television service and electronic distribution system during the existence of this franchise, and have the right to extend its distribution system upon the streets, alleys, and public grounds of any addition or additions hereafter made to the city's territory and to use the streets, alleys and public grounds to continue to points beyond the corporate limits of said city. 
Section VIII. 
    The company shall at all times during the existence of this franchise, maintain and require its contractors and itself to maintain insurance with a duly authorized Louisiana insurance company as follows: 
(1)	Workmen's compensation insurance in accordance with the laws of the State of Louisiana. 
(2)	The franchisee shall be required to maintain insurance in such forms and in such companies as shall be approved by the city, such approval not to be unreasonably withheld, to protect the city and the franchisee from and against any and all claims, injury and damage to persons or property, both real and personal, caused by the construction, erection, operation or maintenance of any aspect of the system. The amount of such insurance shall not be less than the following: 
General Liability Insurance 
Bodily injury per person ..... $100,000 
Bodily injury per occurrence ..... $300,000 
Property damage per occurrence ..... $ 50,000 
Property damage, aggregate ..... $100,000 
(3)	Automobile liability insurance with the limits of not less than $25,000.00 to any person and $50,000.00 as to any one (1) accident and automobile property damage insurance with a limit of not less than $5,000.00 to cover all automobile equipment. 
(4)	Property damage insurance with a limit of not less than $5,000.00. 
The company is and shall be considered an independent contractor hereunder for all things. 
Section IX. 
    Failure or refusal to observe the terms and provisions of this franchise by the company, its successors and assigns, shall entitle the city to cancel and terminate this franchise and all rights hereunder. The city may exercise such right 90 days after serving notice upon the company of failure to observe the terms thereof, and upon refusal by the company during the said 90 day period to perform or act as requested by said notice, this franchise shall be subject to cancellation as hereinabove provided. 
Section X. 
(a)	All provisions of law provided and prescribed for the granting of this franchise and authority are hereby declared to have been fully complied with and the franchise shall be in full force and effect from and after its execution and approval. 
(b)	The company's rates shall be as follows: 
(1)	A schedule of the maximum rates to be charged by grantee for their services to subscribers shall be as specified in Appendix "A" attached hereto and incorporated herein for all purposes. 
(2)	All subsequent changes in said rates shall be subject to the prior approval of the council of the City of Westlake after an appropriate public hearing is held thereon affording due process to all interested parties. 
(c)	The company shall pay the city as a franchise fee, and as compensation for the rights and privileges enjoyed hereunder, three percent (3%) of its gross subscriptions receipts, less state sales taxes, federal excise taxes and copyright taxes received by the company from all its connections to said cable television service and electronic distribution system in said city. 
(d)	In addition, the company agrees to deposit with the City of Westlake and has deposited with the City of Westlake $500.00. This said amount will be credited against the first month's franchise fee due to the City of Westlake from the company. Should the franchise agreement and cable television service and electronic distribution system not be completed, the said $500.00 deposit shall be forfeited by the company. The said gross subscription shall be computed quarterly and the amounts due to city shall be paid on or before January 1, April 1, July 1, and October 1. The company shall maintain records which shall be open to inspection by the city upon reasonable notice. 
Section XI. 
    The Calcasieu Parish School System and City of Westlake will be furnished one (1) free connection and monthly service to the designated school buildings, city fire station, city police station and city hall, and each connection will be placed in a readily accessible location, and the schools, fire station, police station and city hall will be responsible for service beyond this connection. The said company shall have no liability beyond said free connection, and by requesting said free connection, the schools, fire station, police station, and city hall will hold said company free of liability. 
Section XII. 
    The cable communication system company (the grantee) must locate and maintain a permanent office to be full time secretary, said office to be located in the City of Westlake. 
Section XII. 
    Provisions of the current requirements for the system shall be and shall remain in accordance with the specifications and requirements promulgated by the Federal Communications Commission, and franchisee shall: 
(1)	Limit failures to a minimum by locating and correcting malfunctions promptly, but in no event longer than 48 hours after notice, unless such failures are caused by the acts of God or circumstances beyond the control of the franchisee. 
(2)	Demonstrate by instruments and otherwise to subscribers that a signal of adequate strength and quality is being delivered and meets all relevant specifications of the Federal Communications Commission and other applicable federal, state and local regulations. The commission may require proof of calibration of such test instruments if deemed necessary in order to arbitrate a specific complaint. 
Section XIV. 
    The franchise granted by this chapter cannot in any event be sold, transferred, leased, assigned, or disposed of as a whole or in part, or otherwise, without prior consent of the city expressed by resolution, and then only under such conditions as may be prescribed in the consenting resolution; provided, however, that no such consent shall be unreasonably withheld, and further provided that no such consent shall be required for any transfer in trust, mortgage, or other hypothecation, as a whole or in part, to secure an indebtedness. There shall be no restrictions upon the transfer of this franchise to a controlled subsidiary or to a parent corporation. 
Section XV. 
    All installation costs of the cable communication system company shall be paid by the company itself and not by the city. 
Section XVI. 
    The rights, privileges, and franchise granted hereunder shall automatically terminate if grantee has not diligently pursued and made all reasonable efforts to secure approval of its applications with the Federal Communications Commission to bring cable television to Westlake within three (3) months of the date of this agreement. Further, the rights, privileges, and franchise granted hereunder shall automatically terminate if grantee has not commenced construction and installation of the system within three (3) months of the Federal Communication Commission granting the permit and the substantial completion of the system shall be accomplished within one (1) year from the date the permit was granted. The company shall provide the city with written notice of the date the permit was granted. 
Section XVII. 
    The grantee shall, upon 72 hours' notice, adjust, raise, or lower its wires temporarily to permit the moving of houses or other bulky structures, which grantee may charge a reasonable fee for such service, which fee shall be subject to review at any time by the city. The minimum height of all wires shall be 18 feet over streets and alleys and public places or conform to all applicable codes which may now be in effect or become effective hereafter. The grantee may trim trees upon and overhanging the said streets, alleys, sidewalks and public places to the extent reasonably necessary to prevent the branches from coming into contact with the wires, or cables of grantee, under the supervision of the Mayor of the City of Westlake at the expense of the grantee:. 
Section XVIII. 
    Grantee shall not transmit or cause to be transmitted, any television program, either live programs or programs on film which are obscene or pornographic in nature or content, or any portion of a motion picture commonly known as an "X-rated" motion picture, which: 
(1)	In whole or in part depicts nudity, sexual conduct, or sado-masochistic abuse (as these terms are defined by R.S. 14:91.22); 
(2)	Predominantly appeals to the prurient, shameful or morbid interest of persons; and 
(3)	Is patently offensive to the average person, applying contemporary community standards. 
Section XIX. 
    If any provision or term of this agreement is held invalid, such invalid provision or term shall not effect the validity of the remaining provisions of this agreement. 
    IN WITNESS WHEREOF, the parties hereto have caused this contract to be passed and approved this 23rd day of March, 1978. 
/s/   
      R.H. Tyler   /s/   
      Wilbur A. Green   
/s/   
      Wilridge P. Doucet 
      Mayor, City of Westlake   Appendix A 
(1)	An installation charge of not more than twenty dollars ($20.00) will be made for the installation of the first connection at an address. An additional charge of not more than twelve dollars and fifty cents ($12.50) shall be made for each additional installation at such address. 
(2)	The maximum monthly subscription charge will be ten dollars and twenty-five cents ($10.25) plus one dollar ($1.00) for each active television outlet. 
(3)	Persons wishing to connect an FM receiver or tuner to the cable may do so by paying an installation charge of three dollars and fifty cents ($3.50). There will be no monthly charge for the extra FM service. 
(4)	Transfer from one house to another will be seven dollars and fifty cents ($7.50). 
(5)	No charge will be made for installing cable service at hospitals, hotels, motels or apartment complexes requiring more than six (6) television outlets. The monthly subscription charge for such hospitals, hotels, motels or apartment complexes shall be calculated at a rate not to exceed two dollars and twenty cents ($2.20) per month per television outlet.

CHAPTER 4. - BENCH SIGNS 

Sec. 3-4001. - Sign franchise. 
    The franchise herein granted for the purpose of authorizing, empowering and permitting the licensee to install and maintain benches with commercial advertising in the City of Westlake, shall be for a period of five (5) years, commencing on November 1, 1996, and this franchise is granted on the following terms and conditions and for the considerations hereinafter recited. 
(Ord. No. 446, 2-9-89; Ord. No. 551, 10-12-95) 
Sec. 3-4002. - Supply of benches. 
(a)	The licensee shall supply, deliver, place and maintain a minimum of twenty (20) new benches along public streets and/or other public places in the City of Westlake. The city council of the City of Westlake, through its city council or through its designated official, hereby reserves the right to designate the locations of said benches and to cause to be removed from any given location any benches which it may deem desirable. If after receiving written notice from the city, the licensee has not removed a bench location as requested, the city hereby reserves the right to remove said bench location itself and to charge to the licensee its cost for removal of said bench location. 
(b)	The licensee further agrees and covenants to supply, deliver, locate and maintain any additional needed benches requested by the city, such need to be determined by the city council of the City of Westlake. Should the licensee be unable to supply such additional needed benches, the city shall have the right to acquire such benches from another company of the city's choice. 
(Ord. No. 446, 2-9-89; Ord. No. 551, 10-12-95) 
Sec. 3-4003. - Consideration. 
(a)	As consideration for the privilege granted to place and maintain benches along public streets and/or other public places in the City of Westlake, the licensee agrees to pay to the city quarterly, on or before the first day of the months of April, July, October and January of each year during the term of this franchise, beginning with the first day of November 1995, an amount equal to two hundred twenty-five dollars ($225.00), or seven and one-half (71/2) percent of quarterly gross collections, whichever is greater. The delivery and placement of any bench at any location along city streets and/or other public places shall constitute a warranty by the licensee that such bench meets the minimum detailed specifications of file with the City of Westlake, and, further, that such bench is fit for public use for the purpose for which it was installed and is free from any defect in design or condition that might be hazardous to the public. 
(b)	The payments be made hereunder to the city are for the license and privilege of using the streets, avenues, parkways and/or other public places within the City of Westlake for the location of benches. The privilege of using such streets, avenues, parkways and/or public places for the location of benches shall not be construed as granting any right, title or interest to said locations; and all such location sites shall be and remain the property of the City of Westlake. 
(Ord. No. 446, 2-9-89; Ord. No. 551, 10-12-95) 
Sec. 3-4004. - Safety, repairs and replacement of benches. 
    The licensee expressly covenants and agrees to maintain at its sole expense all benches in a safe, comfortable, clean, attractive and well repaired condition acceptable to the city. The licensee agrees to replace or repair, at its sole expense, and to the satisfaction of the city, any required repairs under this franchise shall be performed in a workmanlike manner and with the standard of care necessary to maintain the benches in a condition which is safe for the public use. Such maintenance shall include, but not be limited to, the following: cutting grass and undergrowth within a fifteen-foot radius and under and around the benches as necessary, and keeping the benches and the same fifteen-foot radius free of debris or litter, but confined for both purposes to the public right-of-way. Seats, if wooden, shall be repaired or replaced as necessary to keep them free of splinters and protruding bolts. Ends and legs, if concrete, shall be repaired or replaced as necessary to keep them free of breaks, cracks and crumbling. Advertising shall be repainted, rescreened, reprinted or replaced as necessary. 
(Ord. No. 446, 2-9-89; Ord. No. 551, 10-12-95) 
Sec. 3-4005. - Notification by city for repair or replacement of benches. 
    The licensee's duty to clean, repair or replace such benches shall exist regardless of whether the benches where negligently or intentionally damaged or broken or otherwise subject to malicious mischief or acts of vandalism. The licensee's obligation to clean, repair and maintain said benches is absolute, and is not dependent upon any notification by the city. However, the licensee agrees to clean, repair and replace any damaged, dirty or broken benches immediately upon receipt of written notice from the city, and in no event later than seventy-two (72) hours after receipt of such notice. At any time a bench shall be removed from its location in the public street and/or other public place for maintenance, cleaning or repairs, a similar bench in good condition shall be substituted and left in its place at the licensee's expense. Failure by the licensee to comply with the provisions of this paragraph, or to timely clean, repair or replace said benches upon the city's request and to the city's satisfaction, shall constitute a breach of this agreement, and the city shall have the right to cancel this franchise and agreement without further notice to licensee. 
(Ord. No. 446, 2-9-89; Ord. No. 551, 10-12-95) 
Sec. 3-4006. - Location of benches. 
(a)	All benches shall be so located so as to be convenient for public use, and shall be parallel to the curb so as to minimize visual obstruction. No bench shall be located so as to in any way constitute a hazard to traffic or to public safety. 
(b)	All bench locations must be approved in writing in advance by the city council, or its duly authorized representative, and no bench shall be located or installed along any public street and/or other public place without such prior written authorization. The licensee shall, within seventy-two (72) hours of written notice by the city, remove any bench located or installed without such prior written authorization. 
(c)	On or before the last day of December each year during the term of this agreement, the licensee shall furnish to the City of Westlake, Louisiana a list showing the current location and the date of installation of each bench located along city streets and/or other public places. The licensee shall further make available its vouchers, books, contracts and records verifying the amount to be paid to the city for the privilege granted under this franchise. 
(d)	At all times during this franchise, the city may deem it necessary that certain benches be removed or relocated. The licensee shall so remove or relocate said benches at the licensee's expense within seventy-two (72) hours after written request is made by the city council or its duly authorized representative. 
(Ord. No. 446, 2-9-89; Ord. No. 551, 10-12-95) 
Sec. 3-4007. - Use of benches for commercial advertising. 
    The city grants to the licensee the privilege of installing commercial advertising on each bench placed and maintained along the city streets and/or other public places under this agreement. No obscene or X-rated cinema advertisement nor advertisements for alcohol beverage products shall be permitted on said benches. Furthermore, the city council shall be the sole judge of the suitability of all advertising and the product advertised on any bench, and if the city council disapproves of any such advertising material, same shall not be used and, if necessary, immediately removed by the licensee at licensee's sole expense. The licensee agrees to be solely responsible for the advertising material and the content of all such advertising exhibited under this franchise, and further agrees to hold the city free and harmless from all blame and for any and all claims and causes of action by any other parties for and on account of the content of the advertising signs exhibited on the benches under the terms of this agreement; and the licensee further agrees to indemnify the city, should it be required by court or any other legal proceedings, to pay any judgment, court costs, fines or other legal expenses for and on account of any advertising signs exhibited on benches. 
(Ord. No. 446, 2-9-89; Ord. No. 551, 10-12-95) 
Sec. 3-4008. - Violations of conditions of franchise. 
    The privilege granted to the licensee by this franchise to place and maintain benches along public streets and/or other public places within the City of Westlake is hereby limited by and shall be exercised solely in accordance with the terms, conditions and provisions of this agreement, and any violation of any such terms, conditions or covenant by the licensee shall constitute grounds for cancellation by the city, but the failure of the city to cancel same for any violation shall not be deemed to waive the right of cancellation of any future violation. The city may cancel this license agreement seventy-two (72) hours after written notice of violation is given to the licensee and such violation is not corrected. In the event of cancellation or termination of this franchise, for any reason whatsoever, the licensee shall immediately remove all benches from city streets and/or other public places and shall restore the premises on which same were located to a neat, clean condition acceptable to the city, at the licensee's sole expense; and should the licensee fail to remove said benches, the city shall have the right to remove same, forcibly, if necessary, and without any liability on the part of the city, an the licensee shall reimburse the city for the cost of such removal. Cancellation of this agreement by the city shall not act as a waiver of any payments due the city by the licensee under the terms of this agreement. 
(Ord. No. 446, 2-9-89; Ord. No. 551, 10-12-95) 
Sec. 3-4009. - Permits, regulation and taxes. 
    The licensee covenants and agrees to comply with all laws, federal, state and local, including the ordinances of the City of Westlake, Louisiana, and all rules, regulations and requirements of any municipal department of the City of Westlake, Louisiana. It is further agreed that the licensee will obtain and pay for all necessary permits, licenses and taxes incurred or required in connection with licensee's exercise of the privileges granted herein, and that the licensee will not do or suffer to be done anything on public grounds or rights-of-way in violation of such laws, ordinances, rules and requirements during the term of this agreement; and that if the city calls the attention of the licensee to any such violation on the part of the licensee, or any person employed by the licensee, then the licensee shall immediately desist from and correct such violation or terminate the exercise of the privileges granted herein. 
(Ord. No. 446, 2-9-89; Ord. No. 551, 10-12-95) 
Sec. 3-4010. - Licensee as independent contractor. 
    The licensee shall operate hereunder as an independent contractor and not as an officer, agent, servant or employee of the city. The licensee shall have exclusive control of and the exclusive right to control the details of the operations hereunder, and all persons performing same; and the licensee shall be solely responsible for the acts and omissions of the officers, agents, servants and employees. [Neither] the licensee, its officer, agents, servants and employees, and nothing herein shall be construed as creating a partnership or joint enterprise between the city and licensee. 
(Ord. No. 446, 2-9-89; Ord. No. 551, 10-12-95) 
Sec. 3-4011. - Liability. 
    The city shall in no way nor under any circumstances be responsible for any property belonging to the license, its officer, agents, employees, contractors or subcontractors which may be lost, stolen, destroyed or in any way damaged; and licensee hereby indemnifies and holds harmless the city, its officers, agents and employees, free and against any and all such claims. 
(Ord. No. 446, 2-9-89; Ord. No. 551, 10-12-95) 
Sec. 3-4012. - Indemnification and hold harmless agreement. 
    The licensee covenants and agrees to indemnify, hold harmless and defend, at its own expense, the city, its officers, agents, servants and employees, from and against any and all claims or suits for property loss or damage and/or personal injury, including death, to any and all persons, of whatsoever kind or character, whether real or asserted, arising out of or in connection with licensee's exercise of privileges granted herein, whether or not caused, in whole or in part, by negligence of officers, agents, servants, employees, contractors, subcontractors, licensees or invitees of the city; and the licensee hereby assumes all liability and responsibility of the city, its officers, agents, servants and employees, for any and all claims or suits for property loss or damage and/or personal injury, including death, to any and all persons, of whatsoever kind or character, whether real or asserted, arising out of or in connection with licensee's exercise of privilege granted herein, whether or not caused, in whose or in part, by alleged negligence of officers, agents, servants, employees, contractors, subcontractors, licensees or invitees of the city. The licensee likewise covenants and agrees to and does hereby indemnify and hold harmless the city from and against any and all injury, damage or destruction of property of the city arising out of or in connection with all acts or omissions of the licensee, its officers, agents, employees, contractors, subcontractors, licensees, or invitees, or caused in whole or in part by alleged negligence of officers, agents, servants, employees, contractors, subcontractors, or licensees of the city. 
(Ord. No. 446, 2-9-89; Ord. No. 551, 10-12-95) 
Sec. 3-4013. - Insurance. 
    The licensee shall furnish a certificate of insurance as proof that it has secured and paid for a policy of public and product liability insurance covering all risks incident to or in connection with the exercise of the privileges granted herein. The amounts of such insurance shall be as follows: 
(1)	Property damage, per accident ..... $50,000 
(2)	Personal injury or death, per person ..... 100,000 
(3)	Personal injury or death, per accident ..... 300,000 
with the understanding and agreement by the licensee that such insurance amounts shall be revised upward at the city's option and that the licensee shall so revise such amounts within thirty (30) days following notice to the licensee of such requirements. Further, said certificate shall provide that the City of Westlake will be given thirty (30) days' written notice of cancellation or modification of said policy. 
(Ord. No. 446, 2-9-89; Ord. No. 551, 10-12-95) 
Sec. 3-4014. - Bond. 
    The licensee agrees to make, execute and deliver, on or before the first day of January of each year, commencing with January 1, 1996, a good and sufficient surety bond payable to the City of Westlake, Louisiana, conditioned upon the faithful performance of the terms and conditions hereunder. The penal sum of such bond shall be an amount equal to the annual amount payable to the city each year for the privileges granted hereunder, and said penal sum shall be adjusted annually to reflect said amount. In no event shall the penal sum be less than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). The surety on said bond shall be a surety company duly authorized to do business in the State of Louisiana and acceptable to the City of Westlake. Such surety bond shall contain a stipulation that the surety agrees to give the city thirty (30) days' written notice prior to any modification or cancellation of said bond by the surety. The city reserves the right to waive the requirement of said surety bond. 
(Ord. No. 446, 2-9-89; Ord. No. 551, 10-12-95) 
Sec. 3-4015. - Assignment. 
    The licensee shall not assign all or any part of its rights, privileges or duties under this franchise without the prior written approval of the city, and any attempted assignment of same without such prior written approval shall be void, and shall constitute a breach of this franchise. 
(Ord. No. 446, 2-9-89; Ord. No. 551, 10-12-95) 
Sec. 3-4016. - Contractual lien. 
    The licensee hereby grants a contractual lien to the city upon all personal property belonging to licensee which licensee places in or upon the above-described city property as a possessory pledge to secure the timely performance by the licensee of all of its obligations hereunder, and, in the event of default by the licensee, the city is and shall be empowered and authorized to seize and hold all the personal property belonging to the licensee on the above-described premises to secure such performance, to sell same at public or private sale and to apply the proceeds thereof first to pay the expenses of the same, and to pay all amounts due to the city hereunder, holding the balance remaining, if any, subject to the licensee's order. A copy of this franchise shall be the only warrant required. 
(Ord. No. 446, 2-9-89; Ord. No. 551, 10-12-95) 
Sec. 3-4017. - Franchise renewal. 
    This franchise shall be automatically renewed and extended for an additional period of five (5) years, commencing on November 1, 1996 and terminating on October 31, 2001, which said renewal shall be upon the same terms and conditions and for the same considerations, unless the licensee or the city gives sixty (60) days' written notice prior to the end of this franchise that either does not desire to extend said franchise. 
(Ord. No. 446, 2-9-89; Ord. No. 551, 10-12-95) 
Sec. 3-4018. - Jurisdiction. 
    Should any action, whether real or asserted, at law or in equity, arise out of the exercise of the privilege granted herein, venue for such action shall lie in Calcasieu Parish, Louisiana. 
(Ord. No. 446, 2-9-89; Ord. No. 551, 10-12-95) 
CHAPTER 5. - SOLID WASTE COLLECTION 

Sec. 3-5001. - Name. 
    There is hereby created the Westlake Waste Collection Services. 
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
Sec. 3-5002. - Definitions. 
    Agricultural solid waste: All organic waste products that are generated from farm production operations of field crops, orchards and animals. 
    Bags: Plastic sacks designed to store refuse with sufficient wall strength to maintain physical integrity when lifted by the top. Total weight of a bag and its contents shall not exceed fifty (50) pounds. 
    Bin (dumpster): Metal receptacle designed to be lifted and emptied mechanically for use only at commercial and industrial units. 
    Bulky waste: Furniture and other waste other than agricultural solid waste, construction debris, dead animals, offal waste, stable matter or vegetable waste with weights or volumes greater than those allowed for bins or containers, as the case may be. 
    Bundle: Tree, shrub and brush trimmings or newspapers and magazines securely tied together forming an easily handled package not exceeding six (6) feet in length or fifty (50) pounds in weight. 
    Buyer: A person or persons who the contractor has an agreement to purchase recycled material collected during the duration of the contract and any extensions. 
    Collection: The act of removing solid waste from the storage point at the source of generation. 
    Collection hours: The time period during which collection of recyclable material, solid waste or yard waste is authorized in the city. Collection shall begin no earlier than 5:00 a.m. and shall end no later than 8:00 p.m. unless an extension of hours is approved in writing by the office of the mayor. 
    Collection service: A public or private operation engaged in the collection and transportation of solid waste materials. 
    Collection vehicle: Any vehicle permitted by the city for collection of solid waste, recyclable materials and yard waste within the city. 
    Commercial solid waste: All bulky waste, construction debris, garbage and rubbish generated by a producer at a commercial unit. 
    Commercial unit: All premises, locations or entities, public or private, requiring refuse collections within the incorporated areas of the city, not a residential unit which can be picked up once per week in not more than two (2) solid waste containers. 
    Construction debris: Waste building materials resulting from construction, remodeling, repair or demolition operations. 
    Container solid waste: A wheeled receptacle with a capacity of ninety-six (96) gallons constructed of plastic, metal or fiberglass, having handles of adequate strength for lifting and having a tight-fitting lid capable of preventing entrance into the container by vectors. The mouth of the container shall have a diameter greater than or equal to that of the base. The weight of a container and its contents shall not exceed fifty (50) pounds. 
    Container or container set recycling: Containers made of rigid plastic construction to assist residents to participate in the curbside recycling program. Each container shall have a minimum capacity of 1.85 cubic feet and approximate inside dimensions of twenty-two (22) inches by sixteen (16) inches by thirteen (13) inches (18 gallons). 
    Dead animals: Animals or portions thereof having expired from any cause, except those slaughtered or killed for human use, generally including dogs, cats or other animals, excluding farm stock. 
    Disposal: The orderly process of discarding useless or unwanted material in a beneficial or nonbeneficial manner. 
    Disposal facilities: The physical components of the disposal system, such as transfer conveyances, transfer stations, processing plants and landfills. 
    Disposal site: A disposal facility permitted or approved by the DEQ, State of Louisiana. 
    Drop-off center: An area where residents are allowed to deliver recyclable materials. 
    Contract: The contract shall consist of this ordinance, and the agreement between the city and contractor binding the contractor to the ordinance, performance bond and any addendum or changes to these documents which have been agreed to by the city and the contractor. 
    Garbage: All normal and usual household and institutional waste products that are placed in approved containers for collection purposes and are usually a mixture of putrescible, nonputrescible, combustible and incombustible materials, such as organic wastes from food preparation and consumption, wrapping and packing materials, metal, glass, and plastic containers and other items. This definition also applies to similar waste products from commercial establishments such as restaurants, cafeterias, schools and hospitals. 
    Generation: The act of producing solid waste. 
    Hazardous waste: Any chemical, compound, mixture, substance or article which is designated by the United States Environmental Protection Agency or appropriate state or local agency to be "hazardous" as that term is defined by or pursuant to Federal, state, or local laws and ordinances. 
    Industrial solid waste: All solid waste produced in the course of, resulting from, or contaminated by an industrial, manufacturing, or mining process, and which is not subject to regulation under the Louisiana Hazardous Waste Regulations, the Office of Conservation's Statewide Order No. 29-B, or other agencies. 
    Institutional solid waste: Solid waste originating from educational, health care and research facilities such as schools, hospitals, nursing homes, laboratories and other similar establishments. 
    Missed collection: A missed collection is defined as the failure of the contractor to provide (solid waste, recycling or yard waste) collection service to a residential property within the route during collection hours on the day scheduled for route collection. 
    Multifamily: The term multifamily shall refer to all residential dwelling units of more than four (4) units, considered to be condominiums, apartment houses or grouped housing. 
    Nonputrescible solid waste: Solid waste materials that do not contain organic matter that is subject to rapid decomposition by fungi and bacteria. 
    Noncompletion of route: Noncompletion of route is defined as the nonprovision of collection service to a block or blocks within the collection route during the hours of collection upon the day scheduled for route collection. 
    Offal waste: Waste animal (land or marine) matter from establishments such as butcher shops, slaughter houses, food processing and packing plants, rendering plants and fertilizer plants. 
    Owner: City of Westlake sometimes hereinafter referred to as the "contractor". 
    Pickup station: A facility where solid waste is concentrated for shipment by truck to a landfill designated by the city. 
    Processing and marketing: Contractor preparation, sale and delivery of recyclable materials to buyers. 
    Processing/storage yard: Area and/or structure where collected recyclable materials are sorted, prepared and temporarily stored prior to delivery to buyers. 
    Producer: An occupant of a commercial and industrial unit or a residential unit who generates solid waste. 
    Putrescible solid waste: Solid waste materials containing organic matter that is subject to rapid decomposition by fungi and bacteria, such as food waste and dead animals. 
    Recyclable material: Means glass, aluminum cans, newsprint, plastics, tin cans, and other materials mutually agreed to by the contractor and the city. These materials are rendered recyclable by the action of residents who prepare and place materials at the curbside for collection. 
    Recyclable materials categories: The categories of recyclable material as separated at the curb are as follows: 
(a)	Clear, green and brown container glass: Glass may be beverage containers or household glass such as mayonnaise jars, ketchup bottles, etc. 
(b)	Aluminum cans. 
(c)	Newsprint: Newspaper of any kind without glossy magazine type paper. 
(d)	Plastics: Usually beverage containers, laundry detergent bottles or milk/water jugs. 
(e)	Tin can: Steel food containers. 
(f)	Yard waste: All grass, shrubs and tree trimmings generated from yard maintenance. Not to include tree removal. 
    Collection routes: The city is subdivided into areas known as collection routes. Each route has a specified day of the week upon which the contractor is allowed material pickup within the boundaries of the route. 
    Resident: Occupant of a residential property. 
    Residential solid waste: All garbage and rubbish generated by a producer at a residential unit. 
    Residential unit: A dwelling within the city occupied by a person or group of persons. A residential unit shall be deemed occupied when either water or domestic light and power services are being supplied thereto. A condominium dwelling whether of single- or multi-level construction, or separate single-family dwelling units, including mobile homes, shall be treated as a residential unit, except that each single-family dwelling within any such residential unit shall be billed separately as a residential unit for the purposes of this contract. Mobile home parks and apartment complexes which contain units located on public roads shall be serviced by the contractor on a per apartment complex or mobile home park basis and shall be covered by the terms of the contract. 
    Rubbish: A mixture of small, putrescible household, institutional and commercial waste products containing a high percentage of combustible materials such as paper, cardboard, plastics, foliage, grass and leaves, and including noncombustibles such as glass, crockery, cans and light scrap metals. 
    Rendering: A process of recovering fatty substances from animal parts by heat treatment, extraction and distillation. 
    Separation: The systematic division of solid waste into designated components. 
    Service unit: A service unit shall be a residential unit (single- and multifamily) or a commercial unit. To be defined as a service unit, a commercial unit shall request solid waste collection and recyclable material collection from the contractor at the rate quoted in this ordinance. 
    Solid waste: Useless, unwanted or discarded materials with insufficient liquid content to be free-flowing, that results from domestic, industrial, commercial, agricultural, government and community operations, which require proper storage, collection, transportation and disposal to prevent environmental pollution inimical to public health, safety and welfare. Solid waste does not include sewage, earth or material used to fill land in accordance with construction codes, mining residues, slag, dissolved or suspended solids in industrial wastewater effluents which are not for acceptable disposal in a sanitary sewage treatment system. 
    Solid waste management: The purposeful, systematic, control of the storage, collection, transport, separation, processing, recovery and disposal of solid waste. 
    Solid waste management system: The entire process of storage, collection, transportation, processing and disposal of solid waste by any person engaging in such process as a business or by any municipality, authority, parish or any combination thereof. 
    Solid waste storage: The handling and holding of solid waste, in an approved manner, near the point of generation pending collection. 
    Solid waste transportation: The conveying of solid waste from one place to another by means of a vehicle, rail car, watervessel, conveyor or other means. 
    Stable matter: The body waste of animal and fowl, and cleanings, and waste foodstuffs from all barns, stables, corrals, or pens used for stabling, caging or penning of animals or fowl. 
    Subcontractor: Person or persons who are performing any part of the scope of work other than the contractor. 
    Transfer station: A site at which solid waste is assembled and temporarily deposited after collection and from which it is transported to a different location for processing and/or disposal. 
    Vector (of disease): An animal or insect which transmits infectious diseases from one person or animal to another by biting the skin or mucous membrane or by depositing infective material on the skin or food or on another object. 
    Vegetable waste: Putrescible solid waste resulting from the processing of plants for food by commercial establishments such as canneries. This definition does not include waste products resulting from the preparation and consumption of food in places such as cafeterias and restaurants. 
    Waste tires: A whole tire that is no longer suitable for its original purpose because of wear, damage, [or] defect. 
    White goods: White goods means inoperative and discarded refrigerators, ranges, water heaters, freezers and other similar domestic and residential large appliances. 
    Yard waste: Grass, leaves, flowers, stalks, stems, tree trimmings, branches, tree trunks. Grass, leaves, flowers, stalks, stems and tree trimmings shall be in a container, bag or box the weight of which shall not exceed fifty (50) pounds. Branches up to six (6) inches in diameter shall be cut in length not exceeding six (6) feet and shall be stacked at the curb. Tree trunks shall not exceed fifty (50) pounds for any one piece or four (4) feet in length. 
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
SOLID WASTE COLLECTION 
Sec. 3-5003. - Scope of solid waste collection and disposal. 
    The work done under this contract shall consist of the items contained in this ordinance including all the supervision, materials, equipment, labor and all items necessary to complete said work in accordance with this ordinance. The services covered by this contract are for the collection, transportation and disposal of solid waste/recyclable materials from residential units as defined and collection of yard waste from residential units as defined. 
    All solid waste collected for the city shall be deposited at a facility permitted on approval by the State of Louisiana, Department of Environmental Quality designated by the owner. The contractor shall negotiate directly with the owner/operator of the disposal facilities for permission to use the facility and the contractor shall bear all disposal costs. As defined herein, agricultural solid waste, hazardous waste, offal waste, stable matter and vegetable waste shall not be transported by the contractor. Garbage and rubbish may be combined in the same collection truck. 
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
Sec. 3-5004. - Type of collection. 
    The contractor shall provide curbside collection of an unlimited amount of residential solid waste to each residential unit and roadside collection of commercial solid waste to each commercial unit as defined herein, which qualifies as a service unit one (1) time per week. Containers, bags and bundles shall be placed at curbside by 5:00 a.m. on the designated collection day. The contractor shall provide for the collection of bulky waste from residential units which shall be included in the per unit charge. In addition, collection of construction debris will be provided not to exceed five (5) bundles during one pickup period and shall be included in the per unit charge. Each container, bag and bundle shall be placed at curbside for collection. Curbside refers to that portion of the roadway adjacent to paved or traveled city streets (including alleys), where mail service is provided. Containers, bags and bundles shall be placed as close to the roadway as practicable without interfering with or endangering the movement of vehicles or pedestrians. When construction work is being performed in the right-of-way, containers, bags and bundles shall be placed as close as practicable to an access point for the collection vehicle. 
    Contractor will not be required to pick up waste if a road becomes impassable and prohibits access to a residential unit from any direction on a roadway. The contractor, however, will be required to notify the city of this occurrence and will be required to pick up waste at the nearest public roadway or at a point of closure. 
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
Sec. 3-5005. - Special service to residential and commercial service units provided by contractor. 
    Special service shall include pickup every other week of the following materials and shall be provided by the contractor at no additional charge. 
1.	White goods to include washers, refrigerators, water heaters, etc., to be transported to a bin provided by the contractor at the designated disposal site for proper disposal. 
2.	Waste tires. Once per year the city may designate a city-wide cleanup of parks, riverfront, public buildings, cemeteries and school grounds. The contractor agrees to provide the necessary equipment including two (2) bins to facilitate the city's annual cleanup. These bins shall be furnished and picked up at no cost to the city. 
    In cases of natural disaster, as defined below, the contractor and the city shall negotiate a reasonable rate for the use of contractor's vehicles and crews to assist in cleanup operations if the impact of such disaster creates an unusual amount of debris and waste beyond the normal scope of services under the contract. "Natural disaster" means any hurricane, tornado, storm, flood, high water, tidal wave, drought or fire or other act of God or catastrophe in any part of the city which causes substantial damage to property or unusual amounts of debris and waste. 
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
Sec. 3-5006. - Special services to residential and commercial service units provided by the city. 
    The following special services shall be provided by the city (payment shall be arranged between the customer and the city): 
    Tree stumps: Any tree waste that exceeds the size and weight requirements as specified in the definition of yard waste shall be removed by the city. 
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
Sec. 3-5007. - Operation. 
(a)	Hours of operation. Collection of solid waste shall not start before 5:00 a.m. or continue after 8:00 p.m. on the same day. Exceptions to hours shall be effected only upon the mutual agreement of the city and the contractor. 
(b)	Routes of collection. Collection routes shall be established by the contractor and approved by the mayor. Such approval shall not be unreasonably withheld. 
(c)	Holidays. The contractor may observe the following holidays: New Years Day, Good Friday, Memorial Day, Fourth of July, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Day, or any others designated by the city. On these holidays, pickup shall be on the next scheduled collection day or shall be considered a missed pickup. 
(d)	Complaints. All complaints shall be made directly to the contractor and shall be given prompt and courteous attention. The contractor will provide monthly reports regarding complaints to include at a minimum: 
(1)	Type of complaint; 
(2)	How it was resolved; and 
(3)	Frequency of occurrence at location. 
(e)	Collection equipment. The contractor will provide an adequate number of vehicles of adequate capacity for regular collection services. At least one (1) spare vehicle shall be available for service within two (2) hours' notice. All vehicles and other equipment shall be kept in good repair, appearance, and in a sanitary condition at all times. Each vehicle shall have clearly visible on each side, the identity and telephone number of the contractor. All vehicles shall be radio dispatched. 
(f)	Office. The contractor shall maintain an office through which it can be contacted. It shall be equipped with sufficient telephones and shall have a responsible person in charge from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. on regular work days. 
(g)	Hauling. All solid waste hauled by the contractor shall be so contained, tied or enclosed that leaking, spilling or blowing are prevented. 
(h)	Disposal. All solid waste collected for disposal by the contractor shall be hauled to a permitted or approved disposal site. 
(i)	Notification. The contractor shall notify all producers at residential units about complaint procedures, rates and regulations. 
(j)	Point of contact. All dealings, contacts, etc., between the contractor and the city shall be directed by the contractor to the director of public works and by the city to the division president and general manager. 
(k)	Litter or spillage. The contractor shall not litter premises in the process of making collections, but he shall not be required to collect any waste material that has not been placed in containers or in the manner described so that leaking, spillage or blowing are prevented. In the event of spillage by the contractor, the contractor shall be required to clean up the litter. 
(l)	Refusal to serve. The contractor must provide solid waste collection service to all residential units that qualify as a service unit as defined, except the contractor may refuse to serve a location as specified under one (1) or more of the following conditions: 
(1)	Contractor may refuse to collect refuse which is not placed in an approved container or bag. 
(2)	Contractor may refuse to collect refuse which is not placed in a proper location as specified herein. 
(3)	Contractor will not be required to collect noncollectable waste except as directed as a special pickup by the appropriate authority of the city or upon request directly from a service unit. The customer and the city shall be notified by the contractor of any refusal of service. 
(m)	[ Container. ] The contractor shall provide, at no charge, one (1) solid waste container for each residential and qualified commercial solid waste producer within the corporate limits of the city. Each residential and qualified commercial solid waste producer may purchase additional solid waste containers from the contractor for the price of sixty-one dollars ($61.00) per container. 
    There shall be no charge for replacement of one (1) container per service unit due to loss or theft upon receipt of proof that a report was filed with the appropriate law enforcement agency. Any cost for additional replacement of container (beyond the first container) shall be borne by the occupant of said service unit. 
    The contractor shall be responsible for absorbing no more than five (5) percent of the total number of containers due to loss or theft over the term of this contract; thereafter, the city shall be obligated to pay for container replacement in an amount not to exceed sixty-one dollars ($61.00) per container as per average current market value. 
    Any additional increase in market value cost per container during the term of the contract shall be borne by the contractor. The contractor will provide eleven (11) solid waste containers to the city for the exclusive use of the municipality. These containers will be clearly marked as containers solely for municipal use. The city shall designate which public building and location these containers may be assigned. Pickup of these containers shall be at no cost to the city. 
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
COLLECTION OF RECYCLED MATERIALS 
Sec. 3-5008. - Residential collection of source separated material. 
(a)	The city anticipates enacting a recycling program within the corporate limits of the municipality. The enactment of such a recycling program shall be with the cooperation and assistance of the contractor and the city council. In the event the city does enact a recycling program, then the contractor agrees to perform all the provisions of paragraph (b) hereinafter provided. Such a recycling program shall be limited to residential units only. 
(b)	The contractor will: 
Collect and remove all separated recyclable materials one time per week (regardless of weather conditions from all service units in the designated area in the city. Transport the collected recyclable materials to a central processing/storage yard or directly to material buyers at the discretion of the contractor. The contractor retains sole responsibility for marketing these materials to prospective buyers. Purchase, store and distribute by delivering to residential properties containers and acknowledging receipt, not later than one (1) week prior to collection, containers to encourage participation. The city will retain ownership of all collection container (sets). In the event of damage, loss of containers, or additional needs due to annexation, the contractor shall be responsible for additional containers (sets) during the duration of the contract, not to exceed five (5) percent of the total house count. 
Be responsible for purchase, operation and maintenance of all collection and processing equipment. The contractor will maintain and be responsible for equipment replacement when necessary. All vehicles used in performance of this contract shall be new and clearly identified with the contractor's name, phone number, truck number, and any company logo on each side and permitted according to city ordinances. In addition, each vehicle shall have separate bins for the storage of recyclables. Vehicles used in association with this contract shall be painted frequently enough to maintain a positive public image and so as not to cause complaints from residents. The city public works department shall have the right to require a vehicle to be painted if it deems it necessary. All vehicles shall be frequently washed to avoid odors and to maintain a positive public image. 
Provide monthly, quarterly and annual reports to the city. These reports shall include summaries of each tonnages/volumes to include gross weight of each load, tire weight for each vehicle, and calculated net weight/volume by material collected and sold; prices received for materials; number of collections by route and date of collection; complaints received; and, in the case of the annual report, a summary of the years marketing activity with an assessment of its results. Including any new strategy to achieve a twenty-five (25) percent diversion goal and a projection for the following years activities. The contractor will make available weight receipts for all materials collected and sold. 
Be responsible to clean up any materials spilled or blown during the course of pickup and/or hauling operations. All collection vehicles shall be equipped with at least one (1) broom and one (1) shovel. 
Establish a procedure for receiving and responding, within twenty-four (24) hours, to residential complaints of missed pickups. The contractor shall provide staffing to receive complaints from residents and/or city staff and report number and nature of complaints in monthly reports. 
If the contractor determines that the recyclables set out by residents are unacceptable due to insufficient preparation of materials, he/she shall follow the rejection procedure. On the first instance of improperly prepared materials the contractor shall collect the items, and leave a sticker approved by the contractor explaining the proper method of preparation of items, record the address on the form approved by the city and report it to the mayor of the City of Westlake. Subsequent instances of improperly prepared items by a resident shall be handled by rejecting the material, not collecting it and notifying the mayor of the City of Westlake of the address (notification shall take place on the day the items are rejected or the items shall be considered a missed collection). Contractor shall provide follow-up contact with the resident to ensure proper set-out and material preparation in the future. Provide general program public information, hand-out materials and public presentation materials to be used with civic organizations and church groups, schools, senior citizens groups, environmental/conservation groups, and other interest groups. 
If requested by the city, the contractor shall provide the following services to assist in the establishment of a recycling program: 
(1)	Commission a public opinion survey of city residents to determine levels of participation, barriers to participation, demographic information, media habits, purchasing habits by material on an annual basis. The survey sample shall be not less than two hundred (200) head of households. 
(2)	Provide information packets (door hangers) specifically for the households included in the curbside areas. 
(3)	Organize "block captains" in selected neighborhoods included in the curbside areas. 
(4)	Provide media materials and events to facilitate media coverage. 
(5)	Provide advertising materials for newspaper, radio, and television coverage (free public service spots as well as paid ads). The budget for media coverage will provide at least one (1) week per quarter with an exposure to at least eighty-five (85) percent of the market. 
(6)	Provide a telephone "hotline" for program information and to receive any complaints from residents. 
(7)	Major efforts will be staged initially, based on a program promotion plan to be developed for and approved by the city. Continuing public awareness and promotional efforts will be needed and conducted, however, to promote and sustain participation and to build a positive posture for the program. 
(8)	Through the schools, poster contests and related activities will be used to generate "at home" interest. In addition to systematic identification and education of local opinion leaders to enlist their support. 
(9)	The selected contractor's staff is expected to work closely and meet quarterly, at a minimum, with the city staff regarding the city's public awareness/education campaign. Participation rates and diversion goals should be analyzed to determine any need to change the public awareness/educational campaign to ensure the twenty-five (25) percent diversion goal reached. 
(c)	The city will: 
Establish the conceptual plan as set forth in these specifications for the city curbside collection program. The city and contractor have to agree to add or delete an item or items to the list of categories of recyclable materials. Either may propose the addition or deletion of materials at any time during the contract period and any extensions. 
Pay the contractor for the provision recycling services provided by the contract which change shall be mutually agreed upon. 
The city will enact an anti-scavenging ordinance to protect the contractor from illegal collection of material placed at curb for collection. 
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
Sec. 3-5009. - Revenue from the sale of material. 
    The contractor will keep all revenue from the sale of materials. 
COLLECTION OF YARD WASTE
AND COMPOSTING 
Sec. 3-5010. - Yard waste. 
    The contractor shall collect all yard waste as defined from all single-family homes, multifamily units of four (4) or less units under common ownership. The contractor shall collect all yard waste in accordance with the applicable provisions of section 3-5008. In the event that city enacts a yard waste and composting program, city will pay contractor for the provision of yard waste collection and composting services as described herein, which change shall be mutually agreed upon. 
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
Sec. 3-5011. - Frequency of collection. 
    The contractor shall collect yard waste from residences within the service area at least one (1) time per week. 
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
Sec. 3-5012. - Hours of collection. 
    Collection shall begin no earlier than 5:00 a.m. and shall cease no later than 8:00 p.m.; provided that in the event of emergency or unforeseen circumstances; collection may be permitted at a time not allowed by this paragraph following approval by the city department of public works. 
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
Sec. 3-5013. - Point of pickup of yard waste. 
    Collection of yard waste shall be at curbside/roadside or other such locations as will provide ready accessibility to the contractor's collection crew and vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
Sec. 3-5014. - Preparation of yard waste for collection. 
    The contractor shall pick up all yard waste generated from residential units which has been properly prepared and stored for collection as follows: 
Yard waste should be placed in garbage cans or other reusable containers and be placed at curbside/roadside or at such other single collection point as may be agreed upon by the contractor and the customer. Disposal of yard waste in plastic bags will be discouraged through promotion and educational efforts sponsored by the contractor but yard waste disposed of in plastic bags or in piles shall still be collected by the contractor. Prior to placement in vehicle, yard waste shall be free of all plastic bags, boxes, glass and other contaminants, only if taken to a compost facility. 
Noncontainerized yard waste shall be collected providing that it does not exceed six (6) feet in length or fifty (50) pounds in weight for any piece or segment. Yard waste exceeding these dimensions and weight shall be collected by a special service, which shall be arranged between the customer and the city. 
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
Sec. 3-5015. - Method of collection of yard waste. 
    The contractor shall make collections with a minimum of noise and disturbance to the householder. Any yard waste spilled by the contractor shall be picked up immediately by the contractor. Garbage receptacles shall be handled carefully by the contractor, they shall not be bent or otherwise abused, and shall be thoroughly emptied and then left at the proper point of collection. Metal or plastic cans shall be inverted with covers placed on the ground next to the container. Any type receptacle found in a rack, cart or enclosure of any kind shall be returned upright, to such rack, cart or enclosure and lids shall be returned to said receptacles. 
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
Sec. 3-5016. - Routes. 
    The contractor shall establish the collection route and submit such route to the city for approval. The route shall identify approximate households to be picked up and duration to complete the route. Such approval shall not be unreasonably withheld. 
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
Sec. 3-5017. - Recordkeeping. 
    The contractor shall be responsible for maintaining information and records adequate to determine participation rates and weekly setout rates by percent, volume of solid waste diverted from the landfill by percent and other information required by the city necessary to meet the requirements of the State of Louisiana DEQ. The contractor shall furnish monthly reports to the city, due by the 10th day of the following month containing the requested information. 
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
Sec. 3-5018. - Equipment. 
    The contractor shall have on hand at all times and in good working order such equipment as shall permit the contractor to adequately and efficiently perform its duties. Equipment shall be obtained from nationally known and recognized manufacturers of collection and disposal equipment. Collection vehicles shall be of the enclosed loader packer type or other vehicle designed to allow for efficient collection of yard waste and shall not exceed forty-cubic-yard capacity. The equipment shall be kept in good repair, appearance and in a sanitary and clean condition at all times. All replacement and additional vehicles shall be new equipment unless otherwise agreed by the city. The contractor shall have available reserve equipment which can be put into service within two (2) hours of any breakdown. Such reserve equipment shall correspond in size and capacity to the equipment used by the contractor to perform the duties. A list of the contractor's equipment shall be given to the city. 
    Equipment is to be painted uniformly in colors selected exclusively for the yard waste program, only if taken to a compose facility. The contractor shall add his name, his telephone number to the side of the vehicle. All vehicles shall be numbered and a record kept of the vehicle to which each number is assigned. No advertising shall be permitted on vehicles except for that promoting the yard waste program. 
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
Sec. 3-5019. - Promotion of the yard waste recycling program. 
    Promotion and education about yard waste recycling is critical to the success of the yard waste program. The contractor will contract with and direct a professional advertising firm to develop a promotional and educational program. The city and contractor shall participate in the development and implementation of this program, including but not limited to consultation with the advertising firm, public appearances in support of the program, use of recycling themes and logos on collection vehicles, distribution of promotional literature, etc. The city shall approve all advertisements prior to publication. At least twice per year, the contractor shall distribute to all recycling customers a newsletter with information explaining and supporting the yard waste/recycling program. 
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
Sec. 3-5020. - Disposal. 
    All yard waste collected for composting shall be hauled by the contractor to a site approved by the Louisiana Department of Environmental Quality. 
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
GENERAL PROVISIONS 
Sec. 3-5021. - Annexations. 
    Should an area be annexed by the city, the contractor shall adjust service to the area upon receiving proper notification from the city. Service shall begin within thirty (30) days of such notification. The monthly rate paid to the contractor will be prorated based on the amount of service provided to the area annexed. 
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
Sec. 3-5022. - Changes in law or governmental laws. 
    In the event of changes in government regulations that substantially affect the ability of the contractor to operate under the terms of this agreement, new terms may be proposed by the contractor for consideration by the city. 
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
Sec. 3-5023. - Annual review and amendment. 
    The city and contractor will jointly review this ordinance and contract agreement at least once each year within sixty (60) days of the first day of July. Proposed changes in the ordinance will be submitted to the city counsel [council] for its consideration and approve [approval] in accordance with the law. The schedule of payment may be amended semi-annually as specified herein. The mayor and contractor will jointly review the service unit count on a semi-annual basis. 
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
Sec. 3-5024. - Payment. 
    Invoices submitted by contractor to the city on a monthly basis shall include monthly reports and, if applicable, copies of weight tickets from the collection and sale of materials. Payment will be made by the city to the contractor within thirty (30) days of the receipt of invoice and monthly report. 
    The city and contractor agree that as of July 15, 1993 there are one thousand eight hundred five (1,805) residential and commercial establishments service units which qualify for solid waste collection within the city. The contractor agrees to provide once a week solid waste collection of an unlimited amount of residential and commercial solid waste in the city to be disposed [of] at an approved site at a unit price of six dollars and ninety-nine cents ($6.99) per residential and commercial establishment per month. 
    The city and contractor agree that as of July 15, 1993 there are one thousand nine hundred seventy (1,970) residential establishments which would qualify for residential collection of source separated materials and yard waste. 
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
Sec. 3-5025. - Penalties. 
    Penalties for certain violations are specified herein: 
a)	Nonperformance: 
Violation: All complaints shall be made directly to the contractor and shall be given prompt and courteous attention. In the case of missed scheduled collections, the contractor shall investigate and shall arrange for the collection of recyclables within twenty-four (24) hours after complaint is received unless the established rejection of unacceptable materials procedure is followed. 
b)	Penalty: The penalty for missed collection shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per unserviced residential structure, the amount to be deducted from the city's monthly payment to the contractor. The city and contractor shall investigate any complaint necessary to validate a missed collection. 
c)	Non-default: Contractor shall not be deemed to be in default where their inability to perform any or all the conditions of the contract is the result of conditions beyond their control. Such conditions include civil disorder, acts of God, inclement weather severe enough that city trucks are kept off the roads, or changes in applicable statutes, regulations, or ordinances. Pickup shall not be required on the following holidays: New Years Day, Good Friday, Memorial Day, Independence Day, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Day or any other designated holiday by the city. On the aforementioned holidays, pickups shall be on the next scheduled collection day or shall be considered a missed pickup. 
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
Sec. 3-5026. - Compliance with laws. 
    The contractor shall conduct operations under this contract in compliance with all applicable federal, state and local laws. 
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
Sec. 3-5027. - Compliance with OSHA. 
    The contractor shall comply with all Federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) standards, rules and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
Sec. 3-5028. - Civil rights and discrimination. 
    The contractor shall adhere in hiring and employment practices to the provisions of all federal, state, and local laws which relate to civil rights and discrimination. 
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
Sec. 3-5029. - Effective date. 
    This contract shall be effective upon execution. Performance shall begin no later than sixty (60) days from adoption of this ordinance for solid waste collection. Recycling and yard waste collection shall commence at such time as the city and contractor can mutually agree. In the event of disagreement, the commencement time shall be set by the majority vote of the Westlake City Council. 
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
Sec. 3-5030. - Nondiscrimination. 
    The contractor shall not discriminate against any person because of race, sex, creed, color, religion or natural origin. This nondiscrimination clause shall be included in any subcontracts associated with the performance of this agreement. 
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
Sec. 3-5031. - Indemnity. 
    The contractor will indemnify, save harmless, and exempt the city, its officers, agents, servants and employees from and against any and all liability, suits, actions, legal proceedings, claims, demands, damages, costs, expenses and attorney's fees arising out or in any way concerning or incident to any work done in the performance of this contract or arising out of a willful or negligent act or omission of the contractor, its officers, agents, servants and employees; provided, however that the contractor shall not be liable for any suits, actions, legal proceedings, claims, demands, damages, costs, expenses and attorney's fees arising out of a willful or negligent act or omission of the owner, its officers, agents, servants and employees. 
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
Sec. 3-5032. - Licenses and taxes. 
    The contractor shall obtain all licenses and permits and promptly pay all taxes and government fees required for the operation of this contract. 
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
Sec. 3-5033. - Term of the contract. 
    The contract shall be for a period of time coinciding with the Calcasieu Parish Contract not to exceed five (5) years. The initial term of this contract shall be extended for an additional five-year term, unless either party notifies the other party in writing, not less than ninety (90) days prior to the expiration of the initial term, of its intentions to terminate this contract. Any such written notice shall be served by certified or registered mail, return receipt requested. 
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
Sec. 3-5034. - Insurance. 
    The contractor shall at all times during the contract maintain [in] full force and effect, Employer's Liability, Workmen's Compensation, Public Liability and Property Damage Insurance, including Contractual Liability coverage. All insurance shall be by insurers and for policy limits acceptable to the city and before commencement of work hereunder the contractor agrees to furnish the city certificates of insurance or other evidence satisfactory to the city to the effect that such insurance has been procured and is in force. The certificates shall contain the following express obligations for the purpose of the contract, the contractor shall carry the following types of insurance in at least the limits specified below: 
_____ 
Coverages Limits of Liability Workmen' s Compensation Statutory Employer's liability $500,000.00 Bodily injury liability except automobile $500,000.00 each occurrence; $1,000,000.00 aggregate Property damage liability except automobile $500,000.00 each occurrence; $500,000.00 aggregate Automobile bodily injury liability $500,000.00 each person; $1,000,000.00 each occurrence Automobile property damage liability $500,000.00 each occurrence Excess umbrella liability $5,000,000.00 each occurrence  
_____
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
Sec. 3-5035. - Performance bond. 
    The contractor will be required to furnish a corporate surety bond or letter of credit as security for the performance of this contract. Said surety bond shall be in the amount equal to twelve (12) months of this contract.
