    Premium for the bond described above shall be paid by the contractor. A certificate from the surety showing that the bond minimums are paid in full shall accompany the bond. Letters of credit shall be issued by banks chartered in the United States of America and made in favor of the owner. 
    The surety on the bond shall be a duly authorized corporate surety company authorized to do business in the state. Attorneys-in-fact who sign performance bonds or contract bonds must file with each bond a certified and effectively dated copy of their power of attorney. 
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
Sec. 3-5036. - Basis and method of payment. 
(a)	Solid Waste Collection and Disposal Rates Collection and Processing of Recyclables Yard Waste Collection. For collection, transportation, processing and disposal required to be performed pursuant to this ordinance, the charges shall not exceed the rates as fixed by this ordinance, as adjusted in accordance herewith. 
(b)	Modification to rates: 
(1)	Consumers price index annual adjustments. The fees which may be charged by the contractor for the second and subsequent years of the term hereof shall be adjusted upward or downward to reflect changes in the cost of operations, as reflected by fluctuations in the Consumer Price Index for Urban Wage Earners and Clerical Workers, Expenditures Category "Gasoline", both as published by the U.S. Department of Labor, Bureau of Labor statistics. As of the last month of the first year of the contract and every twelve (12) months thereafter (the "rate modification date"), the fees shall be increased or decreased for the ensuing twelve-month period in a percentage amount equal to ninety (90) percent of the net percentage change of the all items index plus ten (10) percent of the net percentage change of the gasoline index. All percentage changes are to be computed as the difference between the index value for the first full month prior to the commencement of the contract. The maximum increase or decrease in any one year is limited to ten (10) percent. 
As soon as possible after a rate modification date, contractor shall send to the owner, a comparative statement setting out for both the all items index and the gasoline index (1) the value on the first full month prior to the commencement of the contract; (2) the index value on the rate modification date preceding the date of the statement; (3) the net percentage change; (4) the composite percentage change equal to ninety (90) percent of the net percentage change in the all items index plus ten (10) percent of net percentage change in the gasoline index; and (5) the increase or decrease in the fees which may be charged by the contractor. On the next billing date after the receipt of the comparative statement, the city shall pay the contractor or the contractor shall credit to the city, as the case may be, a lump sum equal to any increase or decrease applicable to that portion of the current period which has elapsed and, thereafter, the monthly fees charged by the contractor shall be modified to reflect any change until a different comparative statement is received by the city. 
(2)	Governmental taxes and fee adjustment. Any taxes or fees imposed by any governmental unit shall be in addition to consumer price index adjustments. 
(3)	Disposal rate increases. The rate or fees charged by the contractor shall also be adjusted at reasonable times on the basis of extraordinary changes in the cost of operations at the disposal facility where the solid waste is disposed [of] as a direct result of disposal rate increases based upon or required by federal, state or local law, regulation, rule, ordinance, order, permit or permit condition that becomes effective after the date of this contract, and that was not imposed because of the action or inaction of contractor. Any such rate adjustment shall be based on a solid waste generation rate per actual scale weight, or one and two-tenths (1.2) tons per year per residential unit, if disposal fee is per ton, or that four (4) compacted truck yards equal one (1) ton, if the disposal fee is paid per truck yard. However, there shall be no rate increase for a duplication of taxes or fees imposed by any governmental unit and this disposal rate increase. 
(4)	Extraordinary changes to justify fee adjustment. In addition to the above, the contractor may petition to the city for additional rate and price adjustments no more than once per year on the basis of extraordinary changes in its cost of operations. Approval of justification for report of price statement shall not be unreasonably withheld. 
(c)	Contractor billings to city. The contractor shall bill the city for services rendered within ten (10) days following the end of the month and the city shall pay the contractor on or before thirty (30) days from receipt of invoice. Such billing and payment shall be based on the price rates and schedules set forth in this ordinance. The contractor shall verify the number of units serviced in a manner acceptable to city. 
(d)	Audit: The city may request and be provided with audit of actual expense to validate any request for increase in rates that in the city's opinion, appears to be unusual or not supportive by the data. Such audits shall be furnished to the city prior to any additional payment made by the city as requested by the contractor. City must request the audit within thirty (30) days of notification of an increase in rates. 
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
Sec. 3-5037. - Transferability of contract. 
    No assignment of this contract or any right occurring under shall be made in whole or in part by the contractor, either voluntarily or involuntarily or by a process of law and shall not come under the control of creditors or trustee(s) of contractor, without the express prior written consent of the city. In the event of any assignment, the assignee shall assume the liability of the contractor. 
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
Sec. 3-5038. - Nonexclusive contract. 
    This contract shall not constitute a franchise or exclusive to provide solid waste collection, removal and disposal services, recycling services, and yard waste collection from residential and commercial units for and on behalf of the City of Westlake, Louisiana. This agreement shall not constitute a franchise or exclusive right to collect solid waste from commercial units within the city. 
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
Sec. 3-5039. - Ownership. 
    Title to solid waste, yard waste and recycled material shall pass to the contractor when placed in contractor's vehicle after removal by the contractor from a container. 
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
Sec. 3-5040. - Termination, discontinued service and other breaches of the contract. 
    If the contractor fails to provide the solid waste collection services, yard waste collection/composting or recycling services required by this agreement for a period in excess of three (3) consecutive, scheduled, working days, the city may take the following actions: 
(a)	At its option, take possession of all the contractor's equipment and facilities used in performance of this contract agreement. 
(b)	Employ such means as it may deem advisable and appropriate to continue work until such matter is resolved and the contractor is again able to carry out his operations under this contract. 
(c)	Deduct any and all operating expenses incurred by the city from any money then due or to become due the contractor, and should the city's cost for continuing the operation exceed the amount due the contractor, collect the amount due, either from the contractor or surety or both and also to assert a lien on all properties of the contractor. 
(d)	During such period, the liability of the city to the contractor for loss or damage to equipment and facilities so used shall be that of a bailee for hire, ordinary wear and tear being specifically exempt from such liability. 
(e)	If the contractor is unable, for any cause, to resume performance at the end of thirty (30) days, all liability of the city to the contractor under this agreement shall cease and the city shall be free to negotiate with another contractor for the operation of said solid waste service and/or take the actions provided below for bankruptcy, default, breech of contract. Such actions shall not release the contractor herein of his liability to the city for such breach of this contract. 
    In the event the contractor shall be adjudged bankrupt, either by voluntary or involuntary proceedings, then this contract shall immediately terminate and in no event shall this contract be, or be treated as, an asset of contractor after adjudication of bankruptcy. 
    If contractor shall be proven insolvent, or fail in business, this contract may be terminated at the option of the city. 
    All terms, conditions, and specifications of the contract are considered material and failure to perform any part of the contract shall be considered a breach of contract. Should the contractor fail to perform any of its obligations, the city may at its option, terminate the contract ten (10) days after written notification to the contractor to remedy the violation within said time. 
    In the event of termination of the contract for breach, default or bankruptcy as specified above, the city shall have the right to forthwith take possession of all of the contractor's equipment, facilities, and records used in performance of this agreement as follows: 
(a)	The city shall have the right to retain possession of said equipment, facilities, and records until other such items can be acquired by the city for operation of the system or another contractor is engaged to perform the service. 
(b)	The city shall have the right at its option to purchase contractor's equipment and facilities at the depreciated fair market value thereof. 
(c)	The city shall pay contractor the reasonable rental value of such equipment and facilities during the time same are used by the city should they elect not to purchase. Liability of the city to the contractor during this period shall be that of a bailee for hire, ordinary wear and tear specifically exempt from such liability. 
Should it become necessary for the city to employ an attorney to enforce the provisions of the contract, the contractor shall be responsible for the payment of reasonable attorney's fees. 
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
Sec. 3-5041. - Contractor's property. 
    The contractor shall not transfer, sell, assign, lease, surrender, abandon, or permit to lapse his title or right or possession in any and to any real or personal property used in the performance of this contract without the prior written consent of the city. Any attempt to do so without such permission shall constitute a material breach of contract, unless the contractor maintains the amount of equipment specified on the inventory list. 
(a)	The contractor shall maintain a complete inventory of all real property, buildings, furnishings, containers, vehicles, and any other pieces of equipment necessary for the performance of this contract and shall furnish the city with such inventory upon request. 
(b)	The contractor shall inform the city of all additions and deletions to said inventory within a reasonable time but not more than thirty (30) days following any transaction or upon request. 
(c)	The contractor shall maintain the existing equipment, or replace equipment with new equipment purchased from nationally known or recognized manufacturers for garbage collection. The contractor shall have available at all times, reserve equipment which can be put into service and operations with[in] two (2) hours of any breakdown. Such reserve equipment shall substantially correspond in size and capability, to the equipment used by the contractor to perform its duties hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
Sec. 3-5042. - Contractor's liability. 
    Contractor shall pay all just claims due for the payment of all employees and mechanics for labor that shall be performed, for the payment of all material and equipment furnished, and for the payment of material and equipment rental which is actually used in the performance of the contract. 
    The contract[or] shall upon request, submit evidence satisfactory the city that all payrolls, equipment or material bills and other indebtedness pertaining to the performance hereof have been paid. 
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
Sec. 3-5043. - Termination of contract. 
    In the event it shall become impossible or unlawful for the contractor to continue the performance of this contract by reasons of an Act of God, an act of the legislature hereinafter passed, or act of the city, or by reason of a final order by a court of record in proceedings not instituted by or acquiesced in by the negligence upon the contract, the contractor shall not be liable for damages arising solely out of such impossibility. The contract shall be terminated and the contractor shall recover from the city, payment for all services rendered prior to the date of termination of the contract. 
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
Sec. 3-5044. - Liquidated damages. 
    As a breach of the service provided by this contract would cause serious and substantial damage to the city and its occupants, and the nature of this contract would render it impracticable or extremely difficult to fix the actual damage sustained by the city be such breach, it is agreed that in case of breach of service, the city may elect to collect liquidated damages as specified below and not as a penalty, the amounts set forth below, such sums being agreed as the amount which the city will be damaged by the breach of such service. An election to seek such remedies the city may have as to any subsequent breach of service under this contract. 
A truck beginning residential collections prior to 5:00 a.m. without the approval of the city, one hundred dollars per incident. 
Failure to collect misses within twenty-four (24) hours of notification to contractor, twenty-five dollars each. 
Repetition of complaints on a route after notification of spilling, noncollection, crossing planted areas, or similar violations, twenty-five dollars each. 
    Liquidated damages shall be adjusted upward or downward at the time and at the same rate as the collection fees are adjusted. 
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
Sec. 3-5045. - Independent contractor. 
    It is specifically understood and agreed between the city and contractor, that the contractor is an independent contractor and not an employee or agent of the City of Westlake. 
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
Sec. 3-5046. - Applicable law. 
    The provisions of this ordinance and contract shall be governed by the Laws of the State of Louisiana, and the venue shall be the Fourteenth Judicial District Court. 
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
Sec. 3-5047. - Conflicts. 
    Conflicts in the provisions of this ordinance and the Calcasieu Parish Contract with contractor exist, then the provisions of this ordinance shall be controlling. 
    Should this ordinance be in conflict with any provisions of the Code of Ordinances for the City of Westlake, then the provisions of this ordinance shall be controlling. 
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
Sec. 3-5048. - Severability. 
    If any provision of this ordinance or the application thereto any person or circumstance is held invalid, such invalidity shall not affect other provisions or applications of the ordinance which can be given effect without the invalid provisions or application, and to that end, the provisions of this ordinance are declared to be severable. 
(Ord. No. 517, 9-16-93) 
Sec. 3-5049. - Applicability of solid waste collection provisions to collection services rendered by persons contracting with the City of Westlake for solid waste collection services. 
    The obligations with respect to solid waste collection, of any natural or juridical person (hereafter referred to as "contractor") that enters into a contract with the City of Westlake for the collection of solid waste (hereinafter referred to as the "contract") shall be regulated and controlled by the terms and conditions of the contract, and contractor shall not be subject to any provision, regulation, requirement, or obligation contained within Part 3, Chapter 5 of the Code of Ordinances in and for the City of Westlake, which conflicts in any way with the terms, conditions, requirements and/or obligations set forth in the contract. Such conflicting provisions of Part 3, Chapter 5 being inapplicable to the collection services rendered by contractor. 
(Ord. No. 835 , § 1, 5-21-12) 
PART 4. - PUBLIC SAFETY 
CHAPTER 1. - POLICE PROTECTION 

Sec. 4-1001. - Department created. 
    There is created a police department for the municipality which shall consist of the chief of police and as many policemen as may be deemed necessary for safety and good order by the mayor and city council. 
Sec. 4-1002. - Department rules and regulations. 
    The police department shall be operated and managed in accordance with departmental rules and regulations as may be adopted by the mayor and city council. 
Sec. 4-1003. - Duties of the chief of police. 
    Other than those duties and powers already granted herein, the chief of police shall: 
(1)	Execute and return all writs and processes as directed by the mayor. 
(2)	Within the city, suppress all riots, disturbances and breaches of the peace; apprehend all disorderly persons; pursue and arrest any person fleeing from justice; and apprehend any person in the act of violating the laws of the state or the Code of this city and bring him before competent authority for examination and trial. 
(3)	Render such accounts of the police department, his duties, department operations and receipts as may be required by the mayor and city council and keep records of the department and his office open to public inspection at all reasonable times. 
(4)	Make recommendations to the mayor and council regarding personnel matters of the police department. 
Sec. 4-1004. - Duties of police officers. 
    All members of the police department shall: 
(1)	Perform all duties as required by law. 
(2)	Suppress all riots, disturbances and breaches of the peace, apprehend all disorderly persons in this city, and pursue and arrest any person fleeing from justice who may be apprehended within the city. 
(3)	Be the enforcement officers of this city and see that the provisions of this Code, any other city regulations and the laws of the state are complied with. 
(4)	Report offenses as may come to their knowledge to the proper city official or report to the mayor, securing a warrant for the arrest of offenders as shall be directed. 
(5)	Execute and return all writs and processes to them directed by the mayor in any action arising under this Code. 
(6)	Observe the condition of the streets, sidewalks and alleys of this city, and of any obstruction, nuisance or impediments there and take necessary measures to remove or abate them. 
Sec. 4-1005. - Oath of office. 
    Before entering upon the duties of his office, each police officer shall take and subscribe to an oath that he will support the Constitution and laws of the state, the Constitution of the United States, and the Code of this city, and that he will faithfully perform the duties of the office upon which he is about to enter. 
Sec. 4-1006. - Uniforms. 
    Every police officer shall wear at all times, while on duty, a uniform of the type and quality prescribed by the mayor and city council. 
Sec. 4-1007. - Duties of citizens to aid. 
    It should be the duty of all persons, when called upon by a police officer, to promptly aid and assist such officer in the discharge of his duties. 
CHAPTER 2. - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION 
ARTICLE A. - FIRE DEPARTMENT[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 450, adopted Aug. 22, 1989, amended Art. A to read as herein set forth. Prior to such amendment, Art. A consisted of §§ 4-2001-4-2009 which pertained to the volunteer fire department and derived from Ord. No. 409, adopted Jan. 28, 1985. The appendixes referred to in new Art. A have not been included herein but are on file and available for reference in the city offices. 

Sec. 4-2001. - Organization; chief and assistant chief. 
(a)	The department shall consist of a chief, one assistant chief, and other officers as the chief deems necessary with the approval of the mayor and council for the effective operations of the department. 
(b)	The chief shall be appointed by the mayor with the approval of the city council for an indefinite period of time, and his tenure of office shall depend upon his good conduct and efficiency. The chief shall be technically qualified for the office by education with either an associate degree in fire science or equivalent, or consideration for years of experience in the field of fire service as well as training achieved. He shall have the ability to command men and hold their respect and confidence. He shall be removed only for just cause and after a public hearing before the city council. 
(c)	The chief shall be held accountable to the mayor only, and shall make written and verbal reports to the mayor and council as may be required. 
(d)	The assistant chief shall be appointed by the mayor with recommendation from the chief subject to removal by the mayor. He/she must be firefighter I, firefighter II, and within six (6) months of appointment, be certified as instructor I. 
(e)	All other officers of the fire department will be appointed by the mayor upon recommendation from the fire chief and assistant fire chief and be subject to removal by the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 450, 8-22-89) 
Sec. 4-2002. - Duties of chief. 
(a)	The chief shall be at the head of the department, subject to the laws of the State of Louisiana, rules and regulations of the City of Westlake, and ordinances herein adopted. 
(b)	The chief shall be held responsible for the general condition and efficient operation of the department, the training of the members, and the performance of all other duties imposed upon him. 
(c)	The chief shall, at least once a month, conduct or cause to be conducted suitable drills or instruction in the operations and handling of equipment, first aid and rescue work, salvage and study of buildings in the city, fire prevention, water supplies and all other matters generally considered essential to good firemanship and safety of life and property from fire. 
(d)	The chief shall formulate a set of rules and regulations to govern the department and shall be responsible to the mayor for the personnel, morale and general efficiency of the department. 
(e)	The chief shall determine the number and kinds of companies of which the department is to be composed and shall determine the response of the companies to alarms. Said determination shall be submitted to the mayor in writing for his approval. No changes to that determination shall be performed without the mayor's approval. 
(f)	The chief is required to assist the proper authorities in suppressing the crime of arson by investigating or causing to be investigated the cause, origin and circumstances of all fires. 
(g)	The chief is hereby empowered to enter any and all places of public assembly and their premises at any reasonable hour for the purpose of making inspections and to serve written notice upon the owner or occupant to abate within a specified time and any and all fire hazards that may be found. Any person so served with a written notice to abate any fire hazard or hazards shall comply there and then, promptly, and notify the chief. 
(h)	The chief shall see that complete records are kept on all fire inspections, investigations, apparatus and minor equipment, personnel and other information about the work of the department in locked files and such records shall be considered confidential. 
(i)	The chief shall report monthly to the mayor and city council the condition of the apparatus and equipment, the number of fires during the month, their location and cause, the date of fire, and loss occasioned thereby, the number and purpose of all other runs made, and the number of members responding to each fire or other run, and any change in membership. 
(j)	The chief, with the water superintendent, may inspect, or cause to be inspected by members of the department, the fire hydrants, cisterns and other sources of water supply at least twice each year. 
(k)	The chief shall maintain a library file updated yearly with current fire codes as funds permit. This library shall also contain publications on fire prevention and fire protection and shall make use of it to the best advantage of all members. 
(l)	The chief shall make every effort to attend all fires and direct the officers and members in the performance of their duties. 
(m)	The chief shall see that the citizens are kept informed on fire hazards in the community and on the activities of the department. 
(n)	The chief shall abide by duly executed mutual aid agreements with other departments in surrounding communities, and take part of his apparatus and department to their aid when requested. In the event that the fire department and or apparatus responds to a call from another city or community it shall be the duty of the chief to make arrangements or provisions for suitable temporary protection for his own community. 
(o)	In the absence of a full-time firefighter on duty, the chief will be the relief person. (See section 4-2005.) 
(p)	See Appendix A for additional duties. 
(Ord. No. 450, 8-22-89) 
Sec. 4-2003. - Membership. 
(a)	The membership of the department shall consist of such persons as may be appointed by the mayor upon recommendation of the chief who shall be able-bodied citizens residing within the limits of the fire district and/or City of Westlake, and who have telephones in their homes. The determination of whether the candidate for appointment is an able-bodied person shall be made by the chief. A medical and physical examination will be required for permanent employees only. On volunteers, a medical history form will be required. The physician shall determine whether the person is able-bodied. 
(b)	A three-man screening committee shall screen all new applications and make necessary recommendations for appointments as vacancies occur. The recommendations shall be turned in to the mayor for approval before the candidate can become a bona fide volunteer firefighter. The committee shall consist of one (1) captain, one (1) lieutenant, and one (1) firefighter and shall be appointed by the chief with the approval of the mayor. 
(c)	Any member of the department may be suspended or discharged from the department by the mayor at any time he may deem such action necessary for the good of the department. All suspensions or discharges shall be in writing giving dates, places and reasons for such action and turned in to the city clerk for recordation. Upon written request within ten (10) days, any discharged or suspended member may ask for and shall be granted a public hearing before the mayor. 
(d)	Any firefighter wishing to take a leave of absence or to terminate his affiliation with the fire department must do so in writing to the mayor with a copy to the fire chief. This will be kept by the city clerk for recordation purposes. 
(e)	Each member is responsible for all departmental equipment issued him and shall return to the department any departmental equipment in his possession at the time of his or her termination. All issued equipment shall be kept clean and in good maintenance at all times. Any equipment that is lost will be paid for by the firefighter at the time of termination or at the time that the equipment is lost. 
(Ord. No. 450, 8-22-89) 
Sec. 4-2004. - Departmental equipment and apparatus. 
(a)	The department shall be equipped with such apparatus and other equipment as may be required from time to time to maintain it's efficiency, fire rating, and to properly protect life and property. All equipment shall be maintained to meet manufacturer's recommendations or specifications for servicing. The records are to be kept on file. 
(b)	Recommendations of firefighting apparatus and equipment needed shall be made by the chief to the mayor and city council for approval. Recommendations for training equipment shall be made to the fire chief for his approval and subsequent approval by the mayor and city council. 
(c)	All equipment of the department shall be safely and conveniently housed in such places as may be designated by the mayor and city council. Such places shall be heated during the winter season. 
(d)	Suitable arrangements shall be provided for citizens to turn in an alarm of fire and for notifying all members of the department so that they may promptly respond. Dispatchers shall notify the fire department personnel immediately upon receiving an alarm and assist at the scene of any emergency. 
(Ord. No. 450, 8-22-89) 
Sec. 4-2005. - Conduct and duties of personnel, members of the public. 
(a)	If funds are available for full-time firefighters to man the fire station twenty-four (24) hours a day, three hundred sixty-five (365) days a year, it shall be the duty of the shift foreman with the approval of the chief to maintain this schedule at all times unless otherwise authorized by the mayor. In the absence of a firefighter, the chief will be the relief. 
(b)	Each member of the department shall be issued a badge designating his or her rank upon approval of the mayor, with recordation of such to the city clerk. 
(c)	Each member of the department shall be issued a suitable insignia to be attached to his or her personal car designating them as a member of the department. 
(d)	All motor equipment and personal cars of the department members shall have the right-of-way over all other traffic when responding to an alarm. At no time shall the member exceed the posted speed limit or disregard traffic signals, stop signs or other traffic-control devices. The member is not relieved of his or her responsibilities if involved in a traffic accident. (This is in reference to Act 160 of 1980, the Attorney General's Opinion). 
(e)	All members shall assist in the work of the department whether it be their assigned duties or not, and in the absence of any specific orders or apparent work to be done, they shall report to the officer in charge of their company. 
(f)	All members shall give strict obedience to the orders of their appointed or elected officers, and display a respectful and professional attitude during all departmental activities. Any violation of this policy shall result in disciplinary action such as a reprimand or, ultimately, dismissal. This recommendation shall come from the fire chief and/or the assistant fire chief subject to approval of the mayor. The mayor shall be the ultimate supervisor over the entire fire department including the volunteers, in regards to their activities associated with the operation of the fire department. 
(g)	No volunteer officer shall command any full-time firefighter but on the fire grounds or associated fire activity. 
(h)	If any officer positions come open, the full-time firefighter will have the first option to fill that position if all other qualifications are equal. 
(i)	Work at fires and drills shall be done in a quick, orderly, quiet and professional manner and all fire department personnel shall display a polite and courteous manner to any private citizen or any other individual(s) who may have been called in for additional aid at the scene. 
(j)	The chief and his department shall cooperate fully with other departments of the city, whether it be the assistance from its personnel, equipment, etc. However, said requests and type of assistance to be provided shall have prior approval from the mayor. 
(k)	No member shall use any fire apparatus or equipment for any private purpose, nor shall any member willfully and without proper authority take away or conceal any article used in any way by the department. 
(l)	No member, unless he is a licensed driver by the State of Louisiana, shall drive any piece of department apparatus. 
(m)	All members of the department should become familiar with the cause and behavior of fire. They shall have forty-two (42) hours of continuing education per year and have one (1) year from the time of appointment before becoming eligible to be a firefighter I, state certified. 
(n)	No member shall report to any alarm of fire or any departmental activity while under the influence of drugs or in an intoxicated state. 
(o)	All members of the department shall also be members of the Louisiana State Fireman's Association, Southwest Louisiana Mutual Aid Association and any other association that the membership so elects and which is approved by the mayor and city council. Dues to such associations shall be paid from departmental funds. 
(p)	Members of the department shall be compensated for each fire and drill attended in accordance with schedules as from time to time are adopted by the mayor and city council. Compensation will be on a monthly basis on the last working day of the month by 4:30 p.m. See the current pay schedule in force now. 
(q)	No alcoholic beverages will be brought or consumed at the scene of a fire or at any departmental meeting. 
(r)	No person shall park any vehicle or otherwise cause any obstruction to be placed within ten (10) feet of a driveway, ten (10) feet of the entrance of any fire station or other place where fire apparatus is stored or within ten (10) feet of any fire hydrant. 
(s)	No unauthorized person with any vehicle shall follow within six hundred (600) feet of any apparatus belonging to the fire department nor park any vehicle within three hundred (300) feet of a fire unless so authorized by the fire chief. 
(t)	No person not a member of the department unless authorized by a department officer shall be allowed to ride on the apparatus or to handle the equipment. 
(u)	Each member of the department shall be capable of operating and maintaining each piece of fire fighting equipment in an efficient and safe manner. 
(v)	Any member bringing any person into the fire situation shall be held responsible for any act that person may commit. 
(w)	No member of the department except an officer acting on orders of the department shall disclose to any person, not a member of the department, any business or other discussions which take place at official assemblies (whether it be a drill, training session, fire, general meeting, or any city sponsored function) of the department. No person shall give press releases or information on the fire department on city stationery without the approval of the mayor, and a copy must be turned over to the city clerk. Any member making such disclosures which are deemed detrimental to the good of the department shall be subject to reprimand or dismissal upon recommendation of the fire chief and/or assistant fire chief to the mayor. 
(x)	No member shall loan or cause to be loaned any departmental equipment without the consent of the chief or officer in charge. 
(y)	The regular meetings and drills of the department shall be held on the second and fourth Thursdays of the month at 6:00 p.m. in the fire station unless otherwise stated. Special meetings and drills to be held at a specified time and place may be called by the chief, or in the case of training drills, they may be called by the assistant chief. All members must attend unless they have a reasonable excuse. Reasonable excuses are defined by the department as sickness of the member or his immediate family, working out of city, unexpected visitors in the home, or being on vacation. Any member absent from a sufficient number of drills so that he cannot obtain a minimum of nine (9) hours' training per quarter, or who does not make up the required hours within the quarter, shall be subject to discipline or review by the chief. 
(z)	All members responding to less than forty (40) percent of his or her alarms shall be dropped from the department. Credit for hours of training will be given for only those hours actually attended to the nearest one-half (1/2) hour. Documentation will be kept on each session attended by original signatures and time kept by the training officer, with those leaving early or arriving late to the session only, having to sign in or out their clock time. 
(Ord. No. 450, 8-22-89) 
Sec. 4-2006. - Enforcement; fines. 
(a)	Any person violating the provisions of section 4-2005 (k), (l), (m), (n), (r), (s) or (t) shall, upon conviction in police court of this city, pay a fine of not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) or more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each offense. 
(b)	Any person in violation of section 4-2002 (g) shall be fined the minimum amount for each day he is in violation after the expiration of his grace period. 
(c)	It is hereby made the special duty of the chief of police and/or other peace officers who may be on duty and available for fire duty to respond to all fire alarms and assist the department in the protection of life and property in regulating traffic, maintaining order, and in enforcing observance of all sections of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 450, 8-22-89) 
Sec. 4-2007. - Assistant chief. 
(a)	There shall be an assistant chief who shall report to the chief at fires and assist him in the discharge of his duties according to state law. 
(b)	In the absence of the chief, the assistant chief shall command the department and be held responsible therefor in all respects with full powers and responsibilities of the chief. 
(c)	The assistant chief shall also act as the department training officer, if appointed by the chief with the approval of the mayor. The training officer could also be any other full-time firefighter of the department besides the assistant chief. The assistant chief shall maintain a high proficiency in the latest firefighting techniques. He shall attend all necessary schools when practical so that these standards shall be maintained. 
(d)	In the absence of both the chief and assistant chief, the highest ranking officer shall command the department with all the powers and responsibilities of the chief. 
(e)	The assistant chief also will be the hazardous materials specialist and the assistant civil defense director in the absence of the civil defense director upon appointment by the mayor. 
(f)	The assistant chief, upon approval of the chief and mayor, shall represent the department in legislative matters and other public functions as deemed necessary. 
(g)	The assistant chief shall be in charge of and maintain all official training reports and documents. 
(h)	He shall assist in full-time personnel time scheduling. He shall assist in approving and recording all shift changes with the approval of the chief. 
(i)	See Appendixes B and C for additional duties. 
(Ord. No. 450, 8-22-89) 
Sec. 4-2007.1. - Captains. 
(a)	Each company of the department shall be in direct charge of a captain, appointed by the mayor with recommendation from the chief. He must be at least firefighter II certified. Existing officers as of August 22, 1989 must reach this certification within one (1) year. The captain shall be responsible to the chief of the department for the efficient operation of the company. 
(b)	In the absence of the chief and the assistant chief, the captain of the first company to arrive at a fire shall command the entire department and, in his absence, the lieutenant of the first company to arrive shall take command until relieved by a superior officer. 
(c)	Each captain shall preserve the discipline of his company and instruct members in their duties. Each captain shall direct the operations of his company at fires and carry out the orders of the chief. He shall report the condition in the position to which he has been assigned and make recommendations where needed to more effectively control the fire. He shall supervise the relief of his men during severe fires to keep them in the most effective condition possible. 
(d)	Each captain shall inspect or cause to be inspected all equipment in his charge each month to see that all equipment is clean, in it's proper place and ready for service. A report of same shall be made to the chief each month. 
(e)	Each captain will see that all hose used at fires or drills is replaced and that no wet hose is placed on the apparatus, and that dirty hose is cleaned or provisions made for it's cleaning. 
(f)	Each captain shall be skilled in firefighting operations and shall maintain a high degree of skill in the latest techniques of both firefighting and fire prevention. 
(g)	Each captain shall be responsible for making out a complete fire report after each fire or investigation he responds to while on fire call duty. The reports shall be properly submitted to the chief for his review and approval. 
(h)	Each captain will assist the training officer at training sessions in the training of the men of his company. 
(i)	Captains shall be responsible for taking roll call at fires and may, at their discretion, relieve members at the scene after the fire or cause their return to the station before relieving them. 
(j)	See Appendix D for duties of full-time captains. 
(Ord. No. 450, 8-22-89) 
Sec. 4-2008. - Lieutenants. 
(a)	The lieutenant shall be appointed by the chief with the mayor's approval to serve under the captain for each company. Appointments to this position must be at least firefighter II certified. Existing officers in this position not certified have one(1) year from August 22, 1989 to become certified. 
(b)	Qualifications for lieutenant: 
(1)	Lieutenant must be knowledgeable with all departmental equipment and firefighting techniques. 
(2)	Lieutenant must be employed by the city no less than one (1) year. 
(c)	Duties of lieutenant: 
(1)	Fight all fires within the fire district or mutual aid calls, i.e., structural fires, vehicle fires, grass fires, trash fires, investigations, etc. 
(2)	Keep all equipment clean. 
(3)	Lieutenant at a fire scene will take charge of any duties passed down by the chief/assistant chief/captain; he will take charge of the fire scene to the best of his trained abilities. 
(4)	After returning to the station from a fire or training the lieutenant will double check all apparatus and departmental equipment to assure everything is back in its proper place. 
(5)	Lieutenant must maintain forty-two (42) hours of in-house training per year. 
(6)	Lieutenant who is off duty and available shall report to the station for structural fires, grass fires, mutual aid calls, etc. 
(d)	The lieutenant shall perform all the duties of a captain in the absence of the company captain. At other times, he shall perform duties as assigned by the company captain or other ranking departmental officer. 
(Ord. No. 450, 8-22-89) 
Sec. 4-2009. - Full-time firefighters. 
    See Appendix E for details on qualifications and duties of full-time firefighters. 
(Ord. No. 450, 8-22-89) 
Sec. 4-2010. - Station manager. 
(a)	Qualifications of station manager: 
(1)	Station manager is by mayor's appointment only, with recommendations by the chief. 
(2)	Station manager must be employed by the city no less than one year. 
(b)	Duties of station manager: 
(1)	Station manager shall maintain all departmental equipment, i.e., all fire apparatus, all generators, portable pump, Hurst tool power unit, etc. 
(2)	Station manager shall keep bay floor and bay area clean at all times. 
(3)	Station manager shall keep offices, meeting room, restrooms, and outside area of station neat and clean at all times. 
(4)	Station manager will report any deficiencies of equipment and station using chain of command. 
(5)	Station manager will maintain forty-two (42) hours of in-house training per year. 
(6)	Station managers off duty and available shall report to station for structural fires, grass fires, mutual aid fires etc. 
(7)	See Appendix E for additional duties. 
(Ord. No. 450, 8-22-89) 
Sec. 4-2011. - Violations; penalties. 
(a)	No person shall park any vehicle or otherwise cause any obstruction to be placed within (10) feet of a driveway, ten (10) feet of the entrance to any fire station or other place where fire apparatus is stored or within ten (10) feet of any fire hydrant. 
(b)	No unauthorized person with any vehicle shall follow within six hundred (600) feet of any apparatus belonging to the fire department nor park any vehicle within three hundred (300) feet of a fire unless so authorized by the fire chief. 
(c)	No person not a member of the department, unless authorized by a department officer, shall be allowed to ride on the apparatus or to handle the equipment. 
(d)	Any person violating the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction in police court of this city, pay a fine of not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) or more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each offense. 
(e)	Any person in violation of this section shall be fined the minimum amount for each day he is in violation after the expiration of his grace period. 
(f)	It is hereby made the special duty of the chief of police and/or other peace officers who may be on duty and available for the fire duty to respond to all fire alarms and assist the department in the protection of life and property in regulating traffic, maintaining order, and in enforcing observance of all sections of this article. 
(Ord. No. 450, 8-22-89) 
Secs. 4-2012-4-2020. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE B. - FIRE PREVENTION CODE 

Sec. 4-2021. - Adoption of fire prevention code. 
(a)	The International Fire Code, 2003 edition, of which no less than one (1) copy is on file in the office of the city clerk, prescribing regulations for the safeguarding of life and property from the hazards of fire and explosion arising from the storage, handling and use of hazardous substances, materials and devices, and from conditions hazardous to life or property in the use or occupancy of buildings or premises, is hereby adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein. 
(b)	All future amendments or changes to the fire prevention code as may be adopted shall be deemed to be adopted and incorporated into this chapter and shall apply prospectively from the date of the amendment, change or revision; at least one (1) copy of any such amendments, changes or revisions shall be filed with the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 718 , § 1, 12-20-04) 
Sec. 4-2022. - Enforcement. 
    The code adopted shall be enforced by the chief of the fire department. 
(Ord. No. 154, § 2, 4-24-67) 
Sec. 4-2023. - Definition. 
    Wherever the word "municipality" is used in the code hereby adopted, it shall be held to mean the City of Westlake, Louisiana. 
(Ord. No. 154, § 3, 4-24-67) 
Sec. 4-2024. - Storage of flammable liquids, gases and explosives limited to restricted districts. 
    The limits referred to in section 16.22a of the code hereby adopted, in which storage of flammable liquids in outside aboveground tanks is prohibited, the limits referred to in section 21.6a of the code hereby adopted, in which bulk storage of liquefied petroleum gas is restricted, and the limits referred to in section 12.5b of the code hereby adopted, in which storage of explosives and blasting agents is prohibited, are hereby established as follows: 
    All properties within the city designated as "commercial" under the existing Westlake Zoning Ordinance. 
Sec. 4-2025. - Modifications. 
    The chief of the fire department shall have power to modify any of the provisions of the code hereby adopted, upon application in writing by the owner or lessee, or his duly authorized agent, when there are practical difficulties in the way of carrying out the strict letter of the code; provided that the spirit of the code shall be observed, public safety secured, and substantial justice done. The particulars of the modification when granted or allowed and the decision of the chief of the fire department shall be entered upon the records of the department and a signed copy shall be furnished the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 154, § 5, 4-24-67) 
Sec. 4-2026. - Appeals. 
    Whenever the chief of the fire department shall disapprove an application or refuse to grant a permit applied for, or when it is claimed that the provisions of the code do not apply or that the true intent and meaning of the code have been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the applicant may appeal from the decision of the chief of the fire department to the city council within thirty (30) days from the date of the decision appealed. 
(Ord. No. 154, § 6, 4-24-67) 
Sec. 4-2027. - Penalties. 
(a)	Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of the code hereby adopted or fail to comply therewith, or who shall violate or fail to comply with any order made thereunder, or who shall build in violation of any detailed statement of specifications or plans issued thereunder, or any certificate of permit issued thereunder, and from which no appeal has been taken, or who shall fail to comply with such an order as affirmed or modified by the fire chief or by a court of competent jurisdiction, within the time fixed herein, shall severally for each and every violation and noncompliance respectively, be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) or by imprisonment for not less than five (5) days nor more than thirty (30) days or by both such fine and imprisonment. The imposition of one (1) penalty for any violation shall not excuse the violation or permit it to continue; and all such persons shall be required to correct or remedy the violations or defects within a reasonable time; and when not otherwise specified, each ten (10) days that prohibited conditions are maintained shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)	The application of the above penalty shall not be held to prevent the enforced removal of prohibited conditions. 
CHAPTER 3. - CIVIL DEFENSE AND EMERGENCY PREPAREDNESS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 401, enacted Aug. 12, 1984, did not specifically amend this Code of Ordinances; hence, codification of the substantive provisions of such ordinance, §§ 7-1-7-11 and 7-13, as superseding former Ch. 3 of Part 4 of this Code was at the discretion of the editor. Former Ch. 3 consisted of §§ 4-3001-4-3004 which pertained to civil defense and derived from Ord. No. 103, enacted Aug. 24, 1962. 
Cross reference- Emergency powers of mayor and mayor pro tem, § 2-2004. 
State Law reference- Louisiana Homeland Security and Emergency Assistance and Disaster Act, R.S., 29:721 et seq. 

Sec. 4-3001. - Statutory authority; short title. 
    There is hereby created jointly with the Calcasieu Parish Police Jury, Calcasieu Parish, Louisiana, the governing authority thereof, a local organization for civil defense and emergency preparedness, pursuant to the provisions of Louisiana Civil Defense Law, Title 29, R.S., 29:608 and R.S., 29:709, as amended, and this chapter shall be known and may be cited and referred to as the "Civil Defense and Emergency Preparedness Ordinance" of the city. 
(Ord. No. 401, § 1(7-1), 8-12-84) 
Sec. 4-3002. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the meanings respectively ascribed: 
    Chief executive means the mayor of the city or the president of the police jury, who by virtue of their offices are responsible for meeting the dangers to the political subdivision, and to the people, presented by an actual or potential disaster. 
    Civil defense, emergency preparedness and emergency management mean the preparation for and carrying out of all disaster emergency programs, activities and functions, except those for which military forces are primarily responsible, to prevent, minimize and repair injury and damage resulting from a disaster as hereinafter defined. Such preparations shall include the preparation and maintenance of plans and procedures, in coordination with law enforcement, fire, public works, health and medical, safety and private organizations, volunteer disaster relief organizations, industry, and individuals, that will provide to the greatest extent possible, organized and effective disaster/emergency response to meet the threats that may arise; to prepare plans to provide warning to the public of both manmade, natural or technological disasters, actual or impending, and cooperate with private industry in an effort to assure adequate and timely warning of officials and the public of an actual or impending accident or incident, including the loss or spill of any hazardous material, chemical product, petroleum product or substance in any form which may be a hazard to the health, safety or welfare of the public or environment. 
    Civil defense forces means the employees, equipment, and facilities of city and parish departments, boards, commissions and institutions; and, in addition, it shall include volunteer or auxiliary personnel, equipment and/or facilities contributed by, or obtained from volunteer persons, agencies or organizations. 
    Civil defense volunteer means any person duly registered, identified and appointed in accordance with the Louisiana Civil Defense Act, R.S., 29:602, as amended, and assigned by the coordinator of the office of emergency preparedness and public safety to participate in the civil defense and emergency preparedness activity, including those military reservists recruited to augment the emergency management staff under the individual mobilization augmentee program. 
    Disaster or emergency means the occurrence or imminent threat of widespread or severe damage, injury, or loss of life or property resulting from any natural, manmade or technological cause, including, but not limited to hurricane, tornado, flood, high water, wind-driven water, storm surge, or tidal wave, earthquake, drought, energy shortage or power failure, fire, explosion, loss or spill or any hazardous material, hostile enemy action, terrorist actions or any other disaster emergency that may occur. 
    Emergency preparedness coordinator, emergency management coordinator or civil defense director means that person duly appointed in accordance with the provisions of the Civil Defense Act, R.S., 29:601 et seq., as amended, the duties and responsibilities assigned to the office of emergency preparedness and public safety, and who shall act as the authorized agent of the chief executive, and under their general authority in all matters relating to the civil defense and emergency preparedness program and activities. 
    Public safety means all of those [measures] taken, both prior to, during or after a disaster, including operational planning for the protection of the public, their safety and welfare. 
    Regulations includes all plans, programs, executive orders, proclamations or emergency declaration which, after approval and adoption, shall have the force and effect of law. 
    Volunteer means contributing a service, equipment or facility to the civil defense emergency preparedness activity. 
(Ord. No. 401, § 1(7-3), 8-12-84) 
Sec. 4-3003. - Office of emergency preparedness and public safety-Intent and purpose. 
(a)	It is the intent and purpose of this chapter to establish jointly with the Parish of Calcasieu an office that will ensure the complete and efficient emergency preparedness, management and utilization of all of the city and parish facilities, manpower and equipment, for the protection of the public, their safety and health during an emergency, either manmade, natural, or as the result of any other catastrophic event, including the loss or spill of any hazardous material, and for the protection of persons and property in the event of any disaster as defined herein. Such office shall be referred to as the office of emergency preparedness and public safety. 
(b)	The office of emergency preparedness and public safety shall be the coordinating agency for all programs and activities in connection with civil defense, emergency preparedness or emergency management; it shall be the instrument through which the mayor of the city and the president of the Calcasieu Parish Police Jury may exercise the authority and discharge the responsibilities vested in them under the hereinabove recited provisions of law and under this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 401, § 1(7-2), 8-12-84) 
Sec. 4-3004. - Same-Organization and appointments. 
    The organization shall consist of the following: 
(1)	The office of emergency preparedness and public safety shall jointly administer the civil defense and emergency preparedness program of the City of Westlake and the Parish of Calcasieu. Such office shall be the coordinating office for all civil defense and emergency preparedness programs and activities, including planning, essential emergency disaster operations, operational staffing of the emergency operations center and its communications center, training, exercises and drills, and essential coordination with the Federal Emergency Management Agency and the state office of emergency management. 
(2)	The office of emergency preparedness and public safety shall have a coordinator or emergency manager who shall be appointed pursuant to the provisions of the Louisiana Civil Defense Law, R.S., 29:601, as amended, who shall have the direct responsibility, under the general direction and control of the chief executive and the governing authority of the city and the Calcasieu Parish Police Jury under the general direction and control of the governor of the state and the assistant secretary, department of public safety, office of emergency preparedness. 
(3)	The coordinator or emergency manager shall execute and enforce such rules, regulations or orders as may be made by the chief executives of the city and the Calcasieu Parish Police Jury or by the governor of Louisiana through and under the office of emergency preparedness. 
(4)	The office shall have such assistants and other employees as are deemed necessary for the proper functioning of the organization. 
(5)	The employees, equipment and facilities of all city and parish agencies, departments, boards, commissions or institutions shall be a part of and participate in civil defense and emergency preparedness programs and activities, including planning, staffing as required, disaster operations, training, exercises, drills and other activities as required. Duties assigned to the aforementioned shall be the same or similar to the duties of the agency, department or organization. 
(6)	Volunteer persons, organizations both public and private, industry and persons with specific operations or technical knowledge or expertise not normally found within local government operations, and offering services, may be accepted by the office of emergency preparedness and public safety. 
(Ord. No. 401, § 1(7-4), 8-12-84) 
Sec. 4-3005. - Emergency powers and duties. 
(a)	Chief executive: 
(1)	The mayor of the city and the president of the Calcasieu Parish Police Jury may cooperatively exercise the emergency power and authority necessary in the event of an actual or imminent disaster or emergency, to fulfill their general powers and duties under this chapter and the law of the state. The judgment of the mayor of the city, [and] the president of the Calcasieu Parish Police Jury shall be the sole criteria necessary to invoke the emergency powers provided under this chapter and other appropriate authorities. The city council and the Calcasieu Parish Police Jury may convene to perform their legislative and administrative powers as the situation demands, and shall receive reports relative to civil defense and emergency preparedness activities and operations. Nothing in this chapter shall be construed as abridging or curtailing the powers or restrictions of the city council or the Calcasieu Parish Police Jury as defined by the law of the state. 
(2)	A local disaster emergency may be declared only by the principal executive officer of the local governmental subdivision affected, i.e., the mayor or the president of the police jury. It shall not be continued or renewed for a period in excess of seven (7) days, except by the consent of the governing authority of the local governmental subdivision, either jointly or separately as the situation may warrant. Any order or proclamation declaring, continuing, or terminating a local disaster emergency shall be given prompt and general publicity and shall be filed promptly with the office of the clerk of court. 
(3)	The effect of a declaration of a local disaster emergency is to activate the response and recovery aspects of any and all local disaster emergency plans and to authorize the furnishing of aid and assistance thereunder. In addition to any other powers conferred upon the principal executive officer of the city and the president of the Calcasieu Parish Police Jury by the constitution, laws or by home rule, or plan or government, he may: 
a.	Suspend the provisions of any regulatory ordinance prescribing the procedures for the conduct of local business, or the rules or regulations of any local agency, if strict compliance with the provisions of any statute, order, rule, or regulation would in any way hinder, or delay necessary action in coping with the disaster emergency. 
b.	Utilize all available resources of the local government as reasonably necessary to cope with the local disaster emergency. 
c.	Transfer the direction, personnel, or functions of local departments and agencies or units thereof for the purpose of performing or facilitating emergency disaster services. 
d.	Subject to any applicable requirements for compensation, commandeer or utilize any private property if he finds this necessary to cope with the local disaster emergency. 
e.	Direct and compel the evacuation of all or a part of the population from any stricken or threatened area within the bounds of the local governing authority if he deems this action necessary for the preservation of life or other disaster mitigation, response and recovery. 
f.	Prescribe routes, modes of transportation, and destination in connection with the evacuation. 
g.	Control ingress and egress to and from a local disaster area, the movement of persons within the area, and the occupancy of premises therein. Such control shall include the prohibition of unauthorized travel in and through any disaster area or flooded area whereby the wake or waves caused by any vehicle or boat will or may contribute damage to homes, places of business or other facilities. 
h.	Suspend the sale, dispensing, or transportation of alcoholic beverages, firearms, explosives, and combustibles. 
i.	Declare and evoke a curfew between the hours from "sunset to sunrise" where such declaration is deemed essential to the preservation of life and property, and the safety, health and welfare of the citizenry; such curfew shall not include organized disaster emergency forces engaged in authorized disaster emergency operations such as police, fire, rescue, medical, health, civil defense forces or public works and public utility crews, i.e., telephone power, water, gas or bona fide members of the news media engaged in news gathering. 
j.	Make provisions for the availability and use of temporary emergency housing. 
(b)	Coordinator, emergency preparedness and public safety: 
(1)	The coordinator shall be a person duly appointed in accordance with the provisions of the Louisiana Civil Defense Law, as amended, and who shall have direct responsibility, under the general authority of the city council and the Calcasieu Parish Police Jury and the mayor and president of the aforementioned political subdivisions, and under the general direction and control of the governor of the state through the assistant secretary, office of emergency preparedness. Such appointment shall be approved by the city council and the Calcasieu Parish Police Jury. 
(2)	The coordinator may exercise the power and authority necessary to fulfill his duties and responsibilities under this chapter and under the laws of the state which pertain to the civil defense and emergency preparedness program, and, in addition may assume such other authority granted to him by the mayor and president of the police jury by executive order or directive. Such additional authority and responsibility shall stem from and remain with the chief executive of the aforementioned political subdivisions. 
(3)	In the event of an actual or impending disaster emergency, as defined in this chapter, the coordinator of the office is authorized to utilize the services, equipment and facilities of existing offices, agencies and departments of the city and the Calcasieu Parish Police Jury to the maximum extent practicable and the officers and personnel of all such agencies, departments and offices are directed to cooperate and extend such services and facilities to the mayor and police jury president and the coordinator upon request. 
(4)	Duties and responsibilities of the coordinator shall include, but not be limited to the following: 
a.	Organization and administration of the office of emergency preparedness and public safety. 
b.	Development and coordination of emergency preparedness plans to cope with any disaster emergency as defined in this chapter, and utilizing all of the facilities, equipment, manpower and other resources of the city and parish, volunteer disaster relief agencies, the health and medical profession, and industry for the purpose of minimizing or preventing the loss of life, injury and loss or damage to property in the event of disaster. Such plans shall be in accordance with state and federal plans and programs. 
c.	Coordinate with each agency, department and office of the local government subdivisions concerned in the development of individual operational annexes and appendices to the emergency preparedness plan that will ensure operational readiness to respond effectively to a disaster emergency. 
d.	Activation, staffing and operational readiness of the emergency operations center and its communications center, including provisions for twenty-four-hour operations when required. 
e.	Provision of necessary training and training exercises, drills and seminars, including those essential to ensure the readiness of the EOC staff to effectively direct and control the operations of their forces in the field in meeting the actual or impending threat. 
f.	Coordinate with state and federal emergency management authorities, the military, and the authorities of adjacent political subdivisions in all planning and disaster operations so as to ensure the most effective operation of the emergency operations plan and available resources. 
g.	Negotiate and conclude agreements with owners of buildings and other facilities, for the use of such buildings and facilities that meet prescribed factors, for use as public shelters. 
h.	Coordinate the recruitment of volunteer personnel to augment the regular organized forces of local government, and arrange for training of such personnel with the specific agency or department chief officer. After completion of training such personnel assigned will operate under the direction and control of the chief officer of the agency or department. 
i.	Operational readiness of the emergency operations center and emergency communications center and the staffing thereof in accordance with the approved staffing pattern. 
j.	Provision of public education through the conduct of classes and provision of informational materials on hazardous and protection measures applicable to the disaster threats as defined herein. 
(Ord. No. 401, § 1(7-5), 8-12-84) 
Sec. 4-3006. - Civil defense and emergency preparedness plan. 
(a)	The preparedness plan for emergency operations shall meet the standards and criteria for integrated emergency management in accordance with the civil defense guide and based upon the hazard/vulnerability/capability analysis conducted for the political subdivisions indicated herein, and shall conform with state and federal planning guidance. 
(b)	The preparedness plan, its annexes and appendices and attachments, shall be approved by resolution of the city council and the Calcasieu Parish Police Jury upon the recommendation of the mayor and the president of the police jury of the above cited political subdivisions. 
(c)	Upon approval, the preparedness plan, its annexes, appendices and attachments shall be considered supplementary to this chapter and shall have the effect of law whenever a disaster, as defined in this chapter, has been proclaimed. 
(d)	Each service chief and department head assigned responsibility in the preparedness plan shall be responsible for carrying out all duties and functions therein. Such responsibilities and duties shall include: 
(1)	The preparation, in coordination with the coordinator, of an operational plan for his service, agency or department, which, when approved, shall be annexed to and be a part of the basic plan. 
(2)	Organization and training of assigned agency and departmental and auxiliary or volunteers to support the operational of regular departmental personnel. 
(3)	Essential staffing of the emergency operations center and communications center upon activation of the EOC as the result of an actual or imminent disaster emergency in accordance with the approved staffing pattern in the basic plan. 
(e)	All duty assignments under the plan such as services, equipment, facilities and manpower of all agencies and departments of local government shall be utilized to the fullest extent, and it shall be the duty of all agencies and departments to perform the functions assigned by the plan and to maintain their portion of the plan in a current state of readiness. 
(f)	Amendments to the basic preparedness plan shall be submitted to the coordinator. If approved, the coordinator will submit the amendments to the mayor and the president of the police jury for appropriate action by the city council and the police jury. Such amendments shall take effect thirty (30) days from the date of approval, unless action is taken by the city council and the police jury disapproving the coordinator's submission. In the event an amendment is pending at the time a disaster is proclaimed under the provisions of this chapter, the amendment will be considered approved immediately and will remain in effect unless specifically revoked by the city council and the police jury. 
(g)	When a required competency or skill for a disaster function is not available within the city or parish government, the coordinator is authorized to seek assistance from persons outside of government. The assignment of duties, when of a supervisory nature, shall grant authority for the person so assigned to carry out such duties prior to, during, and after the occurrence of a disaster. Such services from persons outside of government may be accepted by the city and parish on a volunteer basis. Such persons shall be enrolled as civil defense volunteers in cooperation with the head of the city and parish agencies and departments affected. 
(Ord. No. 401, § 1(7-6), 8-12-84) 
Sec. 4-3007. - Mutual aid agreements. 
    Under the provisions of the authority granted by the Louisiana Civil Defense Act, as amended, the city and the Parish of Calcasieu, Louisiana, are authorized to develop mutual aid agreements for reciprocal civil defense aid and assistance in the case of disaster of extreme nature which affects two (2) or more political subdivisions. Such agreements shall include those made between adjacent parishes and between municipal subdivisions within those parishes made a part of such mutual aid agreement. 
(Ord. No. 401, § 1(7-7), 8-12-84) 
Sec. 4-3008. - Appropriations and authority to accept services, gifts, grants and loans. 
(a)	The political subdivisions creating the office of emergency preparedness and public safety as authorized herein shall have the power to make appropriations in the manner provided by law for the payment of expenses of the office herein created. Funding shall be in the amounts and in accordance with agreements between the city and the Parish of Calcasieu, Louisiana. 
(b)	When the federal or state government or any agency or officer thereof shall offer to the city or the parish, services, equipment, supplies, materials, or funds by the way of gifts, grants or loans for purpose of civil defense, the coordinator, with the consent of the city council or the police jury, may accept such offer and is authorized to receive such aid and assistance. 
(Ord. No. 401, § 1(7-8), 8-12-84) 
Sec. 4-3009. - Authority of mayor to enter into contract with police jury. 
(a)	The mayor of the city is hereby authorized to enter into a joint services agreement with the Parish of Calcasieu to finance the office of emergency preparedness and public safety, provided that said contract or any portion thereof is not contrary to this chapter or state or federal laws. 
(b)	The mayor of the city is hereby authorized to include any provision in any joint service agreement which he deems appropriate and may include provisions defining the respective rights and duties of the city and parish, the ownership of vehicles, insurance, public liability and workmen's compensation, hiring of employees, or any provision necessary to carry this chapter into effect. 
(Ord. No. 401, § 1(7-9), 8-12-84) 
Sec. 4-3010. - Violation of regulations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any of the provisions of this chapter or the regulations or plans issued pursuant to the authority contained herein, or to willfully obstruct, hinder or delay any member of the civil defense or emergency preparedness organization as defined herein in the enforcement of the provisions of this chapter or any regulation, rule, plan or proclamation issued hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 401, § 1(7-10), 8-12-84) 
Sec. 4-3011. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provisions of this chapter, or any rule or regulation promulgated hereunder, upon conviction thereof shall be punished by a fine of no less than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) and costs of prosecution, or imprisonment for not less than ten (10) days nor more than thirty (30) days, or both such fine and imprisonment, in the discretion of the court. 
(Ord. No. 401, § 1(7-11), 8-12-84) 
Sec. 4-3012. - Conflicting ordinances, orders, rules and regulations suspended. 
    At all times when the orders, rules and regulations made and promulgated pursuant to this chapter shall be in effect, they shall supersede all existing ordinances, orders, rules and regulations insofar as the latter may be inconsistent therewith. 
(Ord. No. 401, § 1(7-13), 8-12-84) 
CHAPTER 4. - MISCELLANEOUS 

Sec. 4-4001. - Glass containers in public parks. 
(a)	Prohibition. No person shall bring into any public park within the corporate limits of the City of Westlake, Louisiana, or have in his possession in any public park within the corporate limits of the City of Westlake, Louisiana, any bottle, glass container, or glass receptacle of any type. 
(b)	Evidence of violation. The possession of a bottle, glass container, or glass receptacle by any person in any public park within the corporate limits of the City of Westlake, Louisiana, shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of this section. 
(c)	Penalty. The maximum punishment for any violation of this section shall be that set forth in section 1-1008 of this Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 369, §§ 1-3, 8-12-82) 
Cross reference- Parks, recreation and cultural affairs, Part 6. 
CHAPTER 5. - HOUSE MOVING[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 425, enacted June 8, 1986, purported to amend Part 4 by adding thereto a new Ch. 4. Inasmuch as Part 4 already contained a Ch. 4, the substantive provisions of Ord. No. 425 have been included herein as a new Ch. 5, at the discretion of the editor. 

ARTICLE A. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 4-5001. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, and words shall have the following meanings: 
    Building is a structure designed, built or occupied as a shelter or roofed enclosure for persons, animals or property and used for residential, business, mercantile, storage, commercial, industrial, institutional, assembly, education or recreational purposes. 
    Building mover is any person who moves or procures an agreement to move a building over, along or across any highway, street or alley. 
(Ord. No. 425, Pt. I(1), 6-8-86) 
Sec. 4-5002. - Exceptions to chapter provisions. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to moving small builders' shanties and other similar temporary structures when the structure can be moved on normal automotive equipment and will not require the blocking of rights-of-way or interfere with the normal movement of traffic. 
(Ord. No. 425, Pt. I(10), 6-8-86) 
Sec. 4-5003. - Completion of improvement; penalty for failure to complete. 
    Any building moved pursuant to this chapter shall, upon relocation to a lot within the city be remodeled to conform to the standard building code, plumbing code, electrical code, and heating and air conditioning code of the city as from time to time adopted and amended. If any building relocated within the city fails to meet the standards mentioned in the preceding sentence within six (6) months from the date the permit is issued for moving the building, the building will be subject to condemnation procedures as necessary to effect its demolition or removal. 
(Ord. No. 425, Pt. I(8), 6-8-86) 
Sec. 4-5004. - Enforcement. 
(a)	Enforcing officers. The building official, police department, and the department of public works shall enforce and carry out the requirements of this chapter. 
(b)	Permittee liable for expense above deposit. The permittee shall be liable for any expense, damages, or costs in excess of deposited amounts or securities, and the city attorney shall prosecute an action against the permittee in a court of competent jurisdiction for the recovery of such excessive amounts. In addition to any other permit or costs, the building inspector shall require a deposit of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) prior to issuing any permit for the purpose of moving any structure or building. This deposit of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall be refunded after inspection by the building inspector to determine all sewer lines are closed and sealed. Failure by the owner to close and seal the sewerage line shall result in forfeiture of the deposit. 
(Ord. No. 466, 8-9-90) 
(c)	Original premises left unsafe. The city shall proceed to do the work necessary to leaving the original premises in a safe and sanitary condition when permittee does not comply with the requirements of this chapter, and the cost thereof shall be charged against the bond. 
(Ord. No. 425, Pt. I(11), 6-8-86; Ord. No. 466, 8-9-90) 
Sec. 4-5005. - Penalty. 
    Unless otherwise specified herein, any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter shall, on conviction, be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned for not more than thirty (30) days, or both, at the discretion of the judge. 
(Ord. No. 425, Pt. I(12), 6-8-86) 
Secs. 4-5006-4-5020. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE B. - BUILDING MOVER'S LICENSE 

Sec. 4-5021. - Licensing committee.
