(a)	Created; composition. There shall be and there is organized hereunder and constituted a building movers licensing committee which shall consist of the following members: 
(1)	The building official or his duly authorized representative who shall be ex officio chairman of such board. 
(2)	The traffic supervisor of the city police department or his duly authorized representative. 
(3)	Two (2) licensed house movers appointed by the mayor for a period of one (1) year, such terms to begin on January 1 and end on December 31 of each year. 
(4)	Two (2) authorized representatives of a utility company doing business in the city for one (1) year. 
(b)	Powers and duties. The powers of this committee are as follows: 
(1)	Determine the eligibility of all new applicants for house moving licenses. 
(2)	Conduct hearings on violations of the house moving code. 
(3)	Suspend, revoke or reinstate licenses of house movers. 
(c)	Meetings: 
(1)	Meetings of the committee shall be held at the call of the chairman, and at such other times as the committee may determine. 
(2)	Such chairman, or, in in his absence, the acting chairman, may administer oaths and compel the attendance of witnesses. All meetings of the committee shall be open to the public. 
(3)	The committee shall keep minutes of its proceedings, showing the vote of each member upon each question, or if absent or failing to vote, indicating such fact and shall keep records of its examinations and other official actions, all of which shall be immediately filed in the office of the committee and shall be public records. 
(4)	The concurring vote of three (3) members of the committee shall be necessary to decide on any matter it is required to pass under this chapter or to effect any variation. 
(Ord. No. 425, Pt. III, 6-8-86) 
Sec. 4-5022. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful to engage in business as a building mover, as defined by this chapter, without first having filed an application with and having secured a license from the building official. 
(Ord. No. 425, Pt. II(1), 6-8-86) 
Sec. 4-5023. - Qualifications of licensees. 
    The building official shall issue licenses only to those applicants who otherwise meet the qualifications prescribed herein and who: 
(1)	Have had at least two (2) years' experience as a building mover either in his own business or in the employment of another reputable building mover; provided that those persons who are engaged in such business on February 9, 1966, are exempted from this requirement. For the purpose of this section, the term "engaged in such business" shall mean a building mover who, prior to February 9, 1966, actually moved a building pursuant to a permit issued by the building official and completed such move in compliance with regulations then in effect. 
(2)	Are of good character. 
(3)	Whose equipment satisfactorily passes the inspection required by the state. 
(Ord. No. 425, Pt. I(2), 6-8-86) 
Sec. 4-5024. - Application. 
    Each person who is required to obtain a license under the provisions of this chapter shall make application in writing to the building official on forms provided by him. The application shall be signed by the applicant under oath and shall contain the following information, together with such additional information as may be necessary for the building official to pass upon sufficiency of the application: 
(1)	If an individual contractor: 
a.	The full name, sex, and age of the applicant. 
b.	Residence address at the time of application. 
c.	The name under which the business is to be conducted. 
d.	Location of place of business for which license is sought. 
e.	The experience the applicant has had in the business of moving buildings. 
(2)	If the applicant is a partnership, the information required by subsection (1) for the partner who is to direct the work of the firm. 
(3)	If the applicant is a corporation: 
a.	Full and accurate name. 
b.	Date and state of incorporation. 
c.	The information required by subsection (1) for the active member or employee of the corporation who is to direct the work of the firm. 
(4)	The class, type, make, manufacturer, motor and serial numbers, design, and size of each and every vehicle owned and to be used by applicant. 
(Ord. No. 425, Pt. II(2), 6-8-86) 
Sec. 4-5025. - Liability insurance and bond. 
(a)	Every licensed applicant shall secure liability insurance covering all of his working operations, including loading and unloading buildings upon vehicles, in minimum amounts of two hundred fifty thousand dollars ($250,000.00) each person, five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) each accident, and two hundred fifty thousand dollars ($250,000.00) property damage; and automobile liability insurance in minimum amounts of two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00) each person, four hundred thousand dollars ($400,000.00) each accident, and one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) property damage covering all vehicles used in the business. Certificates of liability insurance in insurance companies authorized to do business in the state shall be delivered to the building official, and each policy shall, by its terms, provide for notice of cancellation to be forwarded to the building official, and in the event the licensed building mover fails to provide another policy of liability insurance prior to such cancellation, then his license shall be automatically suspended as of the date the insurance policy ceases to be effective. Suspension as provided in this section shall be automatic and effective without notice or hearing as otherwise required by this chapter. 
(b)	Every licensed house mover shall submit proof of workman's compensation with the state and file their insurance binders with the inspection division. 
(c)	Applicant shall furnish a solvent bond of three thousand dollars ($3,000.00) executed by a corporate surety company authorized to do business in the state in favor of the city to indemnify such city and any persons for whom the applicant for house moving license [worked,] for damages sustained in issuance of house moving permits to do work with this Code and other requirements of the city. This bond shall remain in effect until the lot where the house is located and foundation are inspected. 
(d)	Rental of motor vehicles used while the house mover is doing a job shall be insured. 
(e)	Insurance and bond shall be approved by the city attorney and kept on file at the inspection division. 
(Ord. No. 425, Pt. II(3), 6-8-86) 
Sec. 4-5026. - Fees. 
    Prior to receipt of any license, the applicant shall pay a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00). Persons securing licenses after June thirtieth of any year shall pay a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). All such licenses shall expire on December 31 of the year in which issued and must be renewed on or before January 31 of the following year. The annual fee shall be the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(Ord. No. 425, Pt. I(3), 6-8-86) 
Sec. 4-5027. - Assignment or transfer prohibited. 
    No license issued hereunder shall be transferred or assigned to any other person. 
(Ord. No. 425, Pt. I(4), 6-8-86) 
Sec. 4-5028. - Equipment. 
    All motor vehicles used by house moving companies shall be inspected by a Louisiana licensed inspection station [and meet the following specifications:] 
(1)	Have a current license plate and inspection sticker. 
(2)	Vehicles shall have signs on the doors giving the name of the company and phone number (this includes rental vehicles). 
(3)	All trailers shall have a current license plate and inspection certificate from the state. 
(4)	All equipment shall be listed on the application for license. 
(5)	Insurance and bond shall be approved by the city attorney and kept on file at the inspection division. 
(Ord. No. 425, Pt. II(4), 6-8-86) 
Sec. 4-5029. - Suspension and revocation. 
(a)	Grounds. Any license issued under this part may be revoked or suspended by the licensing committee for any of the following reasons: 
(1)	Repeated violations of the regulations governing moving of buildings. 
(2)	Failure or refusal to promptly correct installations made in an incompetent or improper manner, or in violation of the building code, after having been instructed to do so by the building officials. 
(b)	Hearing required. Except as provided by section 4-5025, no license shall be suspended or revoked unless the licensee has first been granted a hearing before the house moving licensing committee. The licensee shall be given ten (10) days' written notice of the hearing. The notice shall set forth the cause or causes for the hearing, and may be delivered to the licensee by registered mail addressed to him at the address shown on his application, or may be personally served upon him by the building official or any employee of his office. 
(c)	Suspension: 
(1)	Any suspension imposed shall be for an indeterminate period not to exceed six (6) months, and shall remain in effect until all defects, deficiencies and work not complying with the standards have been corrected by the licensee. After such corrections have been made, the licensee may apply to the building official in writing for reinstatement of his license. Within five (5) days after the receipt of such request, the building official shall cause the necessary inspection to be made, and if all requirements of this part have been met, shall order the reinstatement of the license. 
(2)	If a licensee fails to correct all improper work within six (6) months after suspension of his license, the building official shall, after another notice and hearing, revoke the license. 
(d)	Revocation. No person whose license has been revoked shall again be licensed for a period of one (1) year from the date of such revocation. 
(Ord. No. 425, Pt. II(5), 6-8-86) 
Secs. 4-5030-4-5040. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE C. - PERMITS 

Sec. 4-5041. - Permit required; issued only to licensed movers. 
    No person shall move any building over, along or across any highway, street or alley without first obtaining a permit from the building official. Permits shall be issued only to licensed building movers. The building official or his designated representative shall inspect all buildings prior to moving same into or within the city. The building official may refuse to issue a permit for the moving of any building which, in his opinion, is likely to cause serious bodily injury or harm to any person, or serious property damage to any public streets or improvements, or if the cost of repairs [to the] building in order to comply with the building, plumbing, electrical and heating and air conditioning codes of the city exceeds seventy-five (75) percent of the then physical value of the building. No permit will be issued to move a building which has been condemned by the council to be relocated to another site within the city. 
(Ord. No. 425, Pt. I(5), 6-8-86) 
Sec. 4-5042. - Application. 
(a)	Filing. A person seeking issuance of a permit under this article shall file an application for such permit with the building official. 
(b)	Form. The application shall be made in writing, upon forms provided by the building official, and shall be filed in the office of the building official. 
(c)	Contents. The application shall set forth: 
(1)	A description of the building proposed to be moved, giving street number, construction materials, dimensions, number of rooms, condition of exterior and interior, size of rooms, windows and doors. 
(2)	A legal description of the lot from which the building is to be moved, giving the lot, block and tract number, if applicable. 
(3)	A legal description of the lot to which such building is to be relocated, giving the lot, block and tract number, if applicable. 
(4)	A plot plan of the site the building is to be relocated to within the city, showing the exact portion of such lot to be occupied by the building when moved. 
(5)	A foundation plan as required by the building official. 
(6)	A detailed wall section as required by the building official. 
(7)	The highways, streets, and alleys over, along, or across which the building is proposed to be moved. 
(8)	Proposed moving date and hours. 
(9)	Signatures of representatives from fire alarm, telephone, cable TV, electric, street light, and other utility companies or governmental agencies indicating that clearance is sufficient for passage of the intended move. 
(10)	Any additional information which the building official shall find necessary to a fair determination of whether a permit should be issued. 
(11)	The owner or applicant shall also state the name of the contractor or person to be responsible for such moving and shall furnish evidence that such contractor or person, firm or corporation is properly licensed by the city, that all occupational license taxes due the city have been paid. 
(12)	Prior to relocation of any building, the building mover shall submit a certificate signed by a licensed pest control operator certifying that the structure has, within thirty (30) days of the date of the certificate, been treated by him for the control and eradication of vermin, rodents and household insects according to the standards of the state structural pest control commission. 
(13)	After the permit is issued and relocation begins, the building mover shall continuously and without interruption work at moving the building until it reaches the destination shown in the permit. A building mover's failure to comply herewith shall, in addition to the penalties otherwise provided, be a cause for suspension or revocation of the license. 
(d)	Fees. The application shall be accompanied by a permit fee as follows: 
(1)	For a permit for the relocation of a building or structure to a new location on the same lot, or to an adjacent lot, where the use of public streets and roads is not required, there shall be charged a fee of ten dollars ($10.00) for each building or structure so moved. 
(2)	a.	For a permit for the relocation of a building or structure to another lot, where the use of public streets or roads is required, there shall be charged a fee of thirty-five dollars ($35.00) per day minimum in transit from starting location to final location. 
b.	A foundation permit fee of ten dollars ($10.00) will be charged in addition to the fee required in subsection (d)(2)a., above. 
(3)	Inspection fees as determined by the building official, such fees to be based on an hourly charge of eleven dollars ($11.00) per hour per inspector, plus twenty-four cents ($0.24) a mile. 
(4)	Applications for permits for relocation of buildings shall be accompanied by the amount of the permit fee. 
(Ord. No. 425, Pt. I(6), 6-8-86) 
Sec. 4-5043. - Prerequisites to issuance. 
(a)	No permit for moving any building shall be issued by the inspection division until the application containing the information above set forth has been submitted to the director of public works, and approved by him as not likely to cause damage to the public ways, and further submitted to and approved by such other law enforcement and public safety agencies as the director of public works may deem appropriate or necessary under the circumstances, 
(b)	Except as otherwise provided herein, no permit shall be issued to move any building over any part of a public way where such building exceeds thirty (30) feet in width, fifty feet (50) in length, or nineteen (19) feet in height; the height to be measured from the junction of the moving conveyance with the ground to the highest point of the house or building to be moved; provided, however, that the director of the department of public works may increase such limits if an inspection of the building and the route to be used indicates that such increase will not result in creating a traffic hazard or damage to utilities or other properties. 
(c)	No permit shall be issued until the building official responsible for issuing said permits has been notified by fire alarm, telephone, cable TV, electric light and/or power, street light or other utility company or officials that the route has sufficient clearance to allow passage of the intended move. 
    In order to accomplish the above, it will be required that the house mover or a designated representative accompany the utility representative along the entire route of the intended move or provide a sketch that will clearly reflect the route of the intended move. 
(d)	If a utility company is required to move or adjust a plant to allow for passage of the building being moved, the cost will be estimated by the utility company person or agency involved and presented to the house mover. These costs will be paid prior to the issuance of the permit. Adequate time must be allowed for the utility company to schedule and complete their work. A minimum of three (3) days must be given prior to the date of the intended move. 
(e)	No trees or branches thereof shall be cut or trimmed for the purpose of moving any building except with the written consent of the owner of the property on which such tree is located, or the director of public works where such tree is located on public property. 
(f)	Structures of eighteen (18) feet or over will require escorts, or adjustments may be charged for by the utility company involved at that utility company's discretion. 
(Ord. No. 425, Pt. I(7), 6-8-86) 
Sec. 4-5044. - Duties of inspection division. 
(a)	Inspection. The chief of the inspection division shall inspect the building and the applicant's equipment to determine whether the standards for issuance of a permit are met. It shall be the duty of the chief of the inspection division to have an inspection made of the sidewalk and curb of the present location of the building before such moving operations are commenced, and to make an additional inspection of both locations after such moving operations are completed, and if damage has resulted to the sidewalk, curb or street, a report of such damage shall be made to the director of public works. The director of public works shall make demand upon the moving contractor that such damage be repaired, and in the event such damage is not immediately repaired, the director is authorized to make the necessary repairs and charge the costs thereof to the bond required by section 4-5025. 
(b)	Standards for issuance. The inspection division shall refuse to issue a permit on the following grounds: 
(1)	That any application requirement or any fee or deposit requirement has not been complied with. 
(2)	The approval of the director of public works has not been previously secured or if for any reason such approval is withheld. 
(3)	That the building is too large to move without endangering persons or property in the city. 
(4)	That the building is in such a state of deterioration or disrepair or is otherwise so structurally unsafe that it could not be moved without endangering persons and property in the city. 
(5)	That the building is structurally unsafe or unfit for the purpose for which moved, if the removal location is in the city. 
(6)	That the applicant's equipment is unsafe and that persons and property would be endangered by its use. 
(7)	That zoning, fire prevention, or other ordinances would be violated by the building in its new location. 
(8)	That for any other reason, persons or property in the city would be endangered by the moving of the building, including property. 
(9)	That the structure proposed upon the new site does not meet the requirements of the building, plumbing, and electrical codes and other regulations applicable thereto. 
(10)	That the utility companies have not inspected the proposed route, have not arranged, rearranged, or adjusted their facilities or have not received payment for the proposed work. 
(11)	If the application for the permit does not have the signatures of representatives from fire alarm, telephone, cable TV, electric, street light, or other utilities that may be involved. 
(c)	Fees and deposit: 
(1)	Deposit. The inspection division shall deposit all fees and deposits and all bonds and insurance policies within their department. 
(2)	Return upon nonissuance. Upon refusal to issue a permit, the inspection division shall return to the applicant all deposits, bonds, and insurance policies. Permit fees filed with the application shall not be returned. 
(d)	Designated streets. Before giving approval required by him, the director of the department of public works shall act to assure maximum safety to persons and property in the city and to minimize congestion and traffic hazards on public streets. 
(e)	Notification to emergency organizations. Where the use of public streets or roads is required for the relocation of a building or structure, the police escort shall notify the fire alarm headquarters and the fire protection district, such notification to include the route and time of the move. 
(Ord. No. 425, Pt. I(9), 6-8-86) 
Sec. 4-5045. - Duties of permittee. 
    Every permittee under this chapter shall: 
(1)	Use designated streets. Move a building only over streets designated for such use in the written permit. 
(2)	Notify of desired moving time. Notify the inspection division in writing of a desired change in moving date and hours as proposed in the application. 
(3)	Notify of damage. Notify the inspection division in writing of any and all damage done to property belonging to the city within twenty-four (24) hours after the damage or injury has occurred. 
(4)	Display lights. Red lights are to be displayed during the night hours on every side of the building, while standing on a street, in such manner as to warn the public of the obstruction, and shall at all times erect and maintain barricades across the streets and street rights-of-way in such a manner as to protect the public from damage or injury by reason of the removal of the building. 
(5)	Comply with governing law. Comply with the building code, the zoning ordinances and all other applicable ordinances and laws upon relocating the building in the city. 
(6)	Clear old premises. Remove all rubbish and materials and fill all excavations to existing grade at the original building site so that the premises are left in a safe and sanitary condition unless the owner is putting up a cash bond for responsibility. The bond is to be set by the building official. 
(7)	Remove service connections. See that the sewer line is plugged, gas and water shut off. Permittee shall notify the telephone, cable TV, gas, and electric service companied to remove their services. 
(8)	Pay the expenses of officers. Pay the expense of any officer required by the chief of the inspection division to accompany the movement of the building to protect the public from injury. The contractor shall pay the police officers to be assigned at the rate of ten dollars ($10.00) per hour for each hour that said services are rendered, with a minimum of forty dollars ($40.00) to be charged where four (4) hours or less are involved. 
(Ord. No. 425, Pt. I(9A), 6-8-86) 
CHAPTER 6. - SALE OF TOBACCO AND TOBACCO PRODUCTS 

Sec. 4-6001. - Findings, declaration and purpose. 
(a)	The city hereby finds and declares that: 
(1)	Cigarette smoking is dangerous to human health; 
(2)	There exists substantial scientific evidence that the use of tobacco and tobacco products causes cancer, heart disease and various disorders; 
(3)	The Director of the National Institute on Drug Abuse has concluded that the majority of the three hundred fifty thousand (350,000) Americans who die each year from cigarette smoking "became addicted to nicotine as adolescents before the age of legal consent;" 
(4)	Smokeless tobacco is a potential source of nicotine addiction; 
(5)	Smokeless tobacco provides a highly concentrated source of nicotine, which is a potential cardiovascular and gastrointestinal stimulant and may produce adverse cardiovascular and gastrointestinal effects; and 
(6)	Smokeless tobacco products are directly associated with increased risk for oral cavity carcinomas. 
(b)	It is therefore the purpose of this chapter to prohibit the sale of tobacco and tobacco products to, and the purchase of tobacco or tobacco products by, individuals under eighteen (18) years of age, and to provide for the enforcement of laws to restrict access to tobacco and tobacco products by individuals under eighteen (18) years of age. 
(Ord. No. 482, 7-11-91) 
Sec. 4-6002. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this chapter: 
    Person shall mean any natural person or any firm, partnership, company, corporation or other entity; 
    Smokeless tobacco product shall mean any substance containing finely cut, ground, who shredded, powdered or leaf tobacco that is intended to be placed in the oral or nasal cavity, including use or consumption of such substance by chewing, dipping, snuffing or holding in the mouth; 
    Tobacco, cigarette or other tobacco product shall include, but not be limited to, cigarettes, cigars, pipes, any other smoking equipment, and smokeless tobacco products; 
    Vending machine shall mean any automated, self-service device which, upon insertion of money, tokens or other form of payment, dispenses tobacco, cigarettes or other tobacco products. 
(Ord. No. 482, 7-11-91) 
Sec. 4-6003. - Furnishing to under age persons. 
    It shall be unlawful to sell, give or furnish tobacco, cigarettes or other tobacco products to individuals under the age of eighteen (18) years. 
(Ord. No. 482, 7-11-91) 
Sec. 4-6004. - Unlawful purchase. 
    It shall be unlawful for individuals under the age of eighteen (18) years to purchase tobacco, cigarettes, or other tobacco products. It shall further be unlawful for individuals under the age of eighteen (18) years to misrepresent their identity or age or use any false identification for the purpose of purchasing any tobacco, cigarette or other tobacco product. 
(Ord. No. 482, 7-11-91) 
Sec. 4-6005. - Use in public school facilities prohibited; exception. 
    The use of tobacco, cigarettes or other tobacco products in enclosed areas, buildings, or facilities of a public elementary or secondary school is hereby prohibited, except in designated areas authorized by school principals for employees over the age of eighteen (18) years of said public elementary or secondary school. 
(Ord. No. 482, 7-11-91) 
Sec. 4-6006. - Vending machine sales. 
    It shall be unlawful for tobacco, cigarettes or other tobacco products to be sold in a vending machine in the city. 
(Ord. No. 482, 7-11-91) 
Sec. 4-6007. - Identification of purchaser required, when. 
    Any person who engages in the sale of tobacco, cigarettes or other tobacco products having reasonable cause to believe that an individual attempting to purchase such product is under the age of eighteen (18) years shall demand that such purchaser present some form of identification clearly indicating his or her age. 
(Ord. No. 482, 7-11-91) 
Sec. 4-6008. - Compliance monitoring. 
    It shall not be considered "entrapment" or any other violation of the law for law enforcement authorities to use an individual under the age of eighteen (18) years to attempt to purchase tobacco, cigarettes or other tobacco products for the purpose of monitoring compliance with this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 482, 7-11-91) 
Sec. 4-6009. - Violations; penalties. 
    Any person violating this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished by a fine of not more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), or by imprisonment for not more than thirty (30) days, or both. Any subsequent offenses shall subject such persons violating this act to a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or by imprisonment for not more than ninety (90) days, or both. In addition, a license to sell tobacco, cigarettes or other tobacco products may be suspended for a first or second offense involving a violation of this act, and may be revoked for a third or subsequent offense involving a violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 482, 7-11-91) 
CHAPTER 7. - AMBULANCES 

Sec. 4-7001. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms, phrases and words shall have the following meanings: 
    Emergency ambulance. An "emergency ambulance" shall mean any ambulance designed for emergency care which provides a driver compartment and a patient compartment. Such ambulance shall carry equipment and supplies for optimal emergency care at the scene, as well as during transit, and shall be designed and constructed to afford maximum safety and comfort and to avoid aggravation of the patient's condition, exposure to complications, and threat to survival. Ambulance shall meet the minimal federal specifications as outlined in documents KKK-1822A or KKK-1822B. 
    Owner-operator. "Owner" or "operator" means any person who owns or controls an ambulance. 
    Driver. "Driver" means any person who drives an ambulance. 
    Person. "Person" includes any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. 
    Health officer. "Health officer" means the person who is duly appointed by the mayor and approved by the city council. 
    Attendant. "Attendant" means an employee of owner/operator who accompanies the patient in the patient compartment while transporting any patient. 
    Non-emergency ambulance. A "non-emergency ambulance" is any motor vehicle constructed, reconstructed, arranged, equipped or used for the purpose of transporting ill, sick or injured persons under other than emergency conditions, i.e., when the element of time in transporting the patient is not essential to said patient's health or life. 
    City clerk. City clerk is the duly appointed city clerk of the City of Westlake. 
(Ord. No. 535, § 1, 11-10-94) 
Sec. 4-7002. - License required for owner/operator. 
(a)	No owner or operator of an ambulance shall permit it to be used or operated upon the streets or roads of the city without first obtaining a permit therefor from the city clerk. 
(b)	The mayor is hereby given authority to promulgate such reasonable rules and regulations as may be necessary to enforce the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 535, § 2, 11-10-94) 
Sec. 4-7003. - Applications for licenses. 
    An application for a license to own or operate said ambulance(s) shall be made to the city clerk upon forms prescribed by him, and shall include: 
(1)	The name and address of the owner or operator of the ambulance. 
(2)	A description of the ambulance, including the make, model, year of manufacture, Louisiana license number, the current year, motor and chassis numbers, and a statement regarding the length of time the vehicle has been in use. 
(3)	The location and description of the place or places from which it is intended to operate said ambulance(s). 
(4)	Such other information as the city clerk shall find reasonably necessary to a fair determination of whether the provisions of this chapter have been complied with. 
(Ord. No. 535, § 3, 11-10-94) 
Sec. 4-7004. - Qualifications for license. 
    In determining whether a license shall be issued, the city clerk shall give weight and due regard, among other things, to: 
(1)	The probable permanence and quality of the service offered by the applicant, to include, among other things, proof of financial responsibility and the establishment and maintenance of the bona fide office from which the service is offered. 
(2)	The experience the applicant has had in rendering services in the city, the past experience of the applicant in prompt adjustment of claims and in payment of judgments, if any, arising out of the operation of such ambulance(s). 
(3)	The financial ability of the applicant to respond in damages. 
(4)	That insurance as required by this chapter has been secured. 
(5)	The character and condition of the ambulance(s) to be used, determined after inspection as required by this chapter. 
(6)	That all requirements of this chapter and all other applicable laws and ordinances have been complied with. 
(7)	That the public convenience and necessity require the proposed additional ambulance service. 
(Ord. No. 535, § 4, 11-10-94) 
Sec. 4-7005. - Insurance required. 
(a)	Before any license is issued hereunder, the applicant must file with the city clerk a policy of public liability insurance issued by an insurance company qualified to do business in the State of Louisiana, which shall contain the following conditions and stipulations and shall be approved as to form by the city attorney: 
(1)	The term of such insurance policy shall be for a period of not less than one (1) year. 
(2)	The insurance policy shall provide not less than the following limits of liability: for each accident causing bodily injury (including death, if any, resulting therefrom) one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) each person; three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) each accident; and fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) property damage sustained in any one (1) accident. 
(3)	Such policy shall by its terms provide that it may not be canceled except after ten (10) days' written notice thereof to the city clerk. 
(b)	Any owner or operator who fails to secure another policy of liability insurance prior to cancellation of any existing policy shall automatically and without notice or hearing suffer suspension of his license until such time as such insurance policy has been filed with the city clerk. 
(c)	Any persons operating an ambulance without having such liability insurance in force shall be guilty of a violation of this chapter and shall be punished as hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. No. 535, § 5, 11-10-94) 
Sec. 4-7006. - Inspection of ambulance. 
(a)	Before any license shall be issued hereunder, all of the ambulances listed in the application shall be inspected by the city police and shall be certified to be in proper mechanical condition. At the same time, each ambulance will be inspected by the city inspector or his designee and shall be certified to be equipped in compliance with section 4-7001 of this chapter. 
(b)	Each ambulance which is licensed shall be inspected by the city police once each year during the month of January. At the same time, each ambulance will be inspected by a person designated by the mayor and shall be certified to be equipped in compliance with section 4-7016 of this chapter. 
(c)	After each such inspection, registration tags shall be issued for those vehicles which are mechanically fit. 
(d)	Each owner or operator shall pay to the city clerk a fee of ten dollars ($10.00) annually for each vehicle to be inspected, said fee to be payable by January 1 of each year. 
(e)	Any person who operates an ambulance without having obtained the mechanical inspection certificate and tag required shall be guilty of a violation of this chapter and shall be punished as hereinafter provided. 
(f)	The owner or operator of any ambulance whose ambulance has a mechanical defect shall be given seven (7) days in which to have it repaired. After the expiration of said seven-day period, the make, registration and license number of each ambulance remaining uncertified shall be given to the city police. 
(Ord. No. 535, § 6, 11-10-94) 
Sec. 4-7007. - Driver's license required. 
(a)	No person shall drive an ambulance upon the streets or roads of the city, and no person who owns or controls an ambulance shall permit it to be so driven, unless the driver shall have then in force a driver's license issued under the provisions of this chapter. 
(b)	An application for a driver's license shall be made to the city clerk upon forms prescribed by him. 
(Ord. No. 535, § 7, 11-10-94) 
Sec. 4-7008. - Qualifications for driver's license. 
    Each applicant for a driver's license shall certify that he meets the following qualifications: 
(1)	He is a person over eighteen (18) years of age. 
(2)	He has a current motor vehicle chauffeur's license issued by the State of Louisiana. 
(3)	He possesses a current certificate of qualification in advanced first aid issued by the American Red Cross or the Bureau of Mines of the United States, or he possesses a current qualification of a "First Responder" course. Any new employee who does not possess the certificate of qualification hereby required may be temporarily employed, but must obtain such certificate within ninety (90) days after employment. 
(4)	He has never been convicted anywhere under the laws of this state, or of any other state, or of the United States, or this parish or any other parish or county of the offense of murder, aggravated battery, aggravated rape, simple rape, aggravated burglary, simply burglary, aggravated kidnapping, simple kidnapping, armed robbery, simple robbery, pandering, prostitution, soliciting for prostitutes, illegal possession or sale or use of narcotics, contributing to the delinquency of a juvenile, indecent behavior with a juvenile, and that he has not been convicted two (2) or more times of any traffic offense during the year preceding the filing of the application. 
(5)	He has not been convicted of any other felony, or of any misdemeanor involving moral turpitude against the criminal laws of this state or of any other state, or of the United States, within five (5) years, and has not served any part of a sentence therefor within five (5) years before the date of the filing of said application, and that he is not presently charged therewith, or with any of the felonies, offenses or misdemeanors set forth in subsection (d) of this section, or with violating any of the provisions of this chapter. 
(6)	He is not addicted to the use of intoxicating liquor, does not use any narcotic drugs, and is not suffering from any disease or infirmity which might make him an unsafe or unsatisfactory driver. 
(7)	He does not have a bad driving record. His driving record cannot contain more than three (3) moving traffic violations nor can it contain a DWI or reckless driving offense. 
(Ord. No. 535, § 8, 11-10-94) 
Sec. 4-7009. - Certificate of physician. 
    Each application shall be accompanied by a certificate from a reputable physician of the Parish of Calcasieu, certifying that he has examined the applicant within ninety (90) days, and that, in his opinion, the applicant is not addicted to the use of intoxicating liquors, does not use any narcotic drugs, and is not suffering from any disease or infirmity which might make him an unsafe or unsatisfactory driver. 
(Ord. No. 535, § 9, 11-10-94) 
Sec. 4-7010. - Fee for annual driver's license. 
(a)	Each applicant for a driver's license hereunder shall pay a fee of ten dollars ($10.00) to the city clerk. 
(b)	Said licenses shall be issued yearly and not later than the fifteenth day of February of each year, and no driver shall be permitted to operate an ambulance without having in his possession a valid license for the current year. 
(c)	Each driver's license in good standing shall be renewable on or before its expiration upon application and payment of the required fee, provided that no such license may be renewed unless the applicant meets the requirements of section 4-7009 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 535, § 10, 11-10-94) 
Sec. 4-7011. - Investigation for driver's license. 
(a)	The city police shall conduct an investigation of each applicant for a driver's license, and each applicant shall submit himself to being photographed and fingerprinted. 
(b)	A report of the investigation by the city police and a copy of the traffic and police record of the applicant shall be attached to the application and kept on file in the office of city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 535, § 11, 11-10-94) 
Sec. 4-7012. - Issuance of driver's license. 
    Upon approval of an application for a driver's license, the city clerk shall issue a license to the applicant which shall bear the name, address, age, signature, level of training and photograph of the applicant, and be signed by the mayor. Said license shall be worn and displayed on said licensee for public view at all times when in the performance of his duties. 
(Ord. No. 535, § 12, 11-10-94) 
Sec. 4-7013. - Denial, suspension or revocation of license for owner or operator and driver's license. 
(a)	The city clerk may deny any applicant's license whenever in the exercise of his reasonable and sound discretion, and after notice and affording the applicant a hearing thereon, he shall determine that said applicant is not a fit and proper person to have such license and/or the applicant has not met the requirements of this chapter. The applicant may appeal within ten (10) days from such denial to the mayor for a hearing in connection therewith, which hearing may be held public or private at the request of the applicant. This hearing shall be held not less than ten (10) nor more than thirty (30) days after the filing of the appeal. The decision of the mayor shall be final. 
(b)	Every owner or operator and every driver licensed under this chapter shall comply with all city, state and federal laws. Failure to do so will justify the suspension or revocation of said license by the city clerk. 
(c)	The city clerk is hereby given authority to suspend any license issued under this chapter for failure or refusal to comply with the provisions of this chapter, such suspension to last for a period of not more than thirty (30) days. The city clerk is also given authority to revoke any license for failure to comply with the provisions of this chapter. However, the license may not be suspended or revoked unless the holder has received notice and has had an opportunity to present evidence in his behalf. Further, the applicant may appeal such suspension or revocation within ten (10) days therefrom to the mayor, who shall schedule a hearing as hereinabove set forth in subsection (a) of this section, and the decision of the mayor shall be final. 
(d)	Whenever a person who shall have been issued a license under this chapter shall be charged in any court with a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude, or with any felony, or with violation of this chapter, the city clerk is hereby given authority to suspend the license pending final disposition of the charges against him, and to revoke same upon conviction thereof. 
(Ord. No. 535, § 13, 11-10-94) 
Sec. 4-7014. - Unlicensed drivers. 
    If any person not licensed under this chapter is found driving any ambulance, the city clerk may immediately take the necessary action to revoke the license held by the owner or operator, until such time as action is taken by the owner or operator to rectify same. 
(Ord. No. 535, § 14, 11-10-94) 
Sec. 4-7015. - Attendants. 
(a)	No person shall be permitted to serve as an ambulance attendant who does not possess a current certificate of qualification as an emergency medical technician issued by the National Registry of Emergency Medical Technicians. 
(b)	An attendant shall be present in the patient compartment while transporting any emergency or stretcher patient. 
(c)	An attendant shall meet the qualifications for an ambulance driver's license as set forth in section 4-7008 of this chapter and he shall possess said driver's license. 
(d)	All ambulances that respond to request for emergency must have a minimum of one (1) nationally registered emergency medical technician paramedic on the primary response ambulance. 
(Ord. No. 535, § 15, 11-10-94) 
Sec. 4-7016. - Standards for ambulance equipment. 
(a)	Required equipment in each emergency ambulance shall include, at all times when the ambulance is in use as such, equipment adequate in the judgment of the inspector for dressing wounds, splinting fractures, controlling hemorrhage and providing oxygen. 
(b)	The inspector is authorized and directed to promulgate regulations, after public notice and opportunity for public hearing, to implement the standards provided herein as to required equipment in emergency ambulances. In determining the adequacy of equipment, the inspector shall take into consideration the current list of minimal equipment for emergency ambulances adopted by the committee on trauma of the American College of Surgeons. Each licensee of an emergency ambulance shall comply with such reasonable regulations hereunder as may be promulgated by the inspector and shall maintain in each such ambulance, at all times when it is in use as such, all such equipment as may be prescribed by the Inspector hereunder. 
(c)	The equipment in non-emergency ambulances shall be as required by the inspector, and shall be maintained in each such ambulance at all times when it is in use as such. 
(Ord. No. 535, § 16, 11-10-94) 
Sec. 4-7017. - Fare, charge or fee for ambulance service. 
(a)	For ambulance service rendered within the City of Westlake, a fare, charge or fee may be demanded and received in accordance with rates hereinafter established. No owner or operator or driver of an ambulance shall charge a greater sum for the use of an ambulance than in accordance with Calcasieu Parish Ordinance No. 1387, as amended. 
(b)	It shall be the duty of every owner or operator of every vehicle used in ambulance service to furnish each patient with a printed itemized rate statement, when requested, which shall be in a form that has been approved by the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 535, § 17, 11-10-94) 
Sec. 4-7018. - Arrival of ambulance without call. 
    No ambulance shall respond at any time unless specifically requested to do so by the Westlake Police Department, Westlake Fire Department, Calcasieu Parish Sheriff's Office, Louisiana State Police, Calcasieu Parish Communication District (911), Mutual Aid, or the person or persons actually needing assistance. It is strictly forbidden to respond by monitoring emergency radio frequencies or to appear at the scene of an emergency without first having been requested to do so. Any ambulance which appear at the scene of an accident without having been properly summoned will be considered to be in violation of this chapter and the license of the owner or operator of said ambulance, as well as the driver's license, will be subject to revocation. In the event an ambulance arrives at the scene of an emergency situation without being summoned, such violation or occurrence shall not be reported by the law enforcement officers to the city clerk. Voice recorded conversation of said request of ambulance by person or persons actually needing assistance shall serve as documentation of said request. Recorded conversation can be requested by the mayor for review. 
(Ord. No. 535, § 18, 11-10-94) 
Sec. 4-7019. - Obedience to officers. 
    Any ambulance driver answering a call and arriving at the place where any accident or emergency has occurred shall obey all lawful orders given by any police officer investigating such accident or emergency and shall not in any manner interfere with such police officer in the performance of his duty, nor shall the ambulance interfere with the flow of traffic, provided, however that there shall be no interference with medical treatment and care of any person or persons at the scene of medical emergency. 
(Ord. No. 535, § 19, 11-10-94) 
Sec. 4-7020. - Hospitals. 
    The West Calcasieu Cameron Hospital shall be designated by the City of Westlake as the first responder for all request for ambulance within the city limits of Westlake by the Westlake Police Department, Westlake Fire Department, Calcasieu Parish Sheriff's Office, Louisiana State Police, and the Calcasieu Parish Communication District. As such, the City of Westlake agrees to provide the West Calcasieu Cameron Hospital with a location to house an ambulance. This location shall be at the fire station on Guillory Street or such other suitable location as may be agreed by the City of Westlake and the West Calcasieu Cameron Hospital. The West Calcasieu Cameron Hospital agrees to have two (2) people, one (1) of which shall be a paramedic on duty at the Westlake Fire Station to respond to emergency calls. In addition, the West Calcasieu Cameron Hospital agrees to maintain liability insurance in the amount of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) with the City of Westlake named as an additional insured. The West Calcasieu Cameron Hospital agrees to indemnify and hold the City of Westlake harmless from any and all acts or omissions which might occur as a result of its utilization of the fire station and response to emergency calls. 
(b)	To further evidence the intent of the parties, the City of Westlake and the West Calcasieu Cameron Hospital shall enter into a written agreement evidencing the full intent of the parties. 
(Ord. No. 535, § 20, 11-10-94) 
Sec. 4-7021. - Choice of care facility or hospital. 
    All ambulance service shall give the person or persons involved in the emergency situation the choice of which care facility or hospital to which they are to be taken. If the person or persons cannot make such a decision due to their physical condition, then a relative of the person or persons involved in the emergency situation shall be given the choice of which care facility or hospital the person or persons are to be taken. If there are no relatives available and the person or persons involved in the emergency situation can not make the decision, then the ambulance service shall take the person or persons to the nearest care facility or hospital which can properly administer to the needs of the individual. 
(Ord. No. 535, § 21, 11-10-94) 
Sec. 4-7022. - Penalties for violation of chapter. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall upon conviction be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or be imprisoned for not less than thirty (30) days nor more than six (6) months, or both, in the discretion of the court, for each offense. 
(Ord. No. 535, § 22, 11-10-94) 
PART 5. - PUBLIC WORKS 
CHAPTER 1. - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS 
ARTICLE A. - OBSTRUCTING STREETS AND SIDEWALKS 

Sec. 5-1001. - Assembly on streets or sidewalks. 
    No persons shall assemble or remain assembled on the streets and sidewalks in sufficient numbers or in any manner as to constitute an obstruction to free passage thereon if requested to disperse by any officer of the town. 
Sec. 5-1002. - Hardware, furniture, merchandise or other works prohibited. 
    No person, firm or corporation, or its agent shall obstruct the streets, sidewalks or alleys of the town by placing thereon any hardware, furniture, merchandise, shelving, boxes or other works that will in any manner interfere with the use of the streets, sidewalks, or alleys by the public. 
Sec. 5-1003. - Display of goods prohibited. 
    No person shall place for display or sale any goods, wares or merchandise of any kind upon any of the sidewalks of the town. 
Sec. 5-1004. - Placing or leaving objects on streets and sidewalks. 
    No brick, stone or wood or other substances obstructing the free passage of persons and vehicles shall be placed or left to lie in any of the alleys, streets, or other routes of the town, nor shall any person place on or in any of the streets, sidewalks or alleys any boxes, crates, casks, or barrels of any description, or any other obstruction of any kind. Provided that any person erecting a building, may with town permission place building material for immediate use on the streets in such a way as not to interfere with the usual traffic. 
Sec. 5-1005. - Construction near sidewalk. 
    Before building or remodeling in close proximity to the sidewalk, a passage way shall be constructed so as to leave the sidewalk unobstructed and provide safe and easy passage. 
Sec. 5-1006. - Encroachments on streets. 
    It shall be the duty of the building inspector to notify all persons about to erect any building, sidewalk, wall or fence near the street or any public way or alley not to encroach upon such street or public alley, and if in the opinion of the may or any such obstruction is being, or has been, constructed on any street or public alley, the mayor shall cause a survey of the line of the street or alley to be made by a competent surveyor. If such survey shall show that the street or alley is obstructed by any building, sidewalk, wall or fence, the owner shall be required to pay the costs of the survey and shall be required to remove all obstructions at once. Every person who shall be found to have encroached on any street or public way or alley by any such building, sidewalk, wall or fence and refuses or neglects to remove the same upon notice from the chief of police within ten (10) days from the date thereof, shall, upon conviction, be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
Sec. 5-1007. - Construction of driveways and culverts. 
    No person, firm or corporation, or its agent shall construct or install any driveway or drainage culvert within the town without first receiving approval of the construction as to size and quality by the building inspector. 
Sec. 5-1008. - Dedication of streets. 
    All streets tendered to the city for maintenance by an owner or developer shall have a minimum requirement of six (6) inches reinforced concrete roadway together with curb and gutter which shall have a minimum right-of-way of fifty (50) feet with a minimum of twenty-five (25) feet to be concrete. 
(Ord. No. 642, § 1, 3-20-00) 
Sec. 5-1009. - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person violating any provision of this article, or any condition or regulation of a permit hereunder, shall be punished as provided in section 1-1008 and be subject to having any permits previously issued revoked. Each day that a violation continues shall be considered a separate violation. 
(Ord. No. 642, § 2, 3-20-00) 
Sec. 5-1010. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE B. - USE AND CLEANLINESS OF STREETS AND SIDEWALKS 

Sec. 5-1011. - Use of nails and tacks restricted. 
    It is hereby declared unlawful for any person to drive any nails or tacks into the telephone, telegraph or electric light poles, or into any house or store situated on any sidewalks or street of the town, except with the prior permission of the owner. 
Sec. 5-1012. - Driving through street barricade. 
    No person shall drive any vehicle into or upon any alley or street that has been barricaded by an employee of the town. 
Sec. 5-1013. - Removing barricades forbidden. 
    No person, other than an employee of the town shall remove any barricade which has been erected by the town. 
Sec. 5-1014. - Burning trash. 
    It is unlawful for any person to burn any trash, garbage or substance on or in any public street, alley, park, public place or any private yard or lot within the limits of the town. 
Sec. 5-1015. - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person violating any provision of this article shall be punished as provided in section 1-1008. 
Secs. 5-1016-5-1020. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE C. - EXCAVATIONS 

Sec. 5-1021. - Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, except as provided by public utility franchises, or employees of the town in the course of their employment, to open, dig into, remove the surface from or excavate any street, sidewalk, alley, public way or place without first obtaining a permit therefor from the maintenance superintendent. 
Sec. 5-1022. - Application for permit. 
    The application for an excavation permit shall contain such information as required by the maintenance superintendent. 
Sec. 5-1023. - Regulations authorized. 
    In granting an excavation permit, reasonable regulations may be imposed including but not limited to: 
(1)	The manner of making the excavation; 
(2)	The location of the excavation; 
(3)	Protection of underground utility installations; 
(4)	The duration of the excavation; 
(5)	Required safety precautions, such as barricades, lights, warning devices, etc.; 
(6)	The extent and size of the excavation; or 
(7)	Steps to be taken to protect nearby property owners. 
Sec. 5-1024. - Assets or insurance required. 
    The applicant for an excavation permit shall submit satisfactory evidence that he has sufficient assets or insurance to indemnify the town for any costs, losses or liabilities that it may incur by reason of such excavation, and to satisfy any judgments or liabilities arising out of the excavation. 
Sec. 5-1025. - Backfilling and resurfacing. 
    It shall be the duty of the person making any excavation hereunder to fill the excavation and restore the surface to a condition at least equal to the surface prior to the excavation. If required, the person making an excavation shall furnish a bond, deposit or other security sufficient to assure compliance with this section. Provided, however, that the town may elect to fill and resurface the excavation and charge the cost thereof against the person making the excavation. 
Sec. 5-1026. - Inspections required; fee. 
    All excavations except those backfilled and resurfaced by the town shall be inspected and approved by the town before and after backfilling and before and after resurfacing. A reasonable fee for each man hour or portion thereof spent by town employees making such inspections may be charged. 
Sec. 5-1027. - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person violating any provision of this article, or any condition or regulation of a permit hereunder, shall be punished as provided in section 1-1008, and shall be subject to having his permit revoked, provided such penalty shall not relieve the person from any civil liability under the provisions of this Code. 
CHAPTER 2. - NUMBERING OF HOUSES AND BUILDINGS 

Sec. 5-2001. - Unlawful not to number. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to fail to have all houses and buildings owned by them properly display municipal numbers. 
(Ord. No. 39, 10-6-53, § 1) 
Sec. 5-2002. - Requirements for installation. 
    Numbers shall be installed in such a location as to be clearly visible to the public from the street from which the building or house faces. 
(Ord. No. 39, 10-6-53, § 2) 
Sec. 5-2003. - Assignment of numbers. 
    Municipal numbers shall be assigned to each house and building by the maintenance superintendent of the town, who is in charge of the street department. 
Sec. 5-2004. - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction therefor shall be fined in the sum not exceeding two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
PART 7. - MUNICIPAL UTILITIES 
CHAPTER 1. - WATER SUPPLY AND DISTRIBUTION 
ARTICLE A. - WATER AND SEWER DEPARTMENT 

Sec. 7-1001. - Creation; purpose. 
    A water and sewer department is created and established for the city. The department is responsible for the management, maintenance, care and operation of the water supply and distribution system of the city. 
Sec. 7-1002. - Administration. 
    Subject to the general control and direction of the mayor and council, the department shall be administered by the maintenance superintendent who shall manage the city water works and sewer system and shall perform all acts necessary for the prudent, efficient and economical management of the city water supply and distribution system and the sewage collection and treatment system. 
Secs. 7-1003-7-1010. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE B. - WATER REGULATIONS, POLICIES AND RATES 
Division 1. - In General 

Sec. 7-1011. - Turning on water. 
(a)	No water from the city water supply shall be turned on for service into any premises by any person but the superintendent or some person authorized by him to perform this service. 
(b)	Where water has been cut off or disconnected for nonpayment of a bill, temporarily disconnected at the request of a customer or for other reasons, there shall be a charge for reconnection as fixed from time to time by resolution of the mayor and council. This charge shall be paid prior to any reconnection of service. 
Sec. 7-1012. - Application. 
    Application to have water turned on shall be made in writing to the city clerk. 
Sec. 7-1013. - Deposit. 
(a)	The mayor and city council shall, by resolution, determine the amount of security deposit for water services within the municipality. The deposit shall accompany each application. If the customer maintains current payments on his water services for a period of five (5) years from date of the application, the deposit shall be returned. "Current payments" is defined as not having a balance carried forward onto the next month's statement. 
(b)	Any customer whose services have been disconnected for nonpayment shall have to pay all the outstanding charges and deposit an additional five dollars ($5.00) with the city before services can be reconnected. Whenever service to the customer is permanently discontinued, the deposit, less any charges due the city, shall be refunded. 
(Ord. No. 330, 5-22-80; Ord. No. 346, 3-12-81) 
Sec. 7-1014. - Plumbing. 
    No water shall be turned on for service in premises in which the plumbing does not comply with the Code; provided, that water may be turned on for construction work in unfinished buildings, subject to the Code. 
Sec. 7-1015. - Service installation; fee; resale; tampering. 
(a)	No connections with a sewer main shall be made without a permit being issued and twenty-four (24) hours' notice having been given to the superintendent. All connections shall be made and all work done at the expense of the applicant who shall also furnish materials necessary for the work; all connections shall be made under the supervision of the superintendent, and no connections shall be covered until the work has been inspected by him. All connections shall be to the property line. Application for connection must be made to the clerk, and a fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) shall be paid for each connection, which required a break in the roadway and a fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) shall be paid for each such connection which does not require a break in the roadway. 
(b)	No water shall be resold or distributed by the recipient thereof from the city water supply to any premises other than that for which application has been made and approved by the mayor and city council. 
(c)	It shall be unlawful for any person not authorized by the city to tamper with or alter any part of the city water works or supply system. 
(Ord. No. 455, § 1, 10-12-89; Ord. No. 458, § 1, 12-14-89) 
Sec. 7-1016. - Service pipes. 
(a)	Installation. All service pipes from the mains to the premises served shall be installed by, and at the cost of, the owner of the property to be served or the applicant for the service. The installation shall be under the inspection of the superintendent. 
(b)	Repairs. All repairs for service pipes and plumbing systems of buildings shall be made by and at the expense of the owners of the premises served. The city may, in case of an emergency, repair any service pipes and if this is done the cost of repair work shall be repaid to the city by the owner of the premises served. 
(c)	Excavations. Excavations for installing or repairing service pipes shall be made in compliance with the Code provisions relating to making excavations in streets. Provided, that it shall be unlawful to place any service pipe in the same excavation with, or directly over, any drain pipe or sewer pipe. 
Cross reference- Excavations, in streets, § 5-1021 et seq. 
Sec. 7-1017. - Uniform water rates-Generally. 
    The following uniform water rate schedule and rules and regulations be and the same are hereby adopted within the city: 
(1)	Residential Monthly Water Rate Schedule (residences, apartments, mobile homes and churches). 
a. Nonmetered Residential Rate $25.50 b. Metered Residential Rate $24.50 minimum for 2,000 gallons $3.00 per thousand or part thereof over 2,000 gallons c. Nonmetered Senior Citizen Rate $15.75 (Residential/Mobile Homes) d. Metered Senior Citizen Rate $15.75 minimum for 2,000 gallons $3.00 per thousand or part thereof over 2,000 gallons  
(2)	Commercial Monthly Water Rate Schedule: 
All businesses are billed based on the water meter consumption at a rate of $30.00 minimum for the first 8,000 gallons and $3.75 per thousand or part thereof over 8,000 gallons. 
(3)	Industrial Monthly Water Rate Schedule: 
All Industrial accounts are billed based on the water meter consumption at a rate of $46.50 minimum for the first 10,000 gallons and $4.50 per thousand or part thereof over 10,000 gallons with the charge of $1.80 per thousand from 150,000 gallons on up or part thereof. 
(4)	Water District Monthly Rate Schedule: 
All water sold to other Water Districts or Water companies will be billed based on the water meter consumption at a rate of $1.80 per thousand gallons or part thereof. 
(5)	Water Tap fees: $525.00 
Water Taps over 1.5 inches will be charged contractor price plus ten (10) percent. 
(6)	All bills will be rendered promptly to customers for water and shall be paid in accordance with Part 7, Chapter 4, Payment of utility bills. 
All rates and fees established in this chapter shall automatically increase by four (4) percent annually on July 1 st of each year beginning on July 1, 2016. 
(Ord. No. 75A, § 1, 10-1-59; Ord. No. 267, §§ 1, 2, 12-11-75; Ord. No. 382, § (a), 7-14-83; Ord. No. 443, § 1, 12-8-88; Ord. No. 555, 1-11-96; Ord. No. 625, § 1, 5-17-99; Ord. No. 648, § 1, 6-19-00; Ord. No. 670, § 1, 8-27-01; Ord. No. 829 , § 1, 12-5-11; Ord. No. 881 , § 1, 2, 1-12-15) 
Sec. 7-1017.1. - Same-For swimming pools; permit to fill or discharge water. 
(a)	All owners of pools having a capacity in excess of three thousand five hundred (3,500) gallons shall be charged twenty-five dollars ($25.00) upon each fillup of a pool, regardless if filled up annually or at any other time, which sum will be payable to the City of Westlake. 
(b)	A permit must be obtained from the building inspector prior to the filling of a swimming pool. 
(c)	Before discharging the water in a pool, the building inspector must issue a permit, at no charge, stating that there is adequate means for drainage of this water and this permit shall be good for a period of only five (5) days, and upon each drainage of a pool a new permit must be issued. 
(Ord. No. 321, §§ 1-3, 11-8-79) 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 321, enacted Nov. 8, 1979, amended § 1 of Ord. No. 278 to add provisions relative to swimming pools. At the discretion of the editor, however, §§ 1-3 of said Ord. No. 321 have been codified herein as a new § 7-1017.1, for classification and indexing purposes. 
Sec. 7-1018. - Turning off water. 
    It is unlawful for any unauthorized person to turn off any water flowing in any main or pipeline owned or operated by the city unless the person shall have first obtained the permission of the mayor and the council or its designee. 
Sec. 7-1019. - Emergency water shortage. 
    Whenever a state of emergency exists as to a water shortage, the city council shall, by written motion, declare such an emergency. The declaration of such an emergency shall authorize the mayor to issue a proclamation setting forth the reasons for the emergency and the remedies necessary to curtail the excessive use of water. Any customer violating this proclamation shall be subject to penalties in accordance with section 1-1008 of this codification. Once the emergency has ceased, the city council shall declare the emergency terminated and the mayor shall terminate the proclamation. Nothing herein is to be construed to limit the powers granted the mayor pursuant to section 2-2004 of this codification, but is in addition to those powers granted the mayor pursuant to section 2-2004. 
(Ord. No. 334, 7-15-80) 
Sec. 7-1020. - Residential prohibited water usage; definitions and penalties. 
    As used herein the term "excessive residential consumption of water" shall mean any amount of water used in excess of twenty-five thousand (25,000) gallons of water per month. The average daily consumption of eight hundred thirty-four (834) gallons of water per day shall be considered excessive if the daily consumption multiplied by thirty (30) equals or exceeds twenty-five thousand (25,000). 
    The municipality shall regularly monitor water consumption to determine whether a consumer is using excessive amount of water. The monitoring shall be accomplished by the installation of a properly calibrated water meter at the consumer's location. In the event the consumer uses in excess of twenty-five thousand (25,000) gallons per month, then all water used in excess of twenty-five thousand (25,000) gallons per month shall be charged at the highest commercial rate allowed in section 7-1017. 
    Further, the city shall cause to be issued to the consumer of excess water usage, a notice advising the consumer to cease the excess use within ten (10) days of the date of the notice. If the consumer continues the excess usage after the ten-day grace period, the municipality, at its discretion, may (1) allow the excess usage to continue, for which all excess amounts will be charged the highest commercial rate allowed in section 7-1017; or (2) disconnect the water service without further notice. Should the municipality opt to disconnect the water service, the consumer will be responsible for all outstanding water bills and any fees to reconnect the water service. 
(Ord. No. 624, 5-17-99) 
Division 2. - Cross-Connection Control 

Sec. 7-1021. - Cross-connection control device or method required. 
    Each existing or new structure is required to implement and maintain an adequate cross-connection control device or method for backflow prevention as mandated under state law and state regulations. 
(Ord. No. 805 , 6-21-10) 
Sec. 7-1022. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall apply only to this division. For those terms not defined in this division, the definitions contained in the Louisiana State Plumbing Code 2000 Edition (LSPC, 2000 Edition), and as amended, shall apply. 
(1)	Administrative authority means the city utilities department, or any agent, employee, officer, department, or board of the city designated to enforce this chapter. 
(2)	Approved means accepted or acceptable under an applicable specification or standard stated or cited in the Code, or accepted as suitable for the proposed use under procedures and authority of the administrative authority. 
(3)	Approved backflow prevention assembly for containment means an air gap meeting ASME Standard A 112.1.2 - 1991 (R 1998) "Air Gaps in Plumbing Systems" or a backflow prevention assembly which is listed by the University of Southern California-Foundation for Cross Connection Control and Hydraulic Research (USCFCCCHR) as having met the requirements of ANSI/AWWA Standard C510-97 or ASSE Standard 1015-1993, "Double Check Valve Backflow-Prevention Assemblies", or ANSI/AWWA Standard C511-97 or ASSE Standard 1013-1993, "Reduced-Pressure Principle Backflow Assemblies" for containment. The listing shall include the limitations of use based on the degree of hazard. The backflow prevention assembly must also be listed by the ASSE in Table 606 of the LSPC, 2000 Edition or other testing agency approved by the administrative authority. This term shall additionally include those backflow prevention assemblies meeting ANSI/ASSE Standard 1047-1995, "Backflow Preventer, Reduced Pressure Detector Assembly", or ANSI/ASSE Standard 1048-1995, "Backflow Preventer, Double Check Detector Assembly". (These detector assembly devices are often times used on fire protection/fire sprinkler systems to detect and monitor unauthorized water usage.) 
(4)	Approved backflow prevention assembly for containment in fire protection system means a backflow prevention assembly listed in Table 606 of the LSPC, 2000 Edition to be used in a fire protection system which also meets the requirements of Factory Mutual Research Corporation (FM) and Underwriters Laboratory (UL) and the requirement of the standard Codes adopted by the City of Westlake. Devices sized smaller than two and one-half (21/2) inches which have not been listed by Underwriters Laboratory (UL) and tested by Factory Mutual Research Corporation (FM) may be allowed if approved by the State Fire Marshal, and such device is listed in Table 606 of the LSPC, 2000 Edition. Any such device under this definition shall minimally meet the definition of an "approved backflow prevention assembly for containment". In addition, the particular type of device to be used for a particular application/degree of hazard shall be selected and installed in accord with the requirements of Table D104 of the LSPC, 2000 Edition. 
(5)	Approved testing agency means an organization primarily established for purposes of testing to approved standards and approved by the administrative authority (e.g., American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME), American Society of Sanitary Engineers (ASSE), American Water Works Association (AWWA), American National Standards Institute (ANSI), Factory Mutual Research Corporation (FM), Underwriters Laboratory (UL), University of Southern California-Foundation for Cross Connection Control and Hydraulic Research (USC-FCCCHR), etc.). 
(6)	Auxiliary water supply means any water supply on or available to the premises other than the water purveyor's approved public water supply such as, but not limited to, a private well, pond or river. 
(7)	Backflow means the flow of water or other liquids, mixtures, or substance into the distribution pipes of a potable supply of water from any sources other than its intended source. 
(8)	Backflow connection means any arrangement whereby backflow can occur. 
(9)	Back-pressure backflow means backflow due to an increased pressure above the supply pressure. This may be due to pumps, boilers, gravity or other sources of pressure. 
(10)	Backflow preventer means a device or method to prevent backflow into the potable water system. 
(11)	Backflow prevention assembly general tester means those individuals holding a testing certificate from a nationally recognized backflow certification organization approved by the State Health Officer. Such individuals are not required to be a licensed plumber and are authorized to perform tests of backflow prevention devices and methods. When such devices or methods are located on private property, a backflow prevention assembly general tester is not authorized to install, repair, or maintain such devices or methods. A general tester may perform installation, maintenance or repairs, if the backflow prevention device is on public property, after having obtained approval from the water purveyor. 
(12)	Backflow prevention assembly technician means a water supply protection specialist licensed by the State Plumbing Board of Louisiana pursuant to LA. R.S. 37:1361, et seq., and its implementing regulations (LAC 46:LV.101, et seq.). All water supply protection specialists are Louisiana licensed plumbers who hold such a special endorsement on their plumbing license. Such individuals are authorized to test, install, repair, and maintain backflow prevention devices and methods. 
(13)	Back-siphonage means the flowing back of used, contaminated, or polluted water from a plumbing fixture or vessel into a water supply pipe due to a negative pressure in such pipe. (See "backflow") 
(14)	Code The word "Code" or "this Code", when used alone, shall mean these regulations, subsequent amendments thereto or any emergency rule or regulation which the administrative authority having jurisdiction may lawfully adopt. 
(15)	Containment means a method of backflow prevention which requires the installation of an air gap or a backflow prevention assembly immediately following the water meter or as close to that location as deemed practical by the administrative authority. 
(16)	Contamination means an impairment of the quality of the potable water which creates an actual hazard to the public health through poisoning or through the spread of disease by sewage, industrial fluids or waste. Also defined as "high hazard." 
(17)	Cross-connection means any connection or arrangement, physical or otherwise, between a potable water supply system and any plumbing fixture or any tank, receptacle, equipment or device, through which it may be possible for non-potable, used, unclean, polluted or contaminated water, or other substances, to enter into any part of such potable water system under any condition. 
(18)	Customer means the owner, operator, or occupant of a building or property which has a water service from a public water system, or the owner or operator of a private water system which has a water service from a public water system. "Customer" shall not include any residential connection used for dwelling purposes, unless: i) the residence is also used as a business premises and the home-based business or occupation involves operation of a home-based business or occupation which the water purveyor or city inspector deems a potentially significant and high hazard to the city water supply; ii) the domestic water service provided is also used for a landscape irrigation system; or, iii) a separate water service has been installed for landscape irrigation and other non-domestic purposes. 
(19)	Degree of hazard means the rating of a cross-connection or water service which indicates if it has the potential to cause contamination or pollution. 
(20)	Domestic sewage means the liquid and water-borne wastes derived from the ordinary living processes, free from industrial wastes, and of such character as to permit satisfactory disposal, without special treatment, into the public sewer or by means of a private sewage disposal system. 
(21)	Double check valve backflow prevention assembly means a backflow prevention device consisting of two (2) independently acting internally loaded check valves, four (4) properly located test cocks, and two (2) isolation valves. 
(22)	Existing work means a plumbing system, or any part thereof which has been installed prior to the effective date of this Code. 
(23)	Fire protection system means any system used for fire protection or suppression with a direct connection to the public water supply, including but not limited to sprinklers, stand-pipes, and Siamese connections. 
(24)	High hazard see contamination. 
(25)	High hazard cross-connection means a cross-connection which may cause an impairment of the quality of the potable water by creating an actual hazard to the public health, through poisoning or through the spread of disease by sewage, industrial fluids, or waste. 
(26)	Industrial waste means any and all liquid or water-borne waste from industrial or commercial processes, except domestic sewage. 
(27)	Isolation means a method of backflow prevention in which a backflow prevention assembly is located at the cross-connection rather than at the water service entrance. 
(28)	Labeled means equipment or materials bearing a label or listing agency. 
(29)	Liquid water means the discharge from any fixture, appliance or appurtenance in connection with a plumbing system which does not receive fecal matter. 
(30)	Listed means equipment or materials included in a list published by a listing agency that maintains periodic inspection or current production of listed equipment or materials and whose listing states either that the equipment or material complies with approved standards or has been tested and found suitable for use in a specified manner.
