    Any person, firm or corporation violating or failing to comply with any of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, may be fined in an amount not to exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
Sec. 8-1028. - Conflict of law. 
    In any case where a provision of this chapter is found to be in conflict with a provision of the sanitary code of the state as adopted by the city, the provision which establishes the higher sanitary standard shall prevail, and no provision herein shall be construed as authorizing noncompliance with any provision of the sanitary code. 
(Ord. No. 248, § 29, 7-16-74) 
CHAPTER 2. - NOXIOUS WEEDS AND VEGETATION 

Sec. 8-2001. - Definition. 
    Noxious weeds shall mean and include chicory, crabgrass, garlic or wild onion, goldenrod, horse nettle, milkweed, morning glory, mullen, perennial thistle (including Canada, Russian, sow, ball and other thistles), poison ivy, poison oak, kudzu, ragweed, sumac, wild lettuce, wild mustard, wild parsnip, and wild snapdragon, and all other weeds and vegetation not herein specifically mentioned, which serve as a breeding place for mosquitoes or other insects, or as a refuge for snakes or rats, or a hiding place for filth, or create a fire or traffic hazard, or in any manner endanger the health or safety of the inhabitants of the city. 
Sec. 8-2002. - Accumulations prohibited. 
    It shall be the duty of every person who shall hold title in any capacity to, or have possession of, or be responsible for the management or upkeep of, any land or lot of ground upon which any noxious weeds, as herein defined, shall be growing to a height of more than twelve (12) inches, or so as to throw off any unpleasant or noxious odor, or to permit trash, rubbish, refuse and debris, thereon, and such persons shall maintain said lots or tracts, as well as the abutting sidewalks, banquettes, and neutral grounds free of such weeds, grass, brush, underbrush, trash, rubbish, refuse and debris, or so as to conceal any filthy deposit, or so as to create or produce pollen or so as to flower or to go to seed, to cut or destroy such noxious weeds. 
(Ord. No. 618, 8-17-98) 
Sec. 8-2003. - Nuisance. 
    Any noxious weeds growing upon any premises in the city in violation of any of the provisions of this chapter are hereby declared to be a nuisance and detrimental to the health, safety, cleanliness and comfort of the inhabitants of the city. In addition to the penalties provided in this chapter, any such nuisance may be abated as provided by law. 
Sec. 8-2004. - Unlawful to fail, refuse or neglect to cut or trim noxious weeds. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to fail, neglect or refuse to cut or destroy any noxious weeds growing in violation of this chapter, and also to prevent them from flowering or going to seed. 
Sec. 8-2005. - Encroachments. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to permit any noxious weeds or any trees, hedges, bushes or shrubbery of whatsoever kind or nature to grow or remain upon any premises in the city so as to encroach upon adjoining sidewalks, streets, highways or alleys in a manner so as to interfere with pedestrian or vehicular traffic lawfully using the sidewalks, streets, highways or alleys or in a manner so as to encroach upon the property of another person. 
Sec. 8-2006. - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person found guilty of violating any provision of this chapter shall, for each and every such violation, be punished as provided in section 1-1008 of this Code. 
Sec. 8-2007. - Notice to cut and remove. 
    In the event that any person shall fail to comply with the provisions of this chapter, the mayor shall notify the property owner, by personal service or by registered or certified mail, that he is in violation of this chapter, and that if he fails to cut and remove any and all noxious weeds and vegetation growing in violation of this chapter within fifteen (15) days from the date of the notice, the city may have such weeds and vegetation cut or destroyed and removed and charge the expense of the same to the owner. The city may use any and all means necessary to cut these weeds, including the use of heavy equipment to remove debris and junk from the property to accomplish the cutting of any noxious weeds or any trees, hedges, bushes or shrubbery. In addition to personal service as provided herein, the property owner shall also be given the opportunity to do the work himself within at least ten (10) days after notice has been given him by advertisement in the official journal of the city within which it is located, for two (2) consecutive weeks. 
(Ord. No. 322, § 1, 12-13-79; Ord. No. 340, § 1, 10-9-80) 
Cross reference- Cutting weeds, R.S. 33:5062. 
Sec. 8-2008. - Authority to have weeds cut or destroyed; cost of work charged to owner. 
    In addition to the penalty provided in section 8-2007 above, the mayor and city council may, where such persons shall fail to cut or destroy and remove such weeds, after notice as provided in section 8-2007 above, have such weeds cut and destroyed and removed from any land or lot or ground upon which the weeds may be growing, including the costs of debris and junk removal, and charge the expense of the same to the owner by assessment and the filing of a grass lien in the mortgage records of Calcasieu Parish, Louisiana. This lien shall act as a levy against the property and shall bear interest at the rate of twelve (12) per cent per annum until paid. Nothing herein shall limit the prosecution of an individual pursuant to section 8-2006. 
(Ord. No. 340, § 2, 10-9-80; Ord. No. 377, § 2, 4-14-83) 
Sec. 8-2009. - Mailing statement showing expense incurred; addition to tax liability. 
    If, after the cutting, destruction or removal of such weeds, grass or growths, by the city after due notice as above provided, the cost or expense thereof has not been paid within ten (10) days, the tax collector of the municipality shall furnish the owner, as shown on the last assessment roll of the municipality, by registered mail, a written statement showing the cost or expense incurred for the work, and the place or property on which the work was done. If the said statement is not paid within one (1) month thereafter, the amount thereof shall be included in and form part of the taxes due by the owner of said property, and when collected shall be credited to the general fund of said municipality. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 33:5063. 
Sec. 8-2010. - Record of charges for weed cutting. 
    The tax collector shall maintain a record of such charges prior to the filing of the tax rolls, which record shall be open to inspection at all times and which shall constitute legal notice to the purchasers of the property, or parties lending money thereon, of the assessment. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 33:5064. 
Sec. 8-2011. - Hiring of contract labor. 
(a)	In order to facilitate the city's purpose of removing noxious weeds, debris and junk, the city shall advertise once during March of each year for the hiring of three (3) contract personnel who shall be paid a fixed hourly rate for set-up time and a fixed hourly rate for each hour thereafter. These individual contractors shall be hired for a one-year period and shall be utilized by the city on a rotation basis. Each contractor shall be responsible for his own equipment and the hiring of any additional personnel which might be necessary to perform the job. Further, the contractor agrees to provide liability insurance covering himself and the city from any and all acts of negligence during the performance of his job. Such liability insurance shall be in the minimum sum of three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for each occurrence. 
(b)	Should an individual contractor become unable to perform his duties, then the city, at its discretion, may immediately hire a replacement and remove the existing contractor from the rotation list. 
(Ord. No. 377, § 1, 4-14-83) 
CHAPTER 3. - JUNKED MOTOR VEHICLES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 921 , adopted Dec. 19, 2016, repealed the former Ch. 3, §§ 8-3001-8-3012, and enacted a new Ch. 3 as set out herein. The former Ch. 3 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 207, §§ 1, 4-11, adopted Feb. 8, 1971 and Ord. No. 282, § 1, adopted Feb. 10, 1977. 

Sec. 8-3001. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter the following terms, phrases, words, and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense shall include the future; words used in plural number include the singular number; and words used in the singular number include the plural number. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory. 
(1)	Junked motor vehicle is any motor vehicle which does not have lawfully affixed thereto, both an unexpired license plate or plates and a valid motor vehicle safety inspection certificate, and the condition of which is one (1) or more of the following: 
a.	Wrecked; 
b.	Dismantled; 
c.	Partially dismantled; 
d.	Inoperative; 
e.	Abandoned; or 
f.	Discarded. 
g.	Exceptions: The provisions hereto shall not apply to: 
1.	Any motor vehicle in operable condition specifically adapted or constructed for racing or operation on privately owned drag strips or raceways; 
2.	Any motor vehicle retained by the owner for antique collection purposes: provided that the vehicle is registered with the State of Louisiana as an antique automobile, rather than retained by the owner for salvage or for transportation; nor 
3.	Any motor vehicle stored as the property of a member of the Armed Forces of the United States who is on active duty assignment. 
(2)	Motor vehicle shall be any vehicle which is designed to be self-propelled and designed to travel along the ground and shall include, but is not limited to, automobiles, buses, motorbike, motorcycles, mopeds, motor scooters, trucks, tractors, go-carts, golf carts, campers and trailers. 
(3)	Private property shall mean any property within the city which is privately owned and which is not public property as defined in this section. 
(4)	Public property shall mean any street or highway which shall include the entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly maintained for the purpose of vehicular traffic and shall also mean any other publicly owned property or facility. 
(5)	Person is any individual, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. 
(6)	City is the City of Westlake, Louisiana, a municipal corporation organized under the laws of the State of Louisiana, acting pursuant to and under the mayor and/or police power vested in the city. 
(Ord. No. 921 , 12-19-16) 
Sec. 8-3002. - Junked motor vehicles declared a public nuisance. 
    The presence of any junked motor vehicle on any private lot, tract or parcel of land, or portion thereof, occupied or unoccupied, improved or unimproved, within the city shall be deemed and is hereby a public nuisance; and it shall be unlawful for any person to cause or maintain such a public nuisance by wrecking, dismantling, partially dismantling; rendering inoperable, abandoning or discarding any motor vehicle on the real property of another or to suffer, permit or allow any junked motor vehicle to be parked, left or maintained on his real property; provided that this section shall not apply with regard to: 
(1)	Any junked motor vehicle in an enclosed building; 
(2)	Any junked motor vehicle in an appropriate storage place or depository maintained at a location where such business is authorized under the Comprehensive Zoning Ordinance and other regulatory ordinances of the city. 
(Ord. No. 921 , 12-19-16) 
Sec. 8-3003. - Notice to owner or occupant to abate public nuisance on occupied premises. 
(a)	Whenever any such public nuisance exists on occupied premises within the city in violation of section 8-3002 hereof, the mayor, chief of police or their duly authorized agent shall order the owner of the premises, if in possession thereof, or occupant of the premises whereon such public nuisance exists to abate or remove the same or require any vacant lot or other parcel of property, or any unused portion of any occupied lot or other parcel of property, used for the storage of junked vehicles, as described and defined, shall be surrounded or enclosed by a board fence or other non-transparent enclosure, at least eight (8) feet in height from ground level, which board fence or other non-transparent enclosure shall be painted and maintained by the owner or the lessee of the premises at his cost; further, the owner or lessee of the premises shall be required to take such action as may be recommended by the Calcasieu Parish Health Department, or the Louisiana State Health Department, to prevent the breeding of flies; mosquitoes, snakes, rats and other pests and vermin in or on the premises. The order shall: 
(1)	Be in writing; 
(2)	Specify the public nuisance and its location; 
(3)	Specify the corrective measures required; and 
(4)	Provide for compliance within ten (10) days from service thereof. 
(b)	Such order shall be served upon the owner of the premises or the occupant by serving him personally or by sending the order by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the address of the premises. If the owner or occupant of the premises fails or refuses to comply with the order of the mayor or chief of police or their duly authorized agent within the ten (10) day period after service thereof, as provided herein, the mayor or chief of police or their duly authorized agent shall take possession of the junked motor vehicle and remove it from the premises. The mayor and chief of police or their duly authorized agent shall remove and dispose of the junked motor vehicle in the following manner: 
(1)	Prior to the disposition of any vehicle, the police department shall place on an abandoned, stripped or junked motor vehicle a notice of removal, which notice shall be placed on the vehicle at least ten (10) days prior to its removal. The notice shall state the vehicle, unless corrective measures outlined by the mayor and/or chief of police are taken within ten (10) days, shall be considered public property and removed and sold for junk. The notice shall further state the following: 
a.	The date the notice was placed on the vehicle and served on the property. 
b.	The date the ten (10) days' notice will expire. 
c.	The authority to be contacted by any person claiming to have an adverse interest in the vehicle, or to evidence that the required corrective measures have been taken or performed. Such notice shall be placed in a prominent place on the abandoned, stripped or junked motor vehicle so as to be plainly in the public view, and a copy also served to the owner of the property where the vehicle is located. 
(c)	If the owner of the premises so desires, he may within the ten (10) day period after service of notice to abate the nuisance, request the clerk of the city, either in person or in writing and without the requirement of bond, that a date and time be set when he may appear before the mayor's court for a trial to determine whether or not he is in violation of this chapter, and whether or not the location and continued existence of the junked motor vehicle on his property constitutes a public nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 921 , 12-19-16) 
Sec. 8-3004. - Failure to abate-Removal. 
    In the event the public nuisance is not abated in compliance with the order mayor and/or chief of police or their duly authorized agent within ten (10) days from the date of such order, and no hearing is requested timely, the city is authorized to enter the premises in question, to remove or cause to be removed the junked vehicle and to dispose of it as follows: 
(1)	Upon the removal of any junked vehicle by reason of failure to comply with the city order of abatement, the junked vehicle becomes the property of the city without any liability whatsoever to the owner of the premises, the occupant of the premises, the registered owner of the junked vehicle, or any other party whatsoever. 
(2)	Upon removal a junked motor vehicle, the city shall convey the same to a scrap dealer, towing service, contractor, or dismantler, with title passing to such entity upon delivery. Any such transfers shall be made only upon the condition that the junked motor vehicle is scrapped and in no event be resold as a complete motor vehicle or reconditioned so as to be returned to the streets in an operating condition. 
(3)	The mayor and/or chief of police or his duly authorized agent is authorized to contract with one (1) or more scrap dealers, towing services, contractors, and/or dismantlers to provide for the removal of the junked motor vehicles as above specified, and on such terms as he deems are in the best interest of the city, with the preference being given to a removal at no charge to the city, and in no event shall the city pay in excess of five hundred dollars ($500.00) a piece for the removal of such junked motor vehicles. 
(4)	Upon the transfer of a junked motor vehicle as above specified, a certificate of transfer shall be given to the receiving entity and such transfer shall be reported to the Director of the Motor Vehicle Division of the Department of Revenue of the State of Louisiana, which report shall contain the location where the junked motor vehicle was abandoned, any identification information available, the date of transfer and the name and address of the entity to whom the vehicle was transferred for final disposition. 
(5)	All abandoned, stripped or junked motor vehicles removed from the city streets in accordance with this section shall be subject to a towing charge and service charge of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), which charge shall be due by the owner of or any person claiming an interest in the abandoned, stripped or junked motor vehicle. These charges are in addition to any other fees and/or fines. 
(Ord. No. 921 , 12-19-16) 
Sec. 8-3005. - Liability of cost for abatement. 
    The owner of the premises, the occupant of the premises, and/or the registered owner of the junked motor vehicle, in applicable cases, shall be personally liable for all costs of abatement which may be recovered by the city by sending an attested bill of said costs and expenses to the tax collector of the parish, who shall add the amount to said bill to the next tax bill on the property in question. Said duly authorized agent of the mayor and/or chief of police may also cause to be recorded in the mortgage records of the clerk of court of the parish an attested bill showing the cost of removal and the place the property on which the nuisance existed so as to establish for the city a lien and privilege securing the payment by the property owner of said charges, costs and expenses. 
(Ord. No. 921 , 12-19-16) 
Sec. 8-3006. - Record of sales of abandoned, stripped or junk vehicles. 
    City hall shall keep a complete record of all abandoned, stripped or junked motor vehicles removed from private property or city streets, with details as to the date of placing a ten (10) day notice, date of removal from private property or city streets, name and address of scrap iron dealer, towing service, or dismantler to whom the stripped or junked motor vehicle was taken. 
(1)	For the purpose of carrying out the provisions of this chapter, the mayor and/or chief of police is authorized to enter into a contract with an approved towing service, scrap dealer or dismantler. After compliance with this chapter and immediately after removal, title to these vehicles shall pass to the contractor. The vehicles after compliance herewith, shall be disposed of by the contractor, but in no event are these vehicles to be resold as complete vehicles or reconditioned so as to be returned to the streets in operating condition. Immediately after the vehicle is transferred to contractor, the city shall be relieved of all liability for the vehicle. 
(2)	All contractors under this chapter shall carry liability insurance in amounts provided by ordinance for any contractor do work for the city, shall own such equipment as may be required or necessary to properly carry out the contract and shall agree to hold the city free and harmless from any claims arising out of the work performed. The contracts to be so executed shall be approved by the office of the town attorney as to form. 
(3)	In the event contracts are executed with more than one (1) contractor, the mayor and/or chief of police or their duly authorized agent shall make assignments on an approved rotating basis so that all contractors will be given an equal number of assignments to the extent feasible and practical. 
(Ord. No. 921 , 12-19-16) 
Sec. 8-3007. - Notice to owner to abate public nuisance on unoccupied premises. 
(a)	Whenever any such public nuisance exists on unoccupied premises within the town, and the owner thereof can be found, the mayor and/or chief of police or his duly authorized agent shall order the owner of the premises whereupon such public nuisance exists, to abate or remove the same. The order shall: 
(1)	Be in writing; 
(2)	Specify the public nuisance and its location; 
(3)	Specify the corrective measures required; and 
(4)	Provide for compliance within ten (10) day from service thereof. 
(b)	The order shall be served upon the owner of the premises by serving him personally or by sending the order by certified mail, return receipt requested, to his address as shown on the current tax rolls. If the owner of the premises fails or refuses to comply with the order of the mayor and/or chief of police or his duly authorized agent within the ten (10) day period after service thereof, as provided herein, the mayor and/or chief of police or his duly authorized agent shall take possession of the junked motor vehicle and remove it from the premises. The mayor and/or chief of police or his duly authorized agent shall remove and dispose of the junked vehicle as provided in section 8-3004 above. 
(c)	If the owner of the premises so desires, he may within the ten (10) day period after service of notice to abate the nuisance, request the clerk of the city, either in person or in writing and without the requirement of bond, that a date and time be set when he may appear before the mayor's court for a trial to determine whether or not he is in violation of this chapter, and whether or not the location and continued existence of the junked motor vehicle on his property constitutes a public nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 921 , 12-19-16) 
Sec. 8-3008. - Preliminaries to trial in mayor's court. 
    Upon receiving the request for trial, made as herein able provided, the clerk of the town shall forthwith notify the office of the city attorney. Upon being so notified, the city attorney shall cause an affidavit to be prepared and filed charging the owner or occupant of the premises, as the case may be, has violated the provisions of this chapter. After service of the warrant, the complaint shall be placed on the docket of the mayor's court and tried in the same manner as are violations of other city ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 921 , 12-19-16) 
Sec. 8-3009. - Trial in the mayor's court. 
    Upon a finding that the defendant is in violation of this chapter, the defendant shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to a fine in accordance with the penalty provision hereinafter set forth. The magistrate shall further order the defendant to remove and abate the nuisance within ten (10) days, the same being a reasonable time, or render such other judgment or order as may be appropriate under the circumstances. If the defendant shall fail and refuse, within the ten (10) days to abate or remove the nuisance, the magistrate may issue an order directing the mayor and/or chief of police to have the same removed, and the mayor and/or chief of police or his duly authorized agent shall take possession of the junked motor vehicle and remove it from the premises. The mayor and/or chief of police or his duly authorized agent shall thereafter dispose of the junked motor vehicle in the manner provided in section 8-3004 above. 
(Ord. No. 921 , 12-19-16) 
Sec. 8-3010. - Removal with permission of owner or occupant. 
    If, within ten (10) days after receipt of notice from the mayor and/or chief of police, or his duly authorized agent, to abate the nuisance, as herein provided, the owner or occupant of the premises shall give his written permission to the mayor and/or chief of police, or his duly authorized agent for removal of the junked motor vehicle from the premises, the giving of such permission shall be considered compliance with the provision of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 921 , 12-19-16) 
Sec. 8-3011. - Removal from unoccupied premises by order of mayor's court. 
    If there is a junked motor vehicle, as herein defined, on premises that are unoccupied, and neither the owner of the premises nor the owner of the vehicle can be found and notified to remove the junked vehicle, then, upon a showing of such facts to the magistrate, the mayor's court may issue an order directing the mayor and/or chief of police or their duly authorized agent to have the junked vehicle removed, and the mayor and/or chief of police or his duly authorized agent shall take possession of the junked motor vehicle and remove it from the premises. The mayor and/or chief of police or his duly authorized agent shall thereafter dispose of the junked motor vehicle in the same manner as provided in section 8-3004. 
(Ord. No. 921 , 12-19-16) 
Sec. 8-3012. - Evidence of abandonment. 
    If a junked motor vehicle, as defined in this chapter has been situated on private property of another, without that person's permission for a period of sixty (60) days or longer, this fact shall be prima facie evidence that the owner of the vehicle has abandoned the same. 
(Ord. No. 921 , 12-19-16) 
Sec. 8-3013. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction shall be subject of a fine not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment of not more than thirty (30) days, or both. Each transaction in violation of any of the provisions hereof shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 921 , 12-19-16) 
CHAPTER 4. - ANIMALS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 435, enacted Oct. 18, 1987, amended Ch. 4, Animals, in its entirety to read substantially as herein set forth. (In a few instances articles were consolidated and relettered or "division" was substituted for "article" for classification purposes.) Prior to such amendment, Ch. 4 consisted of Art. A, General Provisions, §§ 8-4001-8-4003, and Art. B, Dog Control, §§ 8-4011-8-4020, which provisions derived from Ord. No. 114, enacted Feb. 4, 1963; Ord. No. 255, enacted Nov. 14, 1974; Ord. No. 339, enacted Oct. 9, 1980; Ord. No. 420, enacted Jan. 9, 1986; and Ord. No. 424, enacted April 24, 1986. 

ARTICLE A. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 8-4001. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words and derivations shall have the meanings given herein, unless it shall be apparent from the context that a different meaning is intended. 
    Abandon means the act of desertion of or leaving with inadequate protection and care any animal, whether intentional or not, that has been recognized as owned by a person. 
    Adequate feed means the provision at suitable intervals, not to exceed twenty-four (24) hours, of a quantity of wholesome foodstuff suitable for the species at its age and sufficient to maintain an adequate level of nutrition in each animal. 
    Adequate shelter means a structure which provides protection from the elements consistent with the normal requirements for the animal's size, species and breed. 
    Adequate water means clean, fresh, potable water provided in a sanitary manner or provided at suitable intervals for the species but not to exceed twenty-four (24) hours at any interval. 
    Animal means mammals, birds, fowls, reptiles, amphibians, and fish, except when referring specifically to the control of rabies when the word "animal" shall mean only mammal. 
    Animal control officer means the person whose powers shall be delegated to him by the mayor and city council and whose duties and responsibilities shall be delegated to him by the chief of police of the city. 
    Animal establishment means a facility operated as a pet shop, a grooming shop, a commercial or private kennel, a boarding establishment for dogs or cats, a training establishment for dogs for any purpose, a commercial or private stable, a zoo, or an aviary. Animal shelters operated by a public jurisdiction or tax-exempt humane organizations as well as veterinary medical facilities are exempt from the definition. 
    Animal shelter means a facility operated by public jurisdiction or by an accredited, tax-exempt humane organization for the purpose of impounding [or] harboring, abandoned or unwanted animals in compliance with the applicable federal, state and municipal standards. 
    At large means an animal on or off the premises of its owner and not under the direct control of the responsible owner. An owner may, however, leash, tie, stake, fence, or house the animal in any humane manner so as to keep the animal confined to the owner's property without the animal being defined as at large. Hunting and stock dogs while being worked by a responsible person shall not be defined as at large. 
    Aviary means an enclosure for birds which is large enough for birds to fly in freely. 
    Bite means any abrasion, puncture, tear or piercing of the human skin being caused by any animal. 
    Breeder. See "commercial breeder" and/or "hobby breeder." 
    Calcasieu Parish Health Unit means a governmental body operated by the Calcasieu Parish Police Jury for the purpose of disease control. 
    Calcasieu Parish license fee means a fee as set by the Calcasieu Parish Police Jury for the licensing of any animal within the parish. 
    Calcasieu Parish vaccination license certificate means a serially numbered certificate approved by a health officer and signed by a veterinarian. The certificate shall give the name of the animal's owner, address, telephone number, a description of the animal, the year issued, and shall certify that the animal was vaccinated against rabies and licensed by Calcasieu Parish. 
    Calcasieu Parish vaccination license tag means a suitable tag bearing the same number as the vaccination license certificate and the year issued and which is approved by a health officer. 
    Canine means any member of the family Canidae, not including wolves, jackals and foxes. 
    Cat means any member of Felidae (feline) family which is domesticated. 
    Circus means a commercial variety show featuring animal acts for public entertainment. 
    Collar means a band, chain, harness or other device worn around the neck of an animal to which a vaccination tag may be affixed. 
    Commercial breeder means any person, corporation or other entity, other than a hobby breeder, who breeds and sells animals. 
    Commercial guard dog service means any person, corporation, or other entity offering guard dog training or protection services for financial compensation. 
    Commercial kennel means any person engaged in the commercial breeding of dogs and/or cats for sale, individually or in litter lots; or in the boarding, training, selling or letting for hire of dogs and cats for compensation. Animal hospitals maintained by a veterinarian as part of the practice of veterinary medicine, shelters operated by a public jurisdiction or tax-exempt humane organizations, or private kennels, shall not be considered commercial kennels. 
    Commercial stable means any stable where any charges are made to accommodate equine species. Veterinary hospitals, shelters operated by a public jurisdiction, or tax-exempt humane organizations shall not be considered commercial stables. 
    Dealer means any person who sells, exchanges, or donates or offers to sell, exchange or donate animals to another dealer, pet shop, research facility or corporation. 
    Dog: See "canine." 
    Domesticated means any species accustomed to living with or in close association to man and having proven traditional long-term association with man or society. 
    Euthanasia means the humane destruction of any animal accomplished by a method that involves the use of an agent which produces painless loss of consciousness and subsequent death. 
    Fowl means a bird of any kind. 
    Grooming shop means a commercial establishment where animals are bathed, clipped, plucked or otherwise groomed, excluding veterinary clinics and animal shelters. 
    Health officer means the director and/or an agent of the Calcasieu Parish Health Unit. 
    Hobby breeder means any person who maintains facilities on his premises to breed purebred and/or pedigreed animals or fowl primarily for personal recreational use shown through participation in recognized confirmation shows, field or obedience trials, scenting, specialized hunting or working trials, and water trials. This person's primary purposes for breeding shall be improving the physical soundness, temperament, and confirmation of a given breed to a standard. The person shall not sell or exchange at wholesale nor for purpose of research, testing or experimentation. 
    Humane manner means the caring of an animal including, but not limited to, adequate heat and ventilation, sanitary shelter, and wholesome food and water consistent with the normal requirements and feeding habits for the animal's size, species and breed. 
    Humane organization means any organization duly incorporated under the laws of the state as a nonprofit humane organization. 
    Impound means to place an animal under the supervision of the appropriate animal control and care center or a veterinarian. 
    Interference means the act of hindering or molesting the animal control officer in the performance of any duty or seeking to release any animal in the custody of the animal control officer. 
    Kennel: See "commercial kennel" or "private kennel." 
    Licensing authority means any agency or department of the city or any designated representative thereof, including veterinarians, charged with administering the issuance and/or revocation of certificates and licenses under the provisions of this chapter. 
    Livestock means traditional farm animals. 
    Neutered means incapable of sexual reproduction. 
    Nuisance means any animal which damages, soils, defiles or defecates on private property other than the owner's, on public walks, or in recreational areas; causes unsanitary, dangerous or offensive conditions; causes a disturbance by excessive barking or other noisemaking; molests, attacks, or interferes with persons in the public right-of-way; chases vehicles; or attacks domestic animals. 
    Owner means any person, business, corporation or other legal entity that keeps in his care, harbors, acts as custodian or permits an animal to remain on or about his premises. 
    Pet means any animal kept for pleasure. 
    Pet shop means any establishment which engages in the business of buying two (2) or more species of live animals to sell at retail; accepts animals on consignment; hires to the public; or barters or exchanges animals. 
    Primary enclosure means any structure used to immediately restrict an animal or animals to a limited amount of space. 
    Private kennel means an area on a person's property that houses more than three (3) dogs or cats over four (4) months of age, such animals to be for that person's recreational use; for exhibition in confirmation shows, field or obedience trials; or for herding of ranch or farm animals. The sale of offspring shall not be the primary function of the kennel. 
    Private stable means any stable where no charge or other compensation is made for the use of the facilities or animals. 
    Public auction means any place or location where animals are sold at auction to the highest bidder. 
    Restraint means controlling an animal by a leash, within a vehicle, or by confining it on the property of the owner or keeper. 
    Sanitary conditions means the existence of an area that is physically clean and from which all agents injurious to health are removed and destroyed to a practical minimum. 
    Stable means any building, barn or other premises in which equine species are kept or from which they are let out for hire, for working, training or riding, or from which equine species are provided and used to give instruction in riding, or where equine species are boarded. 
    Tag. See "Calcasieu Parish vaccination license tag." 
    Temporary foster care home means a residence or farm establishment that provides temporary shelter and care for animals having special needs. 
    Veterinarian means any person duly licensed to practice veterinary medicine by the Louisiana Board of Veterinary Medical Examiners. 
    Veterinary hospital means any commercial business where medical and surgical treatment is administered to the animals by or under the direct supervision of a veterinarian. 
    Vicious animal means any animal that attacks, bites or attempts to bite a human or a domestic animal without provocation. 
    Wild and exotic animals means any undomesticated animal which can normally be found in the wild state. 
    Zoological park means any permanent facility, other than a pet shop, displaying or exhibiting undomesticated animals. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87; Ord. No. 448, § 1, 6-8-89) 
Sec. 8-4002. - Enforcement officers. 
    The provisions of this article shall be enforced by the mayor or his designee, with the assistance of the animal control officer, and with the assistance of any police officer of the city who is hereby empowered to enforce the provisions of this chapter. Further enforcement of these provisions may be amended by resolution and joint services agreement with other municipalities and/or parish governing authority. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
ARTICLE B. - BIRDS AND WILD FOWL 

Sec. 8-4003. - Bird sanctuary. 
(a)	The entire area embraced within the corporate limits of the municipality shall be designated as a bird sanctuary. 
(b)	It shall be unlawful to trap, hunt, shoot, or attempt to shoot or molest in any manner any bird or wild fowl or to rob bird nests or wild fowl nests; provided, however, if starlings or similar birds are found to be congregating in such numbers in a particular locality that they constitute a nuisance or a menace to health or property in the opinion of the animal control officer, then such information shall be presented to the mayor and city council, which shall consider the seriousness of the nuisance and if no satisfactory alternative is found to abate such a nuisance, such birds may be destroyed in such numbers and in a manner as is deemed advisable. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
ARTICLE C. - LIVESTOCK 

Sec. 8-4004. - Movement of animals. 
(a)	It shall be unlawful for any person to drive livestock through the streets of the city without written permission from the mayor. 
(b)	It shall be unlawful for any person to tie or anchor livestock or any other domestic animal for grazing or such like purposes or to drive, ride or otherwise cause to be manned any livestock upon or across any grass lawns, golf grounds or parks of the city. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4005. - Keeping swine. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to keep any swine within the city unless such swine are kept in a primary enclosure which shall be located at least three hundred (300) feet from the closest private property line. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4006. - Keeping horses, mules, goats or sheep. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to keep any horses, mules, goats, or sheep within the city unless said animals are kept in a primary enclosure which shall not be less than three hundred (300) feet from the closest property line. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4007. - Keeping milk cows or beef cattle. 
    Only one (1) cow may be kept for milking purposes. An adequate enclosed shelter with concrete floor and sanitary drainage must be provided, and this shelter must be not less than three hundred (300) feet from the closest property line. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4008. - Keeping fowl and rabbits-Proximity to property line. 
    Any person keeping chickens, ducks, geese or other fowl or rabbits within the city shall keep such fowl and rabbits within primary enclosures which shall not be nearer than fifty (50) feet from the closest property line. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4009. - Same-Maintenance of premises. 
    Premises where fowl or rabbits are kept within the city shall be maintained in a sanitary condition and in good repair at all times. Floors and yards where chickens or other fowl are to be kept shall be graded and drained. The accumulation on such premises of materials in which flies may breed or rats may be harbored or may feed is forbidden. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4010. - Same-Premises to be open for inspection. 
    Any person keeping fowl or rabbits within the city shall make such premises available for inspection by the animal control officer. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4011. - Livestock at large-Prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to permit livestock to roam at large or sleep upon or in any way occupy the streets, sidewalks, parks or enclosed lots within the city. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4012. - Same-Impounding. 
    The animal control officer shall secure a suitable and convenient place for the impounding of livestock found to be in violation of the provisions of section 8-4011. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4013. - Same-Records to be kept. 
    The animal control officer shall keep a separate account of the expenses of each animal taken charge of for violation of section 8-4011. Before releasing any such animal, the officer shall confirm the collection of the fees and expenses. The officer shall maintain records giving account of the number of animals impounded, names of owners when known, amount collected from the owner or from sales, and giving a list of expenses incurred. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4014. - Same-Penalties. 
    Any animal found in violation of [section 8-4011] shall be taken in charge by any officer of the city designated for that purpose and placed in a stock shelter or temporary foster care home and there detained until the owner thereof shall come forward and pay the fees and penalty assessed against him for such violation and also pay the actual expenses incurred due to impoundment. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4015. - Same-Authorized removal of impounded livestock. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to take or attempt to take any impounded animal out of the custody of the animal control officer or any animal control and care center or temporary foster care home without first paying the penalty and expenses assessed against him and securing permission to remove the livestock from the supervision of the animal control officer. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4016. - Same-Sale or placement of impounded livestock. 
    When any livestock impounded pursuant to section 8-4012 remains unclaimed for six (6) days and no owner has come forth providing proof of ownership and paying all penalties as provided in this chapter, the animal control officer may sell the impounded animal at public action to the last and highest bidder for cash. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4017. - Same-Notice. 
    When the owner neglects or refuses to pay the fine imposed, the mayor may cause to be published in the official journal of the city a notice describing any unclaimed stock that has been detained under the provisions of section 84012. Such notice may state that unless the fine assessed and the incidental expenses are paid, the mayor or his representative shall, on a day fixed, proceed to sell any remaining impounded stock to satisfy the changes arising against them from a violation of this chapter together with the cost of publication of the sale. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4018. - Same-Disposition of proceeds. 
    Any funds arising or accruing from the enforcement of section 8-4012 shall be devoted first to the payment of the expenses incurred in the enforcement of section 8-4012 and after all incidental expenses are paid, any balance shall be placed into the general fund of the city. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Secs. 8-4019-8-4029. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE D. - CATS 

Sec. 8-4030. - Rabies vaccinations-Required. 
    It shall be unlawful to own, keep, possess, harbor or maintain a cat over the age of four (4) months in the city without having such cat vaccinated against rabies. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4031. - Same-Frequency. 
    Each year, prior to the expiration of the date on the vaccination license certificate, the owner of a cat shall have such cat vaccinated against rabies by a veterinarian and licensed by the licensing authority. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4032. - Same-Place. 
    The owner may take his cat to the veterinarian of his choice for all required vaccinations or to a public rabies clinic. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4033. - Same-Proof. 
    Proof that a cat has been vaccinated lies with the owner or keeper of the animal through the supplying of the vaccination certificate issued by the veterinarian at the time of the rabies vaccination. Tags are not required for cats. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4034. - Licensing. 
(a)	Any person owning, keeping, harboring or having custody of any cat over four (4) months of age within the city must obtain a license for such cat. 
(b)	The animal control officer shall maintain a record of all certificates and licenses issued and make such records available to the Calcasieu Parish health unit and all veterinarians. 
(c)	Application for a cat license for all cats over four (4) months of age shall be made to the licensing authority and shall state name, address and telephone number of the owner(s); the name, breed, color, age and sex of the cat; and a certificate of rabies vaccination issued by the licensing authority. 
(d)	Application for a license must be made within thirty (30) days after obtaining a cat over four (4) months of age, or within thirty (30) days of establishing a residence in the city. This requirement shall not apply to a nonresident keeping a cat within the city for no longer than sixty (60) days. 
(e)	The licensing authority is hereby empowered to collect the license fee and issue a cat license at the time a cat is vaccinated for rabies. Cat license receipts shall be collected from such veterinarians by the animal control officer on at least a quarterly basis. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4035. - Escaped cats. 
    Should any cat be captured by the animal control officer and then escapes by entering the premises of any person and such person refuses to deliver such cat to the animal control officer, such person shall be in violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Secs. 8-4036-8-4039. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE E. - DOGS 
Division 1. - Dog Control 

Sec. 8-4040. - Licensing. 
(a)	Any person owning, keeping, harboring or having custody of any dog over four (4) months of age within this municipality must obtain a license as provided in paragraph (c). 
(b)	The animal control officer shall maintain a record of all certificates and licenses issued and make such records available to the Calcasieu Parish health unit and all veterinarians. 
(c)	Application for a dog license for all dogs over four (4) months of age shall be made to the licensing authority and shall state name, address, and telephone number of the owner(s); the name, breed, color, age, and sex of the dog; and a certificate of rabies vaccination issued by the licensing authority. 
(d)	Application for a license must be made within thirty (30) days after obtaining a dog over four (4) months of age, or within thirty (30) days of establishing a residence in the city. This requirement shall not apply to a nonresident keeping a dog within the city for no longer than sixty (60) days. 
(e)	The licensing authority is hereby empowered to collect the license fee and issue a dog license and a durable metal tag at the time a dog is vaccinated for rabies. Dog license receipts shall be collected from such veterinarians by the animal control officer on at least a quarterly basis. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Secs. 8-4041-8-4049. - Reserved. 
Division 2. - Rabies Vaccinations and Tags 

Sec. 8-4050. - Vaccination against rabies required. 
(a)	It shall be unlawful to own, keep, harbor or maintain a dog over the age of three (3) months in this city without having such dog vaccinated against rabies each year by a veterinarian and licensed by Calcasieu Parish. 
(b)	A durable metal tag and a certificate of vaccination shall be issued at the time of inoculation. Tags are not transferable from one dog to another. 
(c)	Tags must be attached to the collar or harness of the dog and be worn at all times. Dogs used for hunting, on exhibition at approved shows, engaged in a specific "dog club" sponsored event, or being transported to and from such events need not wear their collars nor their tags. 
(d)	For registered dogs serving the blind or deaf or government-owned dogs used for law enforcement, all vaccination provisions shall apply, but the wearing of the tag may be waived by the animal control officer. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87; Ord. No. 563, 4-11-96) 
Sec. 8-4051. - Frequency of vaccination. 
    Prior to the expiration of the date of the vaccination license certificate the owner shall have such dog vaccinated against rabies and licensed by the licensing authority. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4052. - Place for receiving vaccination. 
    The owner may take his dog to a veterinarian of his choice for all required vaccinations and licensing by the licensing authority or may avail himself of the clinics provided for in this article. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4053. - Clinics-Authorized. 
    The animal control officer, with the approval of the mayor and city council, is authorized to sponsor public clinics at any place or time of his choosing for rabies vaccinations and to arrange for the services of veterinarians at such clinics. At such clinics, a veterinarian shall apply the vaccine, and arrangements shall be made by the animal control officer to supply license certificates, tags and administrative personnel. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4054. - Same-Fees. 
    The fee for a vaccination at the public clinic shall be set by the Calcasieu Parish Police Jury or its designated representatives. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4055. - Lost tag replacement. 
    Lost vaccination license tags may be replaced by a veterinarian after receiving verification of vaccination license certificate and payment of a fee set by the mayor and city council. The receipts shall be collected from the veterinarians by the animal control officer on at least a quarterly basis. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4056. - Counterfeiting tags prohibited. 
    Any person who counterfeits or imitates the license tag as provided by the licensing authority, or who shall put on a dog any such counterfeit or imitation tag, or who shall use a license tag on a dog for which it was not issued shall be subject to the penalties provided herein. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4057. - Removal of tags. 
    Any person who maliciously or wantonly removes, or causes to be removed, directly or indirectly, any tag from the dog of another person shall be subject to the penalties provided herein. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Secs. 8-4058, 8-4059. - Reserved. 
Division 3. - Miscellaneous 

Sec. 8-4060. - Escaped dogs. 
    Should any dog at large be captured by the animal control officer and then escapes by entering the premises of any person and such person refuses to deliver such dog to the animal control authority, such person shall be in violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4061. - Dogs in tenement yards. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner or keeper of any dog to allow such dog to be at large in any multiple occupancy building occupied by two (2) or more families or in the yard thereof. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4062. - Dogs on school grounds or public recreation areas. 
    Owners shall not permit dogs on any school ground when school is in session or on any public recreation area when an organized activity is being conducted unless the dog is controlled by a leash or similar device to prevent the dog from biting any person or animal. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4063. - Dogs running at large prohibited. 
    A dog shall be confined within the owner's or keeper's own yard or primary enclosure which shall be adequately fenced. If such dog is allowed outside of the enclosure it shall be on a leash. For the purposes of this section, any person who shall harbor or permit any dog upon or about his premises or is the registered owner of such dog shall be deemed the owner or keeper of such dog, and any owner by permitting his dog to run at large shall be in violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4064. - Penalties for violation of division. 
    Any person who shall be in violation of sections 8-4060 through 8-4063 shall be fined not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00); provided, however, that the minimum penalty for a first offender shall be a fine of not less than five dollars ($5.00); for a second offender a fine of not less than fifteen dollars ($15.00); for a third offender a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00); and for any fourth or more offender a fine of not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00). After a fifth offense, the dog shall be considered abandoned and custody shall transfer to the animal control officer, who shall make the decision about the disposition of the dog. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Secs. 8-4065-8-4069. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE F. - DISPOSITION OF IMPOUNDED ANIMALS 

Sec. 8-4070. - Owner notification. 
    After impoundment of a dog or cat which can be identified by a license tag or other ready means, the animal control officer shall make every reasonable effort to notify the owner so that the owner may claim the animal within three (3) days, exclusive of Sundays and legal holidays, after impoundment. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4071. - Holding period-Defined. 
    An animal impounded shall be kept for a period of three (3) working days and unless claimed by its owner in such time, all rights to the animal held by the owner shall be forfeited and title to the animal shall pass to the appropriate animal control and care center as designated by the mayor and city council. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4072. - Same-Exception. 
    Animals may be disposed of under three (3) days at the discretion of the director of the animal control and care center if, upon notification of impoundment of such animal, the owner states he does not wish to redeem the animal. A diseased or injured animal may be destroyed immediately or prior to the expiration of three (3) days if, in the opinion of the director of the animal control authority or a veterinarian, if possible, its condition is such that imminent destruction is necessary as a humane gesture or for the protection of other animals with which the animal may come in contact. A veterinarian need not be contacted in the case of an animal without collar and tag or identifiable tattoo. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4073. - Redemption of impounded dogs and cats. 
    The owner, upon producing satisfactory proof of ownership, may reclaim his animal upon complying with the vaccination requirements, collar and tag, in addition to paying fees for boarding, impoundment, and violation penalties as provided for herein. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4074. - Redemption of other impounded animals. 
    The owner, upon producing satisfactory proof of ownership may reclaim his animal upon paying the fees for boarding, impounding, and violation penalties as provided for herein. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4075. - Reasons for impoundment. 
(a)	Whenever animals are kept within any building or on any premises without food, water, or proper care and attention, are kept in violation of the provisions of this chapter, are infected with disease, or kept under conditions which could endanger public health or create a nuisance, it shall be the duty of the animal control officer to enter such building or premises and impound animals. Animals so impounded shall not be released before the reason causing such impoundment has been corrected in the opinion of the animal control officer. 
(b)	Any canine not wearing a current vaccination license tag, whether such dog is on or off the premises of its owner, shall be in violation of this chapter. Such canine may be seized by the animal control officer and impounded and thereafter released to its owner, as the circumstances may require, all according to the conditions, rules, regulations and requirements concerning the impoundment of dogs as herein set forth. Further, the owner of the canine may be penalized as provided herein. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4076. - Unwanted animals. 
    Owners of unwanted healthy animals may surrender such animals to the animal control officer at no cost to the owner, and such animal shall be made available for adoption or other disposition at the discretion of the animal control officer. If an owner has a sick animal and chooses to surrender such animal to the animal control officer, there shall be a fee for the humane euthanasia of such animal. This fee shall be established by the mayor and city council. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4077. - Disposition of unclaimed or diseased animals. 
    When an animal has been impounded for three (3) full days, excluding Sundays and holidays, and its owner has not appeared to reclaim it, it shall be disposed of by euthanasia unless the prospects of finding it a home or any other reason justifies detention for a longer period of time; all of which shall be at the discretion of the appropriate animal control and care center. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4078. - Adopting impounded animals. 
(a)	Any animal held at an animal control and care center in an effort to place it in a home may be adopted provided the prospective owner agrees to an adoption procedure set by the animal control and care center and makes payment of all fees for adoption as provided herein. 
(b)	Any person adopting an unspayed or unneutered dog or cat from the animal control and care center must sign an agreement assuring that he shall have the animal spayed or neutered within sixty (60) days or as soon as it reaches an appropriate age as certified by a veterinarian. If the animal is not spayed or neutered according to the agreement, such animal shall be reimpounded and all adoption fees forfeited. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4079. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE G. - VICIOUS ANIMALS 

Sec. 8-4080. - Definition of vicious and/or dangerous dogs. 
(a)	As used in this article, "vicious and/or dangerous dogs" shall mean and include: 
(1)	Any dog which, when unprovoked, in a vicious or terrorizing manner, approaches any person in apparent attitude of attack upon the streets, sidewalks, or any public grounds or places; or 
(2)	Any dog with a known propensity, tendency or disposition to attack unprovoked, to cause injury or to otherwise endanger the safety of human beings or domestic animals; or 
(3)	Any dog which bites, inflicts injury, assaults, or otherwise attacks a human being or domestic animal without provocation on public or private property; or 
(4)	Any dog owned or harbored primarily or in part for the purpose of dog fighting or any dog trained for dog fighting. 
(b)	Subsections (a)(1), (a)(2) and (a)(3) above are necessary controls on the unrestrained activity of vicious animals which threaten the safety and pleasantness of streets, parks, sidewalks, yards, and all areas of the city; and lack of knowledge or lack of intent is not a defense to a violation thereof. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4081. - Owners' responsibilities. 
(a)	No person owning or harboring or having the care or custody of a vicious/dangerous dog shall suffer or permit such dog to go unconfined on the premises of such person. Such dog is "unconfined" as the term is used in this section if such dog is not securely confined indoors or confined in a secure, totally enclosed and locked pen or a dog run area upon the premises of such person. Such pen or dog run area must also have sides six (6) feet high and a secure top, providing shelter from the sun and rain. If the pen or structure has no concrete slab bottom secured to the sides, the sides must be imbedded into the ground no less than one (1) foot. Such enclosure should prevent the entry of young children and be suitable to confine a vicious dog in conjunction with other measures which may be taken by the owner or keeper, such as humanely tethering the vicious dog and shall be designed to prevent the animal from escaping from the enclosure. 
(b)	No person owning or harboring or having the care of a dangerous dog shall suffer or permit such dog to go beyond the premises of such person unless such dog is securely muzzled and restrained with a chain having a minimum tensile strength of three hundred (300) pounds and not exceeding three (3) feet in length. 
(c)	No person shall own or harbor any dog for the purpose of dog fighting, or train, torment, badger, bait or use any dog for the purpose of causing or encouraging such dog to unprovoked attacks upon human beings or domestic animals. 
(d)	No person shall possess with intent to sell, offer for sale, breed, or buy or attempt to buy within the city any vicious/dangerous dog. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4082. - Enforcement. 
(a)	Any animal found "at large" or "unconfined" after written notice has been served by the animal control officer declaring it is vicious shall constitute a public danger and shall be promptly impounded without further notice to its owner. Such animal is to be promptly surrendered to the animal control authority upon request. Refusal of owner to cooperate with the animal control authority constitutes interference with an officer and penalties shall be enforced accordingly. 
(b)	If any declared vicious/dangerous animal is verified "at large" by sworn witness statements and has returned home before the animal control authority arrives, it is hereby found to be in violation of this section. Such animal is to be promptly surrendered to the animal control authority upon request. Refusal of the owner to cooperate with the animal control authority constitutes interference with an officer and penalties shall be enforced accordingly. 
(c)	In the event that the animal control authority has probable cause to believe that a dangerous/vicious dog is being harbored or cared for in violation of section 8-4081, the animal control authority shall petition the mayor's court to order the seizure and impoundment of the dangerous/vicious dog pending trial. In the event that the animal control authority has probable cause to believe that a dangerous/vicious dog is being harbored or housed in violation of section 8-4081 (b) or (c), the authority shall seize and impound the dog pending trial. 
(d)	The owner of any vicious/dangerous dog shall be issued a written citation to this effect and be provided with confinement requirements stating the animal shall not be at large and registered separately as a declared vicious dog with the animal control authority. Any owner seeking to reclaim a vicious/dangerous dog impounded under the authority of section 8-4082 shall also be notified in writing of confinement requirements. 
(e)	No animal impounded under the authority of section 8-4082 (a) through (d) shall be released until confinement requirements have been met and inspected by the animal control authority. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4083. - Restraint, muzzling and confinement. 
    After an investigation by the animal control authority pursuant to section 8-4082 and due notice to the owner, the animal control authority shall issue a citation and notice stipulating confinement requirements, muzzling, removal from the city, or humane destruction of an animal for any of the following reasons: 
(1)	Whenever an animal has committed an unprovoked attack upon any person or domestic animal, or approaches any person in a terrorizing manner or in an apparent attitude of attack upon the streets, sidewalks, or any public grounds or places; or 
(2)	Whenever an animal has undergone quarantine for rabies observation more than once in a twelve (12) month period; or 
(3)	Whenever any lawful patron or visitor of a business is jeopardized by a guard dog which is not securely confined during hours such business is open to the public; or 
(4)	Whenever persistent neighborhood complaints have been lodged against an unrestrained animal and, after investigation by the animal control authority, it is found that said animal is threatening the safety, peace and well-being of persons and/or other domestic pets by its aggressive and menacing behavior; or 
(5)	Whenever it is investigated and apparent by extensive scars and injuries that such animal is being owned or harbored primarily or in part for the purpose of dog fighting or is trained for dog fighting. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4084. - Provoked attacks by vicious dog. 
(a)	Notwithstanding the definition of a vicious dog above, no dog may be declared vicious if an injury or damage is sustained by a person who, at the time such injury or damage was sustained, was committing a willful trespass or other tort upon premises occupied by the owner or keeper of the dog, or was teasing, tormenting, abusing or assaulting the dog or was committing or attempting to commit a crime. 
(b)	No dog may be declared vicious if an injury or damage was sustained by a domestic animal which, at the time such injury or damage was sustained, was teasing, tormenting, abusing or assaulting the dog. No dog may be declared vicious if the dog was protecting or defending a human being within the immediate vicinity of the dog from an unjustified attack or assault. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4085. - Requirements for registration. 
(a)	No vicious dog shall be licensed by the city for any licensing period commencing after January 1, 1988, unless the owner or keeper of such vicious dog shall meet the following requirements: 
(1)	The owner or keeper shall present to the city animal control officer proof that the owner or keeper has procured liability insurance in the amount of at least one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) covering any damage or injury which may be caused by such vicious dog during the twelve-month period for which licensing is sought, which policy shall contain a provision requiring the city to be named for the sole purpose of the city or other licensing authority knowing where such dog is licensed and to be notified by the insurance company of any cancellation, termination or expiration of the liability insurance policy. 
(2)	The owner or keeper shall, at his own expense, have the licensing number assigned to such vicious dog, or such other identification number as the city animal control officer shall determine, tattooed upon such vicious dog, by a licensed veterinary or person trained as a tattooist and authorized as such by the city. The tattoo shall be placed either on the upper inner lip or upper left rear thigh of the vicious dog. The animal control officer may, in his discretion, designate the particular location of said tattoo. Such number shall be noted on the city files for such vicious dog, if it is different from the license number of such vicious dog. For the purposes of this section "tattoo" shall be defined as any permanent numbering of a vicious dog by means of indelible or permanent ink with the number designated by the licensing authority, or any other permanent, acceptable method of tattooing. The city shall affix a two-letter prefix to the identification number. 
(3)	The owner or keeper shall sign a statement attesting that: 
The owner or keeper shall maintain and not voluntarily cancel the liability insurance required by this section during the twelve-month period for which licensing is sought, unless the owner or keeper shall cease to own or keep the vicious dog prior to expiration of such license. 
(4)	The owner or keeper shall, on or prior to the effective date of such license for which application is being made, have an enclosure for the vicious dog on the property where the vicious dog will be kept or maintained. 
(5)	The owner or keeper shall notify the animal control officer within twenty-four (24) hours if a vicious dog is on the loose, is unconfined, has attacked another animal or has attacked a human being, or has died or had been sold or given away. If the vicious dog has been sold or given away, the owner or keeper shall also provide the licensing authority with the name, address, and telephone number of the new owner of the vicious dog. 
(b)	The animal control officer is hereby empowered to make whatever inquiry is deemed necessary to ensure compliance with the provisions of this chapter, and any such animal control officer is hereby empowered to seize and impound any vicious dog whose owner or keeper fails to comply with the provisions hereof. 
(c)	In the event that the owner or keeper of the dog refuses to surrender the animal to the animal control officer or to provide verified name, address, phone numbers of a person who accepted custody or ownership of declared vicious animals, the animal control officer may request a law enforcement officer to obtain a search warrant from the court and to seize the dog upon execution of the warrant. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4086. - Action for damages; destruction of offending vicious dogs. 
(a)	Procedures. If any vicious dog shall, when unprovoked, kill or wound, or assist in killing or wounding any sheep, a lamb, cattle, horse, hog, swine, fowl, or other domestic animal, belonging to or in the possession of any person, or shall, when unprovoked, attack, assault, bite or otherwise injure any human being or assist in attacking, assaulting, biting or otherwise injuring any human being while out of or within the enclosure of the owner or keeper of such vicious dog, or while otherwise on or off the property of the owner or keeper whether or not such vicious dog was on a leash and securely muzzled or whether the vicious dog escaped without fault of the owner or keeper, the owner or keeper of such dog shall be liable to the person aggrieved as aforesaid for all damage sustained, to be recovered in civil action. It is rebuttable presumed as a matter of law that the owning, keeping or harboring of a vicious dog in violation of this article is a nuisance. It shall not be necessary, in order to sustain any such action, to prove that the owner or keeper of such vicious dog knew that such vicious dog possessed the propensity to cause such damage or that the vicious dog had a vicious nature. Upon such attack or assault, the animal control officer is hereby empowered to confiscate and destroy such vicious dog, if the conduct of such vicious dog or its owner or keeper constituted a violation of the provisions of this article, punishable by the confiscation and destruction of the animal. 
(b)	Exemption. The provisions of this article shall not apply to K-9 or other dogs owned by any police department or any law enforcement officer which are used in the performance of police work. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Secs. 8-4087-8-4089. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE H. - NUISANCE ANIMALS 

Sec. 8-4090. - Definition. 
    Any animal shall be deemed and declared a public nuisance if it: 
(1)	Molests passersby or passing vehicles; 
(2)	Attacks other domestic animals; 
(3)	Trespasses on schools grounds while not under direct control of the responsible owner; 
(4)	Damages private or public property; 
(5)	Barks, whines, crows, or howls, or yowls in the case of cats, or squawks in case of birds, in an excessive, continuous, or untimely manner so as to disturb the peace and repose of others living nearby; 
(6)	Continuously trespasses on property other than its owner's and scratches or destroys private property; 
(7)	Causes unsanitary conditions or odors about the premises of the owner through urination or defecation, or by roaming the neighborhood and digging or defecating in lawns or gardens of other besides the owner; or 
(8)	Is a female animal in heat that is not kept confined in a building, a secure enclosure, a veterinary clinic or hospital, or a kennel in such a manner that such female animal cannot come into contact with an animal of the opposite sex except for intentional breeding purposes. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4091. - Maintenance of premises; disturbing noises. 
(a)	The owner of any animal shall maintain his premises in such a manner as not to constitute either a private nuisance to adjoining property owners or a nuisance to the public generally. Pens or yard areas in which animals are confined or maintained shall be cleaned regularly so that they are kept free from offensive odors which would disturb any person residing within a reasonable distance of said premises; and the animals themselves shall be restrained in such a fashion that noise emanating therefrom shall not be disturbing to such persons. 
(b)	Premises on which animals are kept shall be maintained so as to prevent disagreeable odors arising therefrom, or the presence or breeding of flies, mosquitoes, and other pests. Provisions shall be made for the removal and disposal of animal and food wastes, bedding, dead animals and debris. Disposal facilities shall be so provided and operated as to minimize vermin infestation, odors and disease hazards. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4091.1. - Cleanup and disposal of animal waste. 
    If any part of a public street or the private property of a person other than the owner or keeper of the animal shall be soiled by the excreta of that animal, whether such nuisance shall take place in the presence of the owner or keeper or not, the owner or keeper shall promptly remove such excreta and dispose of it in a sanitary manner. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4092. - Complaint procedure. 
    Upon the sworn statement of two (2) witnesses, not in the same household, in the immediate neighborhood and upon investigation by the animal control officer, the owner of the animal may be penalized as provided for herein. Such animal may be seized by the animal control officer and impounded. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4093. - Penalties for article violations. 
    In addition to established penalties herein, upon the second offense by the owner of the animal, the animal shall be confined by the animal control officer. The owner shall be served written notice that upon the third offense, the animal shall be impounded by the animal control officer and destroyed by euthanasia or placed with a suitable person upon proof that that person shall prevent the animal from further nuisance offenses and upon signing the adoption contract. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Secs. 8-4094-8-4109. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE I. - ANIMAL BITES 

Sec. 8-4110. - Exceptions. 
    This article shall not apply, except in the discretion of the appropriate animal control authority or the Calcasieu health unit, to such small caged pets as mice, rats, gerbils, hamsters or guinea pigs. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4111. - Notification of bites. 
(a)	Should any animal bite a person, or be reported to have bitten a person within the city, it shall be the duty of the owner, or the person having the same in his possession or under his control, to immediately notify the animal control officer and surrender such animal to the animal control officer, who shall impound or cause to be impounded and confined securely any such animal for a period of ten (10) days for observation. 
(b)	Any person having knowledge that an animal, domestic or wild, is rabid or suspects an animal of having rabies, or having knowledge that a person or an animal has been bitten by a suspected rabid animal shall promptly report such information, to the extent known, to the animal control officer. 
(c)	Every veterinarian shall report promptly to the animal control officer on the first and tenth days all cases of suspected rabies in animals observed by him giving the name and address of the owner and addresses of any person(s) or animal(s) bitten by such suspected rabid animal, as far as known. No rabies vaccination shall be administered during that ten-day period. Upon completion of the ten-day observation period any such animal, if a dog or cat, must have a valid license and vaccination before it shall be released. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Sec. 8-4112. - Confinement of rabid animals or suspect animals. 
(a)	No animal that has rabies or symptoms thereof, or has been suspected of having rabies or symptoms thereof, shall be allowed at large within the city. The owner of any animal that has rabies or symptoms thereof or has been exposed to rabies or has bitten anyone, whether said animal be on or off the owner's private property, whether vaccinated or not, shall hereby notify the animal control officer and, on demand, convey the animal to them for the purposes of observation. However, if the owner chooses, and upon sufficient evidence thereto, the owner may convey the animal to a veterinary clinic for observation for a period of not less than ten (10) days. 
(b)	If the animal is a family pet that has bitten an immediate family member, the owner must notify the animal control officer, and upon a recommendation from a veterinarian and the owner signing a form releasing the Westlake Animal Control Officer of all liability and upon proof of current rabies vaccination, the animal control officer may permit the animal to be placed under a "courtesy" quarantine inside the owner's home for not less than ten (10) days. 
(Ord. No. 435, 10-17-87) 
Secs. 8-4113-8-4119. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE J. - CRUELTY TO ANIMALS 

Sec. 8-4120. - Described. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person: 
(1)	To overdrive, overload, overwork, torture, beat, mutilate, kill needlessly, carry or confine in a vehicle in an inhumane manner, or otherwise mistreat any animal; 
(2)	To fail to provide any animal with adequate food, drink, protection from the weather and veterinary care; 
(3)	To abandon any animal; 
(4)	To intentionally poison any animal other than rats; 
(5)	To allow or promote any fight between animals, or to allow or permit any such fight in or upon any premises in his possession or under his control; 
(6)	To acquire infant or other "pet" animals for purposes of training fighting animals to kill;
