(5)	All new and replacement water supply systems shall be designed to minimize or eliminate infiltration of flood waters into the system; 
(6)	New and replacement sanitary sewage systems shall be designed to minimize or eliminate infiltration of flood waters into the system and discharge from the systems into flood waters; and, 
(7)	On-site waste disposal systems shall be located to avoid impairment to them or contamination from them during flooding. 
(Ord. No. 811 , Art. 5, 11-15-10) 
Sec. 12-7040. - Specific standards. 
    In all areas of special flood hazards where base flood elevation data has been provided as set forth in (i) Article C, section 12-7007, (ii) Article D, section 12-7025(8), or (iii) Article E, section 12-7041(3), the following provisions are required: 
(1)	Residential construction. new construction and substantial improvement of any residential structure shall have the lowest floor (including basement), elevated to or above the base flood elevation. A registered professional engineer, architect, or land surveyor shall submit a certification to the floodplain administrator that the standard of this subsection as proposed in Article D, section 12-7026(a)(1), is satisfied. 
(2)	Nonresidential construction. new construction and substantial improvements of any commercial, industrial or other nonresidential structure shall either have the lowest floor (including basement) elevated to or above the base flood level or together with attendant utility and sanitary facilities, be designed so that below the base flood level the structure is watertight with walls substantially impermeable to the passage of water and with structural components having the capability of resisting hydrostatic and hydrodynamic loads and effects of buoyancy. A registered professional engineer or architect shall develop and/or review structural design, specifications, and plans for the construction, and shall certify that the design and methods of construction are in accordance with accepted standards of practice as outlined in this subsection. A record of such certification which includes the specific elevation (in relation to mean sea level) to which such structures are floodproofed shall be maintained by the floodplain administrator. 
(3)	Enclosures. new construction and substantial improvements, with fully enclosed areas below the lowest floor that are usable solely for parking of vehicles, building access or storage in an area other than a basement and which are subject to flooding shall be designed to automatically equalize hydrostatic flood forces on exterior walls by allowing for the entry and exit of floodwaters. Designs for meeting this requirement must either be certified by a registered professional engineer or architect or meet or exceed the following minimum criteria: 
a.	A minimum of two (2) openings on separate walls having a total net area of not less than one (1) square inch for every square foot of enclosed area subject to flooding shall be provided. 
b.	The bottom of all openings shall be no higher than one (1) foot above grade. 
c.	Openings may be equipped with screens, louvers, valves, or other coverings or devices provided that they permit the automatic entry and exit of floodwaters. 
(4)	Manufactured homes. 
a.	Require that all manufactured homes to be placed within Zone A on a community's FHBM or FIRM shall be installed using methods and practices which minimize flood damage. For the purposes of this requirement, manufactured homes must be elevated and anchored to resist flotation, collapse, or lateral movement. Methods of anchoring may include, but are not limited to, use of over-the-top or frame ties to ground anchors. This requirement is in addition to applicable State and local anchoring requirements for resisting wind forces. 
b.	Require that manufactured homes that are placed or substantially improved within Zones A1-30, AH, and AE on the community's FIRM on sites (i) outside of a manufactured home park or subdivision, (ii) in a new manufactured home park or subdivision, (iii) in an expansion to an existing manufactured home park or subdivision, or (iv) in an existing manufactured home park or subdivision on which a manufactured home has incurred "substantial damage" as a result of a flood, be elevated on a permanent foundation such that the bottom of the longitudinal structural I-beam of the manufactured home is elevated to or above the base flood elevation and be securely anchored to an adequately anchored foundation system to resist flotation, collapse, and lateral movement. 
c.	Require that manufactured homes be placed or substantially improved on sites in an existing manufactured home park or subdivision with Zones A1-30, AH and AE on the community's FIRM that are not subject to the provisions of paragraph (4) of this section be elevated so that either: 
1.	the bottom of the longitudinal structural I-beam of the manufactured home is at or above the base flood elevation, or 
2.	the manufactured home chassis is supported by reinforced piers or other foundation elements of at least equivalent strength that are no less than thirty-six (36) inches in height above grade and be securely anchored to an adequately anchored foundation system to resist flotation, collapse, and lateral movement. 
(5)	Recreational Vehicles. Require that recreational vehicles placed on sites within Zones A1-30, AH, and AE on the community's FIRM either (i) be on the site for fewer than 180 consecutive days, or (ii) be fully licensed and ready for highway use, or (iii) meet the permit requirements of Article D, section 12-7026(a), and the elevation and anchoring requirements for "manufactured homes" in paragraph (4) of this section. A recreational vehicle is ready for highway use if it is on its wheels or jacking system, is attached to the site only by quick disconnect type utilities and security devices, and has no permanently attached additions. 
(Ord. No. 811 , Art. 5, 11-15-10) 
Sec. 12-7041. - Standards for subdivision proposals. 
(a)	All subdivision proposals including the placement of manufactured home parks and subdivisions shall be consistent with Article A, sections 12-7002, 12-7003, and 12-7004 of this chapter. 
(b)	All proposals for the development of subdivisions including the placement of manufactured home parks and subdivisions shall meet floodplain development permit requirements of Article C, section 12-7008; Article D, section 12-7026; and the provisions of Article E of this chapter. 
(c)	Base flood elevation data shall be generated for subdivision proposals and other proposed development including the placement of manufactured home parks and subdivisions which is greater than fifty (50) lots or five (5) acres, whichever is lesser, if not otherwise provided pursuant to section Article C, 12-7007 or Article D, section 12-7025(8) of this chapter. 
(d)	All subdivision proposals including the placement of manufactured home parks and subdivisions shall have adequate drainage provided to reduce exposure to flood hazards. 
(e)	All subdivision proposals including the placement of manufactured home parks and subdivisions shall have public utilities and facilities such as sewer, gas, electrical and water systems located and constructed to minimize or eliminate flood damage. 
(Ord. No. 811 , Art. 5, 11-15-10) 
Sec. 12-7042. - Standards for areas of shallow flooding (AO/AH Zones). 
    Located within the areas of special flood hazard established in section Article C, 12-7007, are areas designated as shallow flooding. These areas have special flood hazards associated with flood depths of one (1) to three (3) feet where a clearly defined channel does not exist, where the path of flooding is unpredictable, and where velocity flow may be evident. Such flooding is characterized by ponding or sheet flow; therefore, the following provisions apply: 
(1)	All new construction and substantial improvements of residential structures have the lowest floor (including basement) elevated to or above the base flood elevation or the highest adjacent grade at least as high as the depth number specified in feet on the community's FIRM (at least two (2) feet if no depth number is specified). 
(2)	All new construction and substantial improvements of non-residential structures; 
a.	Have the lowest floor (including basement) elevated to or above the base flood elevation or the highest adjacent grade at least as high as the depth number specified in feet on the community's FIRM (at least two (2) feet if no depth number is specified), or 
b.	Together with attendant utility and sanitary facilities be designed so that below the base specified flood depth in an AO Zone, or below the base flood elevation in an AH Zone, level the structure is watertight with walls substantially impermeable to the passage of water and with structural components having the capability of resisting hydrostatic and hydrodynamic loads of effects of buoyancy. 
(3)	A registered professional engineer or architect shall submit a certification to the floodplain administrator that the standards of this section, as proposed in Article D, section 12-7026 are satisfied. 
(4)	Require within Zones AH or AO adequate drainage paths around structures on slopes, to guide flood waters around and away from proposed structures. 
(Ord. No. 811 , Art. 5, 11-15-10) 
Sec. 12-7043. - Floodways. 
    Floodways. located within areas of special flood hazard established in Article C, section 12-7007, are areas designated as floodways. Since the floodway is an extremely hazardous area due to the velocity of flood waters which carry debris, potential projectiles and erosion potential, the following provisions shall apply: 
(1)	Encroachments are prohibited, including fill, new construction, substantial improvements and other development within the adopted regulatory floodway unless it has been demonstrated through hydrologic and hydraulic analyses performed in accordance with standard engineering practice that the proposed encroachment would not result in any increase in flood levels within the community during the occurrence of the base flood discharge. 
(2)	If Article E, section 12-7043(1) above is satisfied, all new construction and substantial improvements shall comply with all applicable flood hazard reduction provisions of article E. 
(3)	Under the provisions of 44 CFR Chapter 1, Section 65.12, of the National Flood Insurance Program Regulation, a community may permit encroachments within the adopted regulatory floodway that would result in an increase in base flood elevations, provided that the community first completes all of the provisions required by Section 65.12. 
(Ord. No. 811 , Art. 5, 11-15-10) 
Sec. 12-7044. - Penalties for noncompliance. 
    No structure or land shall hereafter be constructed, located, extended, converted, or altered without full compliance with the terms of this chapter and other applicable regulations. Violation of the provisions of this chapter by failure to comply with any of its requirements (including violations of conditions and safeguards established in connection with conditions) shall constitute a misdemeanor. Any person who violates this chapter or fails to comply with any of its requirements shall upon conviction thereof be fined not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or imprisoned for not more than sixty (60) days, or both, for each violation. Each day the violation continues shall be deemed a new violation. In addition, the violator shall pay all costs and expenses involved in the case. Nothing herein contained shall prevent the City of Westlake from taking such other lawful action as is necessary to prevent or remedy any violation. 
(Ord. No. 811 , Art. 5, 11-15-10) 
CHAPTER 8. - TREES AND SHRUBBERY[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Cross reference- Utility trimming of trees, §§ 3-1008, 3-1028; trees and shrubbery encroaching onto sidewalks, § 8-2005 et seq. 

Sec. 12-8001. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to define, regulate and coordinate the planting, pruning, trimming, replanting, removal, disposal of, care and preservation of trees and shrubs, on the street rights-of-way and public property within the City of Westlake. Further, this chapter shall provide for the preservation, replacement and indiscriminate removal of trees on city property. In addition, this chapter shall provide for the removal of dead or diseased trees that present a safety hazard on private property within the City of Westlake corporate limits. Under the guidelines of this chapter there shall be created and established the Westlake City Tree Board. 
(Ord. No. 503, § 1, 1-14-93) 
Sec. 12-8002. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter unless the context otherwise requires, the words listed below shall have the meaning ascribed thereto: 
    Arboricultural specification: Those standards and specifications which govern the planting, trimming, bracing, pruning, spraying, fertilizing, removing, maintaining, controlling and preserving trees and shrubbery in accordance with accepted practices of University Horticulturalist and Louisiana Association of Nurserymen and Horticultural Specialists of the Louisiana Cooperative Extension Service. 
    City arborist: The agent designated by the city administration as being responsible for coordination and review of plans and actions affecting trees and shrubbery on public property. 
    Covered area: That area which falls within the drip line of any tree. 
    Destroy: Any intentional or negligent act which will cause a tree to decline and die within a period of two (2) years, including, but not limited to, such damage inflicted upon the root system of a tree by the application of toxic substances, the operation of heavy machinery, including trenching devices, the change of natural grade by excavation or filling the covered area or around the trunk of a tree, and damages from injury or fire inflicted on trees which result in or permit pest infestation. 
    Drip line: A vertical line extending from the outermost portion of a tree canopy to the ground. 
    Maintenance: In reference to maintenance of trees and shrubbery, any activity, including trimming, bracing, pruning or fertilizing of trees or shrubbery for the purpose of stabilizing, enhancing, protecting or controlling their growth. 
    Person: A public or private individual, corporation, company, firm, association, trust, estate, commission, board, institution, utility, cooperative or other legal entity. 
    Preservation: In reference to preservation of trees and shrubbery, any activity, including trimming, bracing, pruning, fertilizing, protecting or controlling of trees or shrubbery for the purpose of retaining such tree or shrub in its existing location. 
    Public property: Any real property within the corporate limits of the City of Westlake owned or maintained by the city of any of its departments or agencies. 
    Public right-of-way: Any parcel or strip of land within the corporate limits of the city which has been dedicated to and accepted for public use and maintenance by the city, including streets and alleys. 
    Removal: The actual removal of a tree or shrub by digging up or cutting down, or necessitating the removal through damage. 
    Shrubbery: Any self-supporting, woody plant species with a single or multiple trunk which normally attains an overall height of less than sixteen (16) feet at maturity. 
    Street tree: Trees, shrubs, bushes and all other woody vegetation planted or growing on land lying within public rights-of-way between the paved areas and the property lines of parcels fronting on said rights-of-way. 
    Tree: Any self-supporting woody perennial plant which has a trunk diameter of six (6) inches or more when measured at a point twelve (12) inches above the ground level and which normally attains an overall height of at least sixteen (16) feet at maturity. 
    Utility: Any publicly, privately, or cooperatively owned line, facility or system for producing, transmitting, or distributing communications, power, electricity, light, heat, gas, oil products, water, sewage, storm drainage or other similar services and commodities. 
(Ord. No. 503, § 2, 1-14-93) 
Sec. 12-8003. - City tree board created; membership, terms, compensation. 
    There is hereby created and established a city tree board, which shall consist of no less than five (5) and no more than ten (10) members, all of whom shall be citizens of and residents of this city, and who shall be appointed by the mayor and confirmed by a majority vote of the city council. The membership of the tree board shall consist of at least one (1) member of the city council, one (1) member who is a professional arborist of the city, three (3) members who shall be persons of the full age of majority and residents of the city. 
    The mayor shall be an ex officio member of the tree board. 
    The term of office for board members shall be one (1) year. 
    Members of the board shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 503, § 3, 1-14-93) 
Sec. 12-8004. - Duties and responsibilities of the tree board. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the Westlake City Tree Board to study, investigate, counsel and develop or update annually, and administer a written plan for the care, preservation, pruning, planting, replanting, removal or disposal of trees and shrubs in parks, along streets and in other public areas. Such plan shall be presented semi-annually to the mayor and city council and upon their acceptance and approval shall constitute the official comprehensive tree plan for the city. 
    The board, when requested by the city council, shall investigate, make findings and reports and recommendations upon any special matter of question coming within the scope of its work. 
    The board shall act in an advisory nature to the mayor and city council in connection with the implementation and work of the comprehensive tree plan. 
(Ord. No. 503, § 4, 1-14-93) 
Sec. 12-8005. - Operation of tree board. 
    The Westlake City Tree Board shall meet at least semi-annually. A majority of the members shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. One (1) representative of the tree board will be selected to report on their activities to the mayor and city council in whatever method deemed appropriate (i.e., through correspondence and/or attending a city council meeting). 
(Ord. No. 503, § 5, 1-14-93) 
Sec. 12-8006. - Power and authority of city. 
    The city shall have full power and authority over all trees, plants and shrubs planted or hereafter planted in the street rights-of-way, parks and public places within the corporate limits. The maintenance of such trees, plants and shrubs shall be subject to the provisions of this chapter. In addition, the city shall have full power and authority over the removal of dead or diseased trees which present a safety hazard on public or private property within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 503, § 6, 1-14-93) 
Sec. 12-8007. - Maintenance and removal of trees. 
    The city through the City of Westlake Tree Board shall have the following powers and duties for the maintenance and removal responsibility of trees and shrubs in the City of Westlake: 
(a)	Responsibility. The city or its appointed representative shall be responsible for the maintenance of trees on public property. 
(b)	City approval. Except in cases of emergencies, any person desiring to remove, destroy, cut, prune, including the root system of any tree or shrub on public property shall first receive written permission from the city tree representatives, who shall follow the intentions and requirements of this chapter when considering the removal of trees. 
(c)	Tree removal. Generally, public trees shall not be removed unless an imminent health and/or safety hazard is probable. Such threat shall be determined by the city arborist. 
Developers and private builders shall follow guidelines in the city zoning ordinance for subdivisions or individual home construction. Removal of trees on city rights-of-way or easements shall be requested through the city arborist prior to construction. Removal of trees shall follow the procedures outlined in this chapter. 
Developers and private builders desiring to plant trees on street rights-of-way shall plant those trees approved pursuant to this chapter. They will additionally adhere to the guidelines under planting of trees contained in this chapter. 
(d)	Pruning. When the city, any person or business is maintaining or cutting limbs on public trees, proper pruning techniques shall be followed. The minimal criteria for pruning of trees shall be as follows: 
(1)	In general, the best time to prune most trees is during the late winter or early spring, before new growth appears (usually between March 1 and May 1). 
(2)	All final pruning cuts shall be made smooth and flush to the tree. Care should be taken not to leave a stub on a tree as this is an excellent port of entry for decay and fungi. 
(3)	Stub cutting of heavy limbs is recommended to prevent splitting the wood and stripping the bark. 
(e)	Replacement and stump removal. Prior to removal of public trees, the party responsible shall make arrangements in concurrence with the city arborist or designee for replacement trees. The party responsible for cutting and/or removing public trees shall make arrangements to remove or grind down the remaining stump and surface roots. In the case of grinding, the stump and surface roots shall be removed from the site and the area leveled with topsoil. 
(f)	Permit to utilities: All work by private utility companies or their agents that will impact public trees should be under review of the city through written specifications, permit and inspection. The costs of work performed by the city or designee performing the inspection of line clearance should be charged to the utility company not bearing a franchise with the city on a pre-arranged schedule. 
Routine scheduled maintenance for all utility companies will require a thirty-day written notice, by notifying the city through its designee to coordinate and inventory the work to be performed prior to commencement under an approved permit. Any work performed under such permit must be done in strict accordance with the conditions of the permit and the provisions of this section. 
(g)	Permits to private arborist. All work that impacts public trees by private arborist should be under the review of the city or designee in charge of public trees through written specifications, permits and inspections. 
(Ord. No. 503, § 7, 1-14-93) 
Sec. 12-8008. - Planting of trees. 
(a)	Before planting of any tree on city rights-of-way property, approval must be given in writing from the office of the mayor certifying the city council approval. 
(b)	New trees planted shall conform to the approved tree species list and shall take into consideration utility lines above and below ground on public rights-of-way. 
(c)	No street trees, other than those listed as small or medium sized trees, may be planted under or within ten (10) lateral feet from any overhead utility wire or directly over any underground water, sewer, or transmission line. 
(d)	No street tree shall be planted closer than twenty (20) feet of any street corner (measured from the nearest intersecting curb or curb lines). No street tree shall be planted closer than ten (10) feet from a fire hydrant. 
(e)	The city shall plant new street trees to replace dead or diseased trees adhering to the provisions of subsections (b), (c) and (d) above. 
(f)	Generally, the locations of new trees shall be governed by a site analysis by the Westlake City Tree Board. 
(Ord. No. 503, § 8, 1-14-93) 
Sec. 12-8009. - Approved tree species. 
    The following list constitutes those tree species that are acceptable as street trees. Small trees are considered those growing no more than thirty (30) feet in height at maturity. Medium trees are considered those that grow no more than forty-five (45) feet in height at maturity. Large trees are those that grow to a height of over fifty (50) feet at maturity. 
Small Trees Medium Trees Large Trees Redbud American Holly Sugar Maple Mayhaw RiverBirch Tulip Poplar Silverbell Golden Rain Pin Oak Sweetbay Magnolia Sassafras Shumard Oak Magnolia Soulangeana Red Cedar Water Oak Dahoon Holly Blue Beech White Oak Wax Myrtle Hophornbeam Live Oak Deciduous Holly Bradford Pear Cow Oak Cassine Holly Chinese Elm Small Leaf Elm Crepe Myrtle Black Gum Thornless - HoneyLocust Dogwood Green Ash Parsley Hawthorn Bald Cypress Crab Apple Gingko (male) Red Maple Hickory Southern Red Oak Southern Magnolia  
(Ord. No. 503, § 9, 1-14-93) 
Sec. 12-8010. - Owner's pruning for corner clearance. 
    Every owner of any tree on private land overhanging any street within the city shall prune the branches so that there is no obstruction of view for motorists at street intersections. Said owner shall remove all dead, diseased, or dangerous trees that constitute a menace to public safety. The city shall have the right to prune any tree or shrub, private or public, when such tree or shrub interferes with visibility along a street or obstructs a street light or traffic control sign. 
(Ord. No. 503, § 10, 1-14-93) 
Sec. 12-8011. - Dead or diseased tree removal. 
    The city shall have the right to cause the removal of any dead or diseased trees on private property within the city, when such trees constitute a hazard to life or property, or harbor insects or disease which constitutes a potential threat to other trees within the city. The mayor shall notify in writing the owners of such trees. Removal shall be done by said owners at their expense within sixty (60) days after notification. In the event failure of owners to comply with such provisions, the city shall have the authority to remove the dead or diseased tree(s) and charge the costs of removal to the owner. 
(Ord. No. 503, § 11, 1-14-93) 
Sec. 12-8012. - Attachment of devices to trees. 
    The city will not permit any person to attach signs, wires, chains, or other devices which would be injurious to a tree. 
(Ord. No. 503, § 12, 1-14-93) 
Sec. 12-8013. - Construction projects. 
    Where feasible, contractors, city crews, and other persons working on public rights-of-way shall tunnel under major tree roots rather than using trenches, which sever the roots. Tunneling shall be used when placing underground utilities that interfere with existing street trees. In cases where tunneling cannot be accomplished, the construction contractor, city crew or other persons working on the public rights-of-way shall notify the city prior to pursuing further work. 
(Ord. No. 503, § 13, 1-14-93) 
Sec. 12-8014. - Penalties for violations. 
    Any person violating any provisions of this chapter or who shall fail to comply with any of the requirements of this chapter, shall be subject to a fine not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00), for the first offense; and not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense thereafter. An offense is construed to encompass damage to an individual tree or shrub planted/growing on public rights-of-way. Fines will be levied for each tree or shrub damaged accordingly. 
(Ord. No. 503, § 14, 1-14-93) 
Sec. 12-8015. - Appeals. 
    In the event any person is dissatisfied with the decision of the authorized representative of this chapter, that person may make written appeal to the Westlake City Council. The council shall render its written opinion, affirming, overruling or modifying the decision of the respective agent as may be fit and proper under the existing circumstances. The decision of the city council shall be forwarded to the person who has made appeal in the form of written notification validated by the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 503, § 15, 1-14-93) 
Sec. 12-8016. - Conflicting provisions. 
    In the case where a provision of this chapter is found to be in conflict with a provision of any other ordinance or code in effect in the City of Westlake which established a lower standard for regulating and controlling the planting, maintenance, preservation, or removal of trees and shrubs, the provisions of this chapter shall prevail, and such other ordinances or codes are hereby declared to be repealed to the extent that they may be found in conflict with this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 503, § 16, 1-14-93) 
CHAPTER 9. - STORM WATER 
ARTICLE A. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 12-9001. - Title. 
    This chapter shall be known as the "Storm Water Code of the City of Westlake, Louisiana" and may be cited and referred to herein as "this chapter". 
(Ord. No. 893 , 11-16-15) 
Sec. 12-9002. - Purpose. 
    The purpose and objectives of this chapter are as follows: 
(1)	To maintain and improve the quality of surface water and groundwater within the City of Westlake. 
(2)	To prevent the discharge of contaminated storm water runoff from industrial, commercial, residential, and construction sites into the municipal separate storm sewer system (MS4) and natural waters affected by the City of Westlake. 
(3)	To promote public awareness of the hazards involved in the improper discharge of hazardous substances, petroleum products, household hazardous waste, industrial waste, sediment from construction sites, pesticides, herbicides, fertilizers, and other contaminants into the storm sewers and natural waters of the City of Westlake. 
(4)	To encourage the recycling of used motor oil and safe disposal of other hazardous consumer products. 
(5)	To facilitate compliance with state and federal standards and permits by owners and operators of industrial and construction sites within the City of Westlake. 
(6)	To enable the City of Westlake to comply with all federal and state laws and regulations applicable to storm water discharges. 
(Ord. No. 893 , 11-16-15) 
Sec. 12-9003. - Administration. 
    Except as other provided herein, the director of public works shall administer, implement, and enforce the provisions of this chapter. Any powers granted to or duties imposed upon the director of public works shall be carried out by that person and may be delegated by the director of public works to other city personnel. 
(Ord. No. 893 , 11-16-15) 
Secs. 12-9004-12-9009. - Reserved.
